content:
Posted: March 16, 2015
												You want the truth, so here it is: I wish Steam had a stars rating system... I'd give it 3 out of 5.  This game is very good, and really is worth the purchase.  (At least until something better comes along.)Some will criticize it as being "simcade", harping on "mediocre physics", etc., and they're right that it's a simcade but not right about the physics at all.  So here's how it really is.  The physics are top notch, simulation grade.  However, great physics don't make a simulator.  True, great physics are a requirement of being a simulator, but a simulator is more than just a set of well implemented physics rules.  That is where such critics get confused: they tend to view physics and simulation as one and the same, but that's just not reality.  The handling and physics models really are quite good.  (The only aspect of physical simulation I think they could improve greatly on is the force feedback - it's good, but not great.)However, this game is a GAME, first and foremost.  What separates it from the likes of iRacing is not "bad physics" (again, they're quite good) but the approach to development, which is very game oriented.  For instance, many of the cars DON'T actually handle like their real world counterparts (for instance the GT-R is far more "understeery" than it is in real life)... however, they DO handle very much like *A* real car... just not necessarily the car being represented.  I believe the reason it is that way is because of lack of research - research I'd guess the developer didn't feel was necessary since the goal was balanced gameplay, and as long as they acheived balanced trade-offs within a given class of car, and it was approximately true to life, that was "good enough".  (However, in my opinion, it's NOT good enough, but I digress.)Another aspect that is very game-ish rather than simulation-ish, is the A.I. (computer driven) cars/players are extremely and frustratingly aggressive.  I read in the developer's blog how proud they were of their aggressive A.I., but I feel they missed the mark.  In real life racing, there is aggression, no doubt, but there is also a sense of caution... no pro race car driver will intentionally derail another driver into a potentially fatal crash - unless they want to be arrested for manslaughter.  Gently tapping/touching/etc. to throw another driver off their game, sure, that happens in real life (and is very controversial)... but repeated hammering until you spin out of control or completely T-boning your car is absolutely NOT realistic.  At times, Grid Autosport reminds me of the old game "frogger", where it feels like the point is to dodge speeding cars as you cross the road, cars that are actually trying to hit you (or at least don't care at all if they do.)  To make this worse, if you return the aggression, the A.I. cars are very difficult to disorient or make slide/spin, whereas they can feel free to derail you at will.  This is the most frustrating aspect of Grid Autosport.  To introduce this kind of A.I. logic is to add a layer of "random chance"... a layer that is very inappropriate in a purely skill oriented venue.Frankly, I don't think that Codemasters (the developer) really understands their audience - we want the wonderful online gameplay and comradery (which is excellent by the way), great cars to drive (and they are) in an immersive and realistic environment (also quite good), but we don't want to waste our time on "games of chance".  Racing is a purely skill oriented discipline... there's no element of random chance whatsoever (not counting weather, which Grid Autosport doesn't have anyhow.)  We want the good aspects of "gameplay" with the best of simulation... because we want to believe that we're real live race car drivers... that's the illusion we want to buy when we give them our money.  This is where Codemasters really misses the mark - they don't seem to get that at all - they seem only to understand the "rules of game design" without considering what we the audience really, truly want: A racing simulation that keeps us immersed and believing that it’s real but gives us a sense of PROGRESSION and ACHEIVEMENT found primarily in games.  Ruining the illusion with random chance and puerile A.I. ruins the experience, and wastes our time and money.The bottom line is that the physics are excellent (if you can forgive inaccurate representations of specific cars), the graphics are excellent, online racing is outstanding, but the A.I. is horrible, frustrating, and hardly fun at all.  If it weren't for the great online gameplay, I'd say avoid this title, but on the whole, it's worth getting.

												I spend almost 2500 hours in this game so I must say that Grid Autosport is a great game worth a lot of time playing.To make 2500 hours long story shorter I will simply just write down whats good and whats bad from my point of view  GOOD- great realistic racing,awesome gameplay- cars are nicely devided by classes,so whatever car you choose it is the right one and it gives you the opportunity for close racing- tuning cars is very effective,large possibility for improvement and setting the car according to your style- multiplayer is made very well,racing,leveling each discipline,leveling cars,racenet challenges,upgrades,tuning,repairs    and the whole online career is great- penalties for cutting the corner are made well and don't cause pileup crashes on multiplayer like on GRID 2- idea about racenet clubs is great- AI behavior and difficulty- great graphics,physics and car damage  BAD- worst career mode so far from a GRID series (playing just as a driver for a hire,long and boring progress,no money to spend)- some bugs that has never been fixed (racing line bug,AI stuck on multiplayer,save data corrupt which is the worst case scenario bug)- most of the tracks and cars are already seen and played in GRID 2- not enough room in multiplayer garage to have a car for every class- so-called "riding the wall" thing is yet again very possible- expiriance points system on multiplayer is very bad (same xp for a 1 lap or a 20 laps race)- same engine sound use 2 different cars (Ford Sierra and Lancia Delta have the same engine sound for example and some others like that)- THERES NO CORVETTE IN THE GAME!As a fan of a GRID series this game deserves a great 8.5/10 it's a great realistic racing game that most of us wanted at the first place after GRID 1,but on the other hand there is a big taste of this being just a very quick game build and a remake of GRID 2

												So, after I bought this game for about 6 dollars on *steam censorship*.com, I thought about making a review about this.So, how does it drive?Actually, better than I thought. I expected some kind of GRID 2-ish handling, but it drives way more like DiRT 3 with more grip and only on ashpalt. Although it is pretty much realism-trimmed, It´s still very fun to drive, especially the Street Cars.And if you´re looking for the most realistic game of the GRID franchise, here you go.The Drift Races still suck tho.Content?Yes.How much?Very much. Most tracks are taken from GRID/GRID 2, but all of them are redone. San Francisco looks way better now. But of course there are multiple new tracks, a few city tracks and race tracks like Hockenheimring and Red Bull Ring (I think, read that somewhere)There is a huge range of cars, everything from numerous kinds of street cars, over classic japanese tuners, muscles and even damn racing trucks, to formula/indycars and touring cars.Grafficks?They exist. And it looks awesome for a game on an engine from 2006. And the difference in graphics between DiRT and GRID Autosport is like the difference between Battlefield BC and Battlefield 4.ayy lmao, dis no sim racur, dis no hev weel optiuns.You´re right, except you´re wrong. Codie´s fixed that in the meanwhile and if you got a Force Feedback Wheel, please try this, this is so much fun with a FFB Wheel.Multiplayer?Exists too. Haven´t tried it yet though.Overpriced?Actually not at all. GRID 2 is overpriced, I won´t pay 30 bucks for Tokyo Drift Simulator. But for the content this is actually wellpriced. Wouldn´t buy the DLCs though, not a fan of them anyway.Cockpit view?Yeeeeahhh-no. Something weird. You have a Dashcam and a normal Cockpit Cam, but the dash in Cockpit Cam is all blurred out for you, so you can´t see that Codemasters didn´t put an HQ Cockpit in your car or even the dials don´t work.Story?noone cares m8The End?Yes. Overall this is a Wellpriced, good looking, well drivable Racing Simulator. Get it. content:
Posted: April 18, 2016
												By far the best value in PC Arcade racers today. While games like Assetto Corsa and Project Cars concentrate on realizm and driving simulator game play, Grid Autosport balances nicely between Arcade and Sim racers. Course designs are easily familiar to the real world courses and course diversity is average. Custom Skins and the abilty to make groups is great but the online multiplayer sessions can be a bit confusing at times when you are trying to meet up with a buddy due in part to the cumbersome RaceNet interface which differs from regular online play.  The stoyline, while lengthy and appears to be full of diverse content, ultimately forces a driver to be all things to all forms of racing, which si not something that actually happens in the racing world. Graphics are 9/10, Audio is 9/10, Controls support 9/10 and content 8/10 (just because I am not into all the tuner and drift stuff). Overall I rate the game 85-90 out of 100 in total game ranking & is worth the on sale price.

Only buy if you play Singleplayer or have a set of friends to play with in Multiplayer.I bought the game at its release and this is what's negative about it:CONS- Codemasters community manager repeatedly claimed that they would constantly improve and patch the game for at least a year after its release. He blatantly lied. - Online play is pretty much dead, you have to switch your Steam download region to UK to be able to find some players- Cheaters in multiplayer matches, cheats which their anticheat can't detect and exist since the release, the kind of cheats which slightly increase your grip or acceleration so beginners think their cars just have better upgrades. - Driving and body physics are fairly arcade-like and unpredictable at times, some cars feel clumsy, e.g. with a keyboard you can't corner as good as a gamepad driver due to steering angle problemsFor me personally it's an improvment towards GRID 2 but still a step backwards compared to GRID 1. So overall it's playable but still a disappointment.I recommend buying "Forza Horizon 3" instead.

content:
Posted: June 27, 2014
												I bought this game thinking it would be completely different than the other games in the GRID series. The "authentic handling" as stated in the description caught my eye as GRID 2 was all about drifting every single car around corners at crazy speeds. I was very disappointed to learn that nothing has changed. This game feels like GRID 2 with better graphics, the same drifty handling, and the same waste of money for someone looking for a, "authentic handling" or simulator experience. This brings me to the controls, I'm sure the game is manageable with a controller or even a keyboard and mouse, but with a wheel like a G27, good luck. The shifting, should you choose to use a manual transmission with a clutch and H shifter is horrid, cars pop out of gear at random times and most of the time you can't put the car back into gear because the game simply won’t recognize it. All in all, the game isn't what I was looking for and Codemasters has only given the series a new set of pretty textures and not much else. If you liked the other GRID games, by all means this is nothing different but if your someone looking for a sim experience I recommend you look into Race 07, and Asseto Corsa and not dump $50 on this game like I did.

content:
Posted: December 24, 2015
75/100Pretty fun racing game!  I expected it to be more realistic when it comes to car handling, but it is in fact quite arcady and a bit loose. I am playing with a Xbox controller and the controls are not super responsive and direct when it comes to the steering with the L joystick, but it's acceptable. You might need to get used to it a bit in the beginning, after that it's fine.The game has a ton of cups and challenges to keep you busy for many many hours (enough content). Even with the arcady feel it is actually quite chalenging to drive against the AI! So far as I have played the amount of different tracks is quite low, I played for 7 hours and only driven half a dozen different tracks (and reversed), also the amount of different cars and classes is quite low. One really noticable quality gap in the game is the cockpit view. It is really low detailed in most/all cars and they made the cockpit on the lower part of your screen blurry to camouflage it. It is extra noticable, because basically everything else in the game is pretty solid and good quality. As for realism I think this game falls far below the racing sims on the market. Even Gran Turismo feels more real (direct/responsive) when it comes to car handling, but the AI in GRID is way more fun to race against and the races are more custimizable then in Gran Turismo. I also don't think that this game tries or was intended to be a realistic racing sim, but an enjoyable not over complicated racing experience. And that it does quite well. Overall I think this is a pretty solid and fun racing game and worthy to pick up during a sale.

content:
Posted: July 1, 2016
												Having over 600 hours in this game, having a lot of fun racing, having completed all achievements;I do not recommend this game!Here are the simple reasons why:A.I. online driver system is broken: It happens in online racing that A.I. drivers will not show up on the starting grid, or never leave at the start of the race. This results in them never finishing that race and all players being stuck in a lobby, having to reset the game.My savegame got corruptedSteam Cloud my♥♥♥♥♥(and i'm fairly confident that VAC is also falsely advertised). Anyway i lost my complete carreer, all my cars, all my cash. Which brings me to my next two:Chunks of money vapor from your bankaccount.Leveling system in cars. May have seemed like a good idea, but with this small community it's simply impossible to level max some cars. I'm not a fan. (Cheatengine helps here, "c'mon Codies, don't ban me for this, you forced this upon me.")Keyboard input randomly stops for a splitsecond! Yes i am a keyboard racedriver, sorry... But seriously on random moments in a race my car will go straight on while already cornering and tapping my keys, they suddenly don't register anymore. Not cool at all and conciderably gamebreaking! Especcially uncool when it causes me to crash another racer offtrack. And NO it's not a hardware failure, i've had this on different systems and keyboards and heard others experiencing this. (sidenote, aside for this bug the controlabilty of the cars through keyboard is great!! no controler or wheel needed)Garage limitation. There is not enough room in the garage to buy a racecar for every racing class. There is DLC available for €7.- !!! to expand your garage with just 5 slots, still not enough to have a racecar in every class. Shamefull! I would even prefer to have 2 owned cars in some classes..Still.... bearing through all this, i DO ENJOY PLAYING THIS GAME, a lot! It's a great and fun racing game, looks great feels great plays great, a nice community, friendly fair, but unfortunatly thinning out. Don't be too surprised when there is no one to race against at 3.00 am on a weekday. Check the playercount yourselves, here: http://steamcharts.com/search/?q=grid+autosportConcidering all this, can i fully recommend this? No.  Will i myself buy the next Grid game? Likely yes, on a sale. If it has good reviews,Tip for the Codies: Your game installments could do well with a replay system of online races, like .demo files. Allowing your racers to capture races from playback. I.m.o. there is no better promotion than good YouTube coverage of your game.I would have uploaded tons of races if a had an option to watch and record a replay later.

number of helpful: 16 of 25 people (64%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 12, 2015
												After Grid 2, I felt there was a lot of good things to be made in the next instalment in the GRID series and I was happy to find out that many were improved. I have invested easily twice the time when comparing to GRID 2 and there was a reason for this. The multi-disciplined Events offer you a lot more variety and it's great for those who are a fan of mixing different race styles. From Endurance races to Tuner and Street you also have Touring Events and Open Wheel as well giving you different tastes of what's available in the racing words. For me all were great aside of any Drift events. It's nothing personal but I love to race in all sorts of classes but when it comes to win by points in a corner by making good use of your handbrake the racer fan in me feels a bit bored. As you advance in all events you will get a chance of having better sponsors interested in you with more difficulty and challenging objectives to complete such beating a rival time, finish above 5th place, then 3rd place and so on.There is a clear effort in making this game a pleasant experience for the racing fans but even after so many efforts there is still much to be done. Endurance races are great but it lacks some proper tuning and the duration of most of them are not really what I would call endurance since the bigger ones are around 12 minutes long. Qualifications are back and it's a great opportunity to set a time to start on a better position. The audio is the best effort I've seen in the grid series. You really do not need any soundtrack or any other sound effect. You just need to remove all the hud in the game, increase the volume and you will have such a good time driving while pushing to the max to the next gear. There are also little things that did not go unnoticed. For instance, you can ask (with the D-pad) what is the current state of your car (gearbox, engine damage, etc) as well the position of your rival, team-mate and so on. If you are entering a tunnel and you ask for this info you can see there's a difference in the sound from the speaker since the signal may be weaker. These little things are always appreciated. One last thing regarding the sound: I loved GRID 2 main theme and it's a such a shame that I felt a downgrade regarding the tunes/themes in the menus (not to mention these menus are quite... bland). Then there are the community feedback that Codemasters did or tried to achieve with things like the Cockpit view. For many racing fans this view not only is a must but it's also the only view they play their racing games. So, in order to keep fans happy Codemasters implemented this view but to be honest this was the most poor effort I've seen in adding something that is a big request in these games. First I thought that my eyes were deceiving me because I've played and seen many recent games with great looking cockpit views like Driveclub and Project Cars so it crossed my mind I was not being fair to GRID Autosport since this game was released some time ago. Then I just remembered. Games like Dirt 2 or Dirt 3 do have a cockpit view and they are quite nicely done, if you ask me. So what happened here? Was no time to develop a better view and they just tried a quick solution? For those who haven't seen it, go check it out. It's a dark, blurry mess with no details at all. Seriously. This was such a wasted opportunity and I can see why so many fans were upset with all this.One thing I also liked was the Cups between the major events. This would be races without a team member and they had a great selection of either prototypes or older gems, something I'm fond of. But still, I wish I could have seen more of them.In the end, I had great fun with Autosport. I played more than 50 hours, I did more than 400 races, leveled up every single category to level 10 or above and finished all the major events, all cups with many qualifications as well. Side Curiosity: It is thanks to Ben Gouldstone, the Senior Game Designer of Driveclub that the racetrack from Algarve, in Portugal is a reality after he gave this feedback to the Codemasters team. It's great to see when companies are open to all sorts of feedback in order to bring more variety and content to their games.

content:
Posted: December 1, 2015
												GRID Autosport is a racing game released by Codemasters in 2014. Similar to the Colin McRae Rally games, GRID Autosport takes us to the world of professional racing, on a variety of authentic tracks, with real cars from around the world. Not exactly a driving simulator, more like a racing career simulator, as you get sponsors, achieve objectives. I compare all racing games to Gran Turismo 2, which is arguably one of the best racing/driving sims ever made, and GRID Autosport does a good job of trying to live up to such high standards. Unfortunately, I found the lack of individual car customization to be a disappointment, and I wish that you could buy cars as you win races and earn money. This isn't the case however, as  you earn reputation and experience, instead of cash, for winning. Still a great game, lovely detail, the tracks are challenging, the AI is competitive, I think racing fans will enjoy this game.

content:
Posted: August 25, 2015
												GRID Autosport is a good game... but it's not a racing sim. Not even close to being one. Handling certainly is more natural and realistic than in GRID 2 (in which drifting somehow gained you more momentum out of corners), but it's still pretty arcady. It's not necessarily a bad thing, but since this game was advertised as more sim-like racing game, I wanted to clarify, that it's not really true. It's still a good game though, if you don't mind somewhat "floaty" handling model (typical to all Codemasters games). AI is kinda fun to drive against, although they tend to ignore any clean driving rules, so you need to get used to that.Although to be honest, I wouldn't buy it for full price - definitely wait for a sale, hopefully GRID 3 will be better.Pros:+ Okay optimisation+ Well structured career mode+ On-demand radio communication+ Overall nice sensation of speed+ It's fun, yet somewhat challenging+ Dem nightrace graphicsCons:- Blurry cockpits- Races lack some depth, no pit stops, no weather changes, etc.- Seriously, no actual mirrors on cars in racing game from 2014?- AI is reckless, especially in first lap, flashback is a must on higher difficulty levels- Annoying control bug - sometimes I just lose throttle or steering wheel for no reason- Just handful of actual tracks (somewhat compensated by many variations of one circuit)- Multiplayer is almost dead by now (August 2015)

												Well, what can i say?  I thought this maybe a return to the excellent days of TOCA but I was sadly mistaken.  If you are a fan of race sims and use a wheel then I'm afraid this game is a waste of money.  In single player mode the AI just smash the♥♥♥♥♥♥out of you and it's even worse online.  The game is infested with joypad players who are just zig zagging all over the track and don't seem to realise that the idea of the game is to try and pass you fair and square.  However, what your sadly presented with is a community full of "smash to pass" players who don't seem to have any grasp of the words "Gentlemanly Behaviour".  I've done several online races now and there doesn't seem to be any penalties for contact but theres plenty of penalties for clipping a corner a SMALL degree (With two tyres still on the tarmac and inside the white line).  I'm sorry but this is just another GRID with the same old churned up♥♥♥♥♥♥♥with additional cars and tracks (Most of which have been produced for their other games such as  the F1 series) which has been produced for the chavvy masses to smash the♥♥♥♥♥♥out of each other.  Oh, the graphics are excellent but the interior views are all blurred out as they couldn't be arsed to go into detail....another♥♥♥♥♥♥part of this extremely poor game.   4/10 -  I've had more fun having teeth pulled out.

												I bought this game for the multiplayer games.That's the biggest mistake I made.The multiplayer is dead.No one plays it and you'll have to change your download region to UK in order to find matches.That's ridiculous.I think it's better if you wait for a little while until this game gets more popular if you wanna buy it.I wasn't really interested in the single player games,though.So I only played the single player for the first 2 races.To be honest,I'm not really worth it to not recommend this game since I only played for 1 hour.It's just totally disappointing that no one plays the multiplayer because my main reason for purchasing steam games was for the multiplayer expierence.And about the game's content,I'll say the overall is really great.Stunning graphics,cool cars,and the engine sound makes you wanna drive more and more.But with the dead multiplayer,I lost my whole interest in this game.

number of helpful: 8 of 11 people (73%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: August 5, 2016
												If you like the type of a game where you want to throw your pad at the wall out of anger and then pick it up 2 mins later to continue playing this might be perfect for you.TL;DRIf you plan to get the game for some single player racing - don'tIf you plan to get the game for some multi player racing - don'tUnless you are a fan of GRID games and can get it for like 5$ max, you can buy it if you want to.Good things:1. Graphics and optimisation The game looks really nice, even compared to new games and it's so well optimised that a decent pc can run it at medium-high or high settings with 60+fps. Night races are good looking and occasional eye catchers like jets or baloons are a nice thing.2. Driving modelIt's not a simulator, but still, driving model is very nice and somehow addicting, it's just fun driving in this game.3. Multiplayer part 1If you can get few friends to play with you, the game can be really fun.Meh things:1. SoundsSound is okay-ish, cars sound good, there is also some music. Nothing too impressive, but not bad either.2. Career modeAt the beginning it's fun, but after some time it gets so boring and repetitive you completely space out when you want to do it. For the occasional races it's much better to create your own cup.3. Amount of carsWell, there are many known cars, both old and new ones, but still, feels like more wouldn't hurt and well...who wouldn't want more cars?4. RacenetSometimes connecting to racenet takes a while - it's not a super long time, but still few seconds. It can be annoying when you have to do it multiple times.Bad things:1. AIPeople responsible for creating AI for this game should be tied to a pole and hit with rotten tomatoes for every ruined race. The AI is just made to irritate the player as much as possible, it's the cause of failing like 80 out of 100 races. They block your line on purpose, won't let you pass on straights unless the track is wide, block you on the corners while they're slow as snails, block the hell out of the road on first corners, brake early, sometimes they crash with each other and they even ram you off the road. They feel like they have only two states - either you don't exist for them on the track, or you do, but they are so agressive it's ridiculous. Driving among them feels like defusing 5 bombs at the same time - you never know which one will do what. They can easily do the pit maneuver on you, but if you try to ram them out of anger, their cars behave like they weight at least 4 tons. It's worth noting that if you manage to pass an AI car, they seem to slow down. They also don't get any penalties...oh those penalties...2. Penalties So what about the remaining 20 out of 100 causes of faling the races? 6 of them are crashing the car or going off the track by yourself and ridiculous penalties you get for cutting the track are the other 14.Sure, there definitely should be a way to punish the player for cutting the track, but the system in this game...it's crap.Penalties slow you down to 50 km/h for a short duration, which is decided by how much you've cut the track...well that's all in theory, in practice you get 5 seconds of penalty for slightly-yet-completely-acceptable cutting when you go over the white line by few centimenters or sometimes even not go over it at all. That type of penalty completely ruins your lap or race and all the fun in trying to get the best time as possible by creating the fastest racing line by yourself. This penalty system was a failure from the very beginning, sadly there's nothing that can be done about it. A simple time penalty PROPERLY calculated would be much better.3. Weekly challengesWhile they are a good way to earn money in the game, it's extremely frustrating. In theory you can compete with other players in the world for the best time while getting paid for it - sounds nice? BAM, in reality you get the two problems from above and sometimes some ridiculous requirements for platinum. I'm 99% sure nobody checks if those times are possible to beat, just some AI(ugh) system sets it. I'm not the best driver there is, but good enough to be really fast with practice, and sometimes even when you practice one challenge over and over and over again until there's nothing that can be improved, you're still not getting that platinum. Weird thing is sometimes it's so easy to get platinum you can get it on the first try, even with some racing errors.4. Multiplayer part 2Well. we know how multiplayer racing games are - there are many good, clean racers and also there are the ones that crash other players and ruin the fun - this game is no different. Who knows, maybe those crashers are people who got angry at the AI? You can kick crashers if they get enough votes to kick...yeah, "if" is the keyword.There is voice chat, which people with always-on-and-over-sensitive microphones love. You can mute them, no problem, but only if you're in the lobby before the race. Yep, even while you've crashed or abandoned the race, all you can do is listen to whiny comments or weird music or some other sounds.There is no text chat, which should be available in a pc game, but when you think about it - maybe it's better you don't have to read about who did what with your mother, but then again, they can crash into you instead, so I don't know really.There is also a small problem with lags. Sometimes you will get pushed out of the track and the other person might not even know about it and vice versa. The only solution to this is to keep a safe distance. And while we talk about multiplayer races...5. "Rewards" from racing......or rather lack of them. If you are racing in an expensive rental car, it won't matter if you finish 1st or 8th - you won't earn anything, instead you lose money for repairs after every race. I call it investing in the races to get better and have a laugh about it, but really I'm laughing through tears.So in the end very few pros and many cons. Shame really, this game had potential to be really fun, but too many things are just bad. I wouldn't recommend buying it, there are so many better alternatives.

content:
Posted: November 19, 2016
												There seem to be many negative reviews of this game mostly by people who have tired it for 5 mins and found that unlike Need for Speed and other driving games aimed at children and the feeble-minded, there is a learning curve.. you need to MAKE AN EFFORT.. you cannot drive GRID autosport and watch TV or text.. you need to concentrate and get the feel of the vehicles etc.. which is actually very realistic and rewarding and just about the best intuitive and responsive car handling that there is in ANY PC driving game currently available. If you want to slam in to all the barriers and hit everything but not lose speed this is not the game for you.. go play My Little Pony or some other empty pointless rubbish which is suited to you.Some people (beginners) told me that GRID autosport is not accessible , what they mean is 'not totally and effortlessly easy'... why bother to walk and talk.. did you learn that instantly??Single player mode is VERY CRAPPY and boring.. but who cares because the real action is online multiplayer where you can race others and create/host your own sessions with your choice of settings, cars and tracksDO NOT pay attention to the negative reviewers who speak more of themselves than of the game.Try it for yourself and you will see GRID autosport is quite simply one of the BEST driving games currently available.. one of the best EVER (so far)GRID Autosport is an excellent arcade racer with superb vehicle handling, an intuitive and very responsive fun racer from Touring Cars to Open Wheel, there's something to please everyone... except feeble-minded My Little Pony lamers.. and sad losers who are used to having everything done for them and mummy holding their hands.. oh there there little baby did the nasty game make you angry.. mummy will kiss it better.

content:
Posted: April 18, 2015
												"Changed my headlight fluid, won at life."  TEN'AH'TA'TEN! - BuckfugglyGamingGrid has and continues to be less of a simulation fans racing game for the sake of being more of an arcade racing game. And it does what it does as well if not better than it ever has before in Grid:Autosport. That being said, there is precious little telemetry and car customization and you're given little to no selection for what you'll be driving from one race to the next. And I hate that, I'm a sim-racing fan more than anything else. But I've enjoyed my time in Grid:Autosport for sure. You won't find bespoke graphical / mechanical car customization and selection in Grid, but  you will find lots of solid arcade (think ridge racer) fun.The HD textures (while perhaps one of my favorite optional free DLC offerings from devs of any game) causes what appears to be memory-leak crashes for me but the game is pretty enough in high-res mode for me to be fine without it. As for other visuals, I feel much more like I'm racing in particular cars than I have in other games, hatchbacks typically have some weighty body-roll thats ideal to pre-load going into a corner, and high-strung sports cars feel like their "twitch" is pushing your head around like it owes this game money.I have a few minor problems with the audio, but they're minor and can be completely overlooked unless you really care to hear them. The team radio announcer is a little bland most of the time and a bit uninformative. But I like the idea of having radio-comms to coordinate car condition and situational performance. I'd especially like it if more games swapped out some selectable or even voice activated voice checks for the typical HUD items that tend to litter most racing games.Split screen!!! Thank you! I wish more games tried a little harder to put/keep this in their PC games. I like online gaming, but few things are as satisfying as sitting next to the person you're stomping into a dirty mudhole on the track =)I really like the idea of a youtube button during replays for uploading them to youtube. A wonderful addition to a very pretty and exciting racing experience. And it has been pretty user-friendly (as far as reply controls go) for me to capture some decent footage for machinima things I do in my spare time. But the manually selectable camera angles are limited to the same ones you have access to during the race. So that could have maybe been better. Note* - the automated cinematic camera angles are on a loop, so if you're trying to get footage, it's easy to accidentally repeat the same exact camera angles over multiple takes.I've had zero problems using my cheapo (but heaven-sent) logitech gamepad with analog triggers with no in-game setup at all. Right outta the gate everything worked flawlessly. There's a lot to be said for that.I can't speak for the online play yet. But if I get around to giving it a shot I'll sure update my review accordingly.

content:
Posted: June 20, 2015
												Oh, Codemasters. I came into Autosport expecting nothing and I was still let down. Where do I start?The GOOD:-Nice overall detail-Tons of arcade(ish) fun!The BAD:-Horrible stutter-Floaty physics-Lackluster AIThe REVIEW:Being a longtime fan of Codemasters and their work (pre DiRT 2), I thought I'd give Autosport a try. I'd seen the horrible reviews that Grid 2 had recieved, and was quite disapointed, as I loved Grid 1. Luckily, I caught Autosport on a nice sale, and was quick to ignore the shoddy reviews because I'd caught it at such a steal. Boy, had I wished I listened. Oddly enough, Autosport proved itself fun in the start. While it presented itself as a hardcore racer for hardcore players, I was lied to, as Autosport's racing physics are at best arcadey, and at worst, unbearable. All cars felt like they handled the same- all that was changed was how much power they were capable of producing. Drifting F1 cars should not be possible.On top of that, the video stutter made a playable game unplayable. I've looked into this and have found that I'm not the only one with a stuttering problem. I've tried many fixes, but to no avail. The stutter comes and goes, however. Codemasters, why advertise a game as a hardcore sim when it's not even close?

content:
Posted: July 14, 2015
												I do recommend Grid Autosport with a few hesitations. The graphics are stunning, the car models are great and the game is for the most part very well optimized for most mid to high end systems. The controls are very well executed, they feel smooth and responsive. Unless you're a hardcore racing purest I'd say pass this one up since you have no ability to choose and customize your own vehicle, they're preselected for you based on the sponsor you choose before entering into a season. The other part that bothered me significantly is that when you are leading a race your opponents appear to gain a significant speed boost and they easily overtake you and speed off into the distance as if you're standing still. The only way to midigate this issue is to turn down AI difficult which will actually impact the amount of xp you earn. If buying through steam I highly discourage it since Grid Autosport is not worth $40+ instead pick it up cheap on sites like♥♥♥♥♥♥♥etc then I recommend it as a fun and addicting time sink for a few days until you grow tired of it.

content:
Posted: January 22
												Positives about the game:-So many cars so many track options, catergories like touring open wheel etc. contain a lot of cups opportunities to race on, and to level up both online and offline.-You can race, have a time attack or have checkpoint or eliminator races and also u have demilition derby, and of course drift events (there are dls which can give u something like drag racing too)Racenet challanges are rewarding, if u are in the top 30% of the leaderboards u can get like 45000 ingame money and by participating in one u can even level up.-You can make your own liveries which for me is a massive plus point with sponsors and what not, and the bigger money u have the better sponsors u can put on, which will earn you little amount of money after a multiplayer race.-Level system. in both career and online but especially online I like it, because we can sort of have an idea on who put a lot of effort into the game and good at the game and probably has upgraded veichles and who is someone with like 1 or 2 hours with level 1, in f1 games u have no idea about stuff like that until u go into the session. - Speaking of upgraded veichles, u can upgrade tune and as I said make your own livery for a veichle you own online, the more you race with it the bigger level it gets, for example after level 5 of ur car the brake bias tuning gets avaliable and etc u will get upgrades too which will make the can better as  I said. the biggest upgrade is at level 50-impact ratings: have u noticed in an online race there is a circle with a '!" in it. know what that means? that shows the impact rating of a certain player I like that cause, for example if I see someone with an orange  I will try and be aware as it means that he is likely to crash into me, and white is "super clean"- Difficulty bonus. in every mode u race in pretty much (there are exceptions) u will get difficulty bonus depending on how challenging u choose to race. for example lets say u are on 38% bonus with 3 flashbacks, now if u put them to unlimited it will be lower, by a lot actually, and the whole bonus will be based on how u choose to race, without tc abs or force inside camera and stuff like that - This game rewards you for putting the time into it and experience, as u need to build up your progress to higher levels in order to reach like sponsors or for example garage slots.- Damage model is cool, the car deformates in many ways- The game looks beautiful despite me having a bad equipment- Racenet clubs. u can make a group where ur friends join, and u can put on a custom livery for that club, u dont have to make a livery for every car, u can just quickly choose that livery and go with it (of course if u dont have time or don't want to make a livery)---Open for updates, I can update this review later---Slight negatives (these negatives don't make me hate the game but they can be annoying)AI- They sometimes have no respect to you they push you off track and in some cases crash into you that u get damage, I reccomend u to be careful in every mode with damage on also have like 1-3 flashbacks.- During online if u have a loan veichle, after a race u get ridicolous amounts of damage expences sometimes even after winning, like -8000 d.e. and like 3000 for everything else, its just not cool, and unfortunetaly I can't own every veichle on a low level obviously.- You can only race RavenWest in carrer after u won that season u can't start a new season with it which is a shame- Engineer speaking skills :D u are in practise in career u completed one lap.. now u are up in the 1st sector by 2.3 seconds and even improving in the second one and the engineer....: "You are on avarage pace through sector 1" "...... avarage pace through sector 2" "....avarage pace through sector 3."  I am like you are an avarage engineer lol xD.Also I improve a lap and he says "you lost a bit of pace in that lap lets pick it up" I am like, you blind ::::::: I improved by a second how is that losing pace :D but its more like facepalm than making me angry.- Distance of races online and offline make no difference, so a 12 lap race isnt worth more xp than a 2 lap this one isnt a negative or a postive: handling.. it is generally quite oversteery, especially open wheel but for example cat c touring has no wheelspin even with tc off (well not no but you know). In the past I didnt play the game cause of the handling but now I got used to it and I just deal with it however some endurance veichles are too slidey for me to control without traction which I prefer not Funny things about the game..Commentator: He is saying all sorts of crap, Peter and Dunken are very funny and can say technically stupid things or even when they dont say stupid things they can befunny for me..UUUUUH there was a naaasty crash.. Looks like somebody has lost control. xD and every times it happens they say it with the same sound xD.We got some of the world best drifters out there, xD And a bonus to the end (not a cracker or anything amazing)When I am in career mode selecting a contract the girls starts talking. "Liqui Moly racing team are reqruiting for their team after ur performance... blalbla I am just talking with her and I know what she is exactly saying so I am saying the same line as her when she is supposed to say something new :Dthats all for now this will be updated in the future and will add more things which i noticed and will correct it

content:
Posted: January 1, 2016
												I'll preface this by saying that GRID Autosport is the most "hardcore" racing game that I own, so I'm not a simmer in any sense of the word. That being said, I play with a Track IR 5 and Logitech G25 on the "manual H-patten + clutch" setting on a 34" ultrawide 21:9 display and it's very immersive. It's even possible to heel-toe downshift but sometimes it's a bit tricky since there's no feedback in the pedals. For a game, it's plenty of fun. The car selection is nice and the track selection is pretty good too. Generally I stick to GP circuits and play either open wheel or hot hatch since everything else just feels like a drift fest to me, but maybe I'm doing it wrong or something.Oh, and did I mention that it works on Linux and MacOS X too? I've played a bit on Macbook Pro running El Capitan with a Xbox 360 controller pad and the splitscreen works beautifully with full rumble support and everything. I've also got it running on Linux Mint 17.3 with my Logitech G25 with full force feedback and 900 degree support too.GRID Autosport has something for everyone and has great OS support and controller/wheel support. Get it!

Posted: January 9, 2015
												The very first GRID was (and still is) my favorite arcade racing game. It had customizable difficulty, it had teams and sponsors and your really didn't have to be always first to win a championship (something that NFS Shift 2 had problems with). You could buy your own cars and customize it, so you can see how you progress through the game. And it was fun to play with AI, since it wasn't really good (i.e. cheating) or really ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥. The game just really balanced between arcade and sim and did it really good.Now in Autosport you still have customizable difficulty and same championship system. And it's pretty much it. AI is ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥s that would just crash into you giving no♥♥♥♥♥♥about it whatsoever. You can't buy cars (well, you can in multiplayer, but you'll be given a car anyway when you joing a race). Well, I know that you race with teams and sponsors just provide you cars, but come on, it's not a sim, it's 100% NFS-like arcade, so what's the point of that? You don't really progress, you just comlete one season to unlock another and that's it (it gets really boring very quick. You know, the AI and♥♥♥♥♥♥. Oh, don't forget annoying bugs with resolution and fullscreen mode. So after all I would not recommend Autosport (even on sale). Just grab Race Driver: GRID instead.

content:
Posted: January 8, 2015
												I have played more racing games in over 20 years than I could ever remember. While not the worst racing game I have ever played, It is a long way from the best.  Controls and handling of the cars is not really an issue except to point out that keyboard players should expect to be at a disadvantage.The main problems are the AI, the lack of visibility and the atrocious in car view.The AI is following the same principle that has been used for a few years now. That is they are "heavy" meaning you cannot ram them and expect to see them suffer much. Unfortunately that the same does not apply in reverse, and you will often find yourself losing many positions or even out of a race after being hit by the AI. What make it worse in this game, is the AI generally doesnt see you or care. They will maneuver to overtake on a corner, then  switch into your lane after a few seconds, regardless of where you are. This only applies if your are not drift/sliding around the corner. In this instance you do not exist and that will blindly drive right into you. If by chance you get t-boned and stuck on the front of thier car, then race over. They will not stop to let you off, and will happily push you as far off the track as they can go before hitting a wall or running out of momentum.Visibilty in this game is not something you will notice much as the graphics are quite nice. The problem does become apparent on the more technical circuits though. The issue is you can see a lot of scenery, but very little of the road ahead. In many places the corners are hard to judge as you can not really see a far as you should be able to. It is like an artificial limit on the draw distance. Using the best line feature can help, but if you cannot see much of the road, you wont see much of a line on the road either.Now for the in car view. Its there.... partially. This is absolutly the worst view I have EVER seen in a car game. Not only do they further restrict your view by making you feel like you are to small to look over the dash, but the whole interior of the car is blurred W...T...F!!! Bonus xp for limiting views to incar only, but not worth it.People who played Grid 2 online are in for some good news. You can buy quite a few cars in this game without having to play online for 100hrs. Bad news is there are now something like 50 catagoeries, so you will still get stuck having to use loan cars until your 100hrs is up.

number of helpful: 9 of 14 people (64%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 20, 2015
												Since I saw this game was on sale for $9.99 today I decided I should write a review for people looking at this game. First off, I don't think I have ever seen this game go on a 75% off sale, and for the record I got this game for free. GRID Autosport is probably one of the best racing games on Steam in my opinion. The graphics are great, and it runs well on my average PC.      The career mode is very unique, with you playing as a professional racer who drives across 5 different disciplines: Touring, Endurance, Open Wheel, Tuner, and Street. Touring is basically normal racing on tracks all across the world. Endurance is similar, but the races are a lot longer and require you to manage your tires by deciding when to put wear on them and when to hold back. Open Wheel features open wheel Formula 1 type cars. Tuner events are drift competitions set into heats, and also time attack where racers begin in a staggered moving start and try to set the fastest lap speed rather than the highest position. Finally, Street is racing on tracks made in tight city streets with many sharp turns and short tracks. As you progress through the different disciplines you unlock new Season opportunities and get closer to racing in the GRID, where all disciplines are tested in one competition. For events you do not get to choose the car you drive, which some people don't like but I am fine with. The game is structured into racing seasons where you pick one discipline and a season with preset races and cars. Seasons can also feature a special event where maybe everyone drives the same car or something. When a season ends you can choose a new season from any discipline. The game will save your progress between events so you don't have to play a whole season in one sitting. For each season you can also choose a racing team which gives different challenges or offers which give you bonus XP. For example, improve your lap time, finish above 5th position, lead for a lap. Also, for most racing events each racing team has two drivers. You recieve a teammate with a description and stats (however I do not think the stats really have a great impact on them). During the race you can order your teammate to hold their position, push for a higher one, or just have the default balanced approach. The racing itself is quite good, featuring a penalty system for infractions like going off track and gaining a position by way of that. There is also a replay feature, similar to Forza Horizon where you can rewind the last seconds where you may have crashed or made a mistake. For racers who don't like this feature, you can disable it, and you will receive an XP bonus. There are also other setting you can turn on or off that will increase your XP bonus or lower it. For inexperienced racers I would recommend turning on the driving line which displays the best path to take on the track and where to brake. Now, a lot of the times you can make big gains in races by way of road rage and muscling your way through the competition, I have to admit I do this some of the time. As long as you are on the track you receive no penalty, however if you take enough damage, your steering column, engine, or tires can be damaged. The multiplayer is fun, one thing is that you have to set your Steam download region to UK-London in order to find matches. From what I've heard this will not affect your downloads and it hasn't seemed to affect me so far. Surprisingly the multiplayer features the rewind function, however it will only rewind your car while everyone else keeps racing, so its really only for big mistakes. By racing in multiplayer you earn money and XP and can buy new cars. There is no customization and the cars you buy are just for multiplayer. All In all I think this is a great racing game and a steal for such a big sale. I probably would not buy this game for full price however, but if I didn't have it and saw it on this sale I would definitely grab it! Great graphics, good career mode, good multiplayer, nice music.NOTE: This game like most racing games is best with a CONTROLLER.

content:
Posted: July 3, 2014
												GRID autosport... what can really be said about this game? Lots, but long story short this game rewards driving skill.You have to hold the line, work the throttle, and have the patience to wait for the moment to pass. The bs drifting advantage is over. Only in select situations does drifting help. So far as I can describe through play, this game by design cuts down greatly on the demolition derby that was GRID 2. The A.I. is definitely challenging, but that may just be since the driving dynamics are different from other GRID titles so passing wouldn't be as familiar.The sound of the game has some notable improvements from G2. There are cockpit rattles in various cars. The engine sounds are satisfying, tires, exhust notes, radio chatter...blah blah. It sounds better.One aspect of the game I am enjoying a lot more are the RaceNet challenges. Again the driving dynamics make this particular game mode great, they take work to complete with platinum medals.Should you pick this game up? Depends if you're an arcade racer or not.

If nothing else, the time trials aren't affected and I like trying to beat my own times round a track. Would I recommend it? -  on sale, perhaps. It hasn't made me want to look out for the next installment, that's for sure.

number of helpful: 12 of 20 people (60%) found this review helpful2 people found this review funny
content:
Posted: January 2, 2016
  Short: I rate this game a  6/10 as of January 2016 .Pros: Supports a lot of racing wheelsVery playable with a controller or keyboard Singleplayer with a lot of racesMultiplayer with Clans ( Racing teams ), custom lobbies Some car customizationCons:  Multiplayer is dead Support systems are perfect ( Can't improve certain things by using a wheel )  A lot of 500-2000h people that own all upgrades on cars and will always finish top places People with the most points always start first.  DLCs ( Yes DLCs are always a Con for me. ) Boring Singleplayer ( Stopped after the second season because it's basically: Choose a team, race , race, Choose a better team, race, race ) Read the full review for my salt.  Long: I owned Grid 2 before, been playing it with keyboard and controller, very arcady indeed.Preordered Grid Autosport when it got announced, played it a couple of hours on release, more of a sim-arcade game than just arcade ( Can't drift around corners anymore and be faster than others ). Now this doesn't have to be bad actually I liked it at first but I never really got into the game during that time, rather played different genres. I played it now and then and every time I had the same feeling and ended up playing other stuff again because of the following reasons:Grid Autosports has upgrades that you can install into your vehicle to boost its performance (Better acceleration for example), for these you need to have a certain level on your car (which you have to buy with ingame cash if you want to level up the car ). Basically this means if you play the game a lot you get better cars ( besides owning cars in the first place ).Again this is something most online games have, reward players that play the game.One problem with this is that the game is basically unplayable and very very very frustrating in multiplayer as a "beginner" as you can't theoretically drive faster than people that have upgraded cars, which means you can't, again theoretically (before you argue you can still do that by skill... ), do better than people with upgraded cars.As you get XP and Cash mainly based on your placement and the amount of players this means you're going to have hard times leveling up and buying new cars. (Cash problem can easily be solved by doing RaceNet-Challenges ).This problem also gets supported by the fact that the Multiplayer is pretty much dead ( EU-Experience ). You may get a full touring lobby on Sundays but then again you will have to race mostly high level players ( Talking about people with somewhere between 700-2000h in this game ).The "reward people that play the game " - system can also be seen at the start of a race: The guy with the most points starts first ( If you just sit in a lobby for long enough and play a lot you will always start on pole ). If you're lucky enough to find a full lobby with some low rank players you will have to start at the very back and probably get rammed out of the first turn. Now you could still have more driving skill than some high skill players, maybe you're thinking because you own a wheel you get advantages as you do in other games but I'm sorry to tell you that you're wrong.As I said earlier this game is somewhere between Arcade and Simulator, therefor it's easily playable with a controller or keyboard, multiplayer doesn't have any specific rules on game supports ( ABS , Shiftmode , TC , stability control, ... ) you can enable what ever you want. Enabling those also doesn't really give you a disadvantage ( you get less xp but that's not really noticible ), having TC enabled for example just saves you from accelerating too quickly but if you choose to fully accelerate you still accelerate perfectly. I am personally using a racing wheel ( T300RS ) and I feel like this is sadly the case for most settings. Manual shifting / sequential is worthless, just more work for your brain and automatic shifts perfectly anyways.Basically this means you can play this game just as well on a controller as you could on a racing wheel. Good if you own a controller - bad if you own a 300€ or more racing wheel and get no advantages.Conclusion:As reviews should tell people who are interested in buying this game if it's worth it or not I'm going to say: Probably not.If you're looking for an arcade game, don't care if you finish last most games and not play with a lot of players ( yes there are private lobbies ... sometimes ... if you're lucky ... so basically never (  let's be real )  ) or if you just want to play this game in singleplayer, go ahead and pick it up.If you actually want a racing sim, play a game where you feel like it's good to own a wheel and not get dusted by people who may be worse drivers than you but still win because they played the game a lot then don't buy this game.Personally I never expected this to be a racing sim but rarely finding lobbies and having to play people who play this game all day is annoying. Also I feel like you should be able to drive better if you own a wheel, support systems shouldn't do everything perfect so there's something to improve by using a wheel.

Posted: January 29, 2015
												I don't know why am I even writing this review but I really want to. Have all grid titles including Grid and Grid 2 in my Steam Library but never touched them. Bought Grid AutoSport + Season Pass just because I had money to waste (and maybe to show off to others that I buy expensive games) and I think it is one of the beautiful mistakes I've made in my life. I was always an avid follower of F1 and thats why I love racing games. Played almost all newer NFS titles where you kind of get a supercar and blast through all the racer and get 1st , 2nd or 3rd place almost every time. Played this game and I got a reality check about what actual racing is. I selected the "Easy" AI Mode but after 4 races (15th Place , 14th Place , 9th place and 16th place *I ain't joking*) . I had to set the AI to "Very Easy" mode. Even after that , I've managed to get the podium 2 times ONLY (2nd and 3rd) even after playing almost 30+ races. If you think you've mastered racing games just because you can play NFS , play this game. I'm sure you'll love it. Although I understand that this game is frustrating at times just because the amount of complexity you'll have to go through e.g. In Online mode car damage will affect your car's performance and trust me when I say that I wanted to threw away my laptop just because I couldn't come 1st in a race just because my car's handling failed after getting hit by another car. I've only played like 2-3 games online so I dont know much about that but I'm really enjoying the Single Player mode.As of now , I've only tried "Touring" and "Endurance" disciplines but I plan to try other ones soon enough. And about the optimization part , I'm running this game maxed out in Intel HD 5200 and haven't encountered a visual glitch till now. Also , the visuals are really top notch. Somethimes when playing , I felt like I was racing in a real world (but I'm too much dreamy so you can ignore that part :'D ) This game also has a good set of cars and racing tracks ..... Well , to finish , I know I spoke too much in my review but if you can , buy this game. You'll have countless hours of fun like I'm having .... Thank You again for reading this length pile of garbage.  P.S. I never played Asseto Corsa and don't plan to. So , please don't tell me about how Asseto Corsa is better than Grid : Autosport even if it is !! Thank You :)

content:
Posted: March 8, 2015
												This is a racing game made for racers. People who genuinely love motorsports. People who have actually DONE motorsports before. People who know what racing really is like in real life. This review is written having only played the game with a G27 racing wheel and only manual sear shifting with all HUD's disabled for the most racing like experience. I've done my fair share of track days and i can tell you, think is the most realistic car racing game i have played. There's plenty of people complaining the game feels too slow, the cars don't grip in corners blah blah. Well guess what, those people have never driven on a track in their life. When on a racing track, unless you're in a ultra fast ferarri or koensigg or something, guess what, you feel SLOW. That's how it is. Your car is slow. People are so used to **** car sims that put so much emphasis on feeling like you're flying along or arcade racing games that let you go around corners at 400kph that they have no idea what it's actually like to race a car. So more on the good parts. The handling of the cars: Fantastic. Cars handle how they should. FWD understeers coming too hot into a corner, or if you put power down coming into a corner and you can even get the♥♥♥♥♥out with lift off oversteer when driving really agressive. All of that is true in a FWD cars handling characteristics and they are all spot on in the game. RWD cars oversteer if you power on too much mid corner, or over a crest. You can really feel the suspension working. Coming super hot down a hill into a banked corner? Your suspension will start to wallow like a real car trying to deal with sideways g-forces, and if not careful in a RWD car, will cause oversteer. Graphics: AMAZING. Holy **** The attention to detail is amazing. From the different exhaust outputs of the cars (some will be obviously running rich, some not, etc) to the in car view of the dash being out of focus (because you're looking at the track, not the car) but obviously having some type of MOTEC carbon fiber HUD in place of the standard cars one, to the general cars decals and body panels. The world around looks so gorgeous, beautiful lighting, amazing scenery, and really perfect track textures. Racing modes: The only thing the game is missing in terms of racing modes is drag racing and rally. Which is not a downside to me. Drag is always a short lived interest in racing games and rally is much a massive part of racing it really does require its own game. One massive thing to note is the different racing game modes all have different racing styles. Touring cars are mega aggressive, open wheelers really require you to be careful with damage on and time attack is like how time attack is with sporadic cars you have to deal with. Sounds: I love the fact you can hear the tyres gripping, the straight cut gears int he gear box and the pop from fuel injectors still being on when your changing gears, because screw fuel efficiency. Its the little things: To me what really makes this game great is the little things. Like picking a perfect line through a series of corners then coming out and realising you just shaved a second or 2 off your lap time. The spectators not being 2d, the clouds and lighting are so gorgeous and the cars look amazing. Even the simple and elegant UI still keeping perfect functionality. The fact you log in, and the game says with voice "Welcome back (name here), there's some new events in the touring car championship, go check them out!". You can really tell Codemasters have really put their heart and soul into this game. Summary: If you're a grown adult that loves racing, and has done it before, this is the game for you. If your some pimply teenager that thinks GTA and Need for Speed are racing simulators, this isn't for you.

												Engine-wise, this is the most optimized game I've played in the last 10 years. Everything is super light and responsive with gorgeous graphics on mid-range PCs, and with acceptable graphics on low-end PCs.There is not enough diversity in cars, despite the many categories (even F1-like cars), but there are a lot of different tracks to drive on.Music is annoying and generic, and does bad job at complementing such a beautiful game.Car damage is realistic and affects driving in a major way - this is not the game to ram your opponents off the track.For me personally, in the age of games that struggle on quad core CPUs and 2+ Gb GPUs to deliver mid-res textures and questionable lighting, the biggest advantage of GRID Autosport is how amazingly beautiful and lightweight its graphics engine is. Definitely restores my faith in developers.I have not noticed any bugs so far, and I've played it way more than my profile shows, outside of Steam.Career is a bit boring, or at least it was to me. Driving aside, a race pilot's career is not very interesting to begin with. But it does provide an extra bit of addrenaline to the regular racing experience.

content:
Posted: April 26, 2016
												9/10 Pretty fun racing game! I expected it to be more realistic when it comes to car handling, but it is in fact quite arcady and a bit loose. I am playing with a Xbox controller and the controls are not super responsive and direct when it comes to the steering with the L joystick, but it's acceptable. You might need to get used to it a bit in the beginning, after that it's fine.The game has a ton of cups and challenges to keep you busy for many many hours (enough content). Even with the arcady feel it is actually quite chalenging to drive against the AI! So far as I have played the amount of different tracks is quite low, I played for 7 hours and only driven half a dozen different tracks (and reversed), also the amount of different cars and classes is quite low.One really noticable quality gap in the game is the cockpit view. It is really low detailed in most/all cars and they made the cockpit on the lower part of your screen blurry to camouflage it. It is extra noticable, because basically everything else in the game is pretty solid and good quality.As for realism I think this game falls far below the racing sims on the market. Even Gran Turismo feels more real (direct/responsive) when it comes to car handling, but the AI in GRID is way more fun to race against and the races are more custimizable then in Gran Turismo. I also don't think that this game tries or was intended to be a realistic racing sim, but an enjoyable not over complicated racing experience. And that it does quite well.Overall I think this is a pretty solid and fun racing game and worthy to pick up during a sale.

number of helpful: 5 of 7 people (71%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: April 12, 2015
												Yet another beloved Codemasters game saga. "Race Driver" games have been out there since early 2000, and although the name of the latest games has changed gradually to "GRID", the focus of the saga keeps exactly the same as in its origins nearly 15 years ago. I have got the 2002 "Pro Race Driver" and from it I could get a well-determined scheme of what the saga is meant to be like. First of all, the title says it all: Pro Race Driver. Yup, you are a race driver going from the bottom to the top of Motorsport, always on tarmac races. What we get then is a large variety of cars and circuits to make the ladder along the career changing and entertaining. Back in 2007, with "Race Driver GRID" being released (and in my all honest opinion, one of the best games I've ever played), the saga was brought back. Later in 2012, the game library grew with GRID 2 to finally lose the name "Race Driver" and pretend like it was a brand new saga. Now, after the release in 2014 of GRID Autosport, some say this may be the end of the GRID saga. As exposed before GRID is actually part of the Race Driver saga, so maybe the next tarmac-racing game by Codemasters may not be called GRID but will still be part of the RD line. No developer is stupid enough to let down one of their most successful sagas ever while it still sells well.After some context introduction, it's time for the actual review:At first sight this brand new game might look like a GRID 2 DLC. Visuals are almost identical to it, and as in the store page what you see from the game are screenshots, you feel convinced of your opinion. GRID Autosport shares a lot of visual features with GRID 2 indeed. But the game is directioned in a completely different way. First up, GRID 2 was mostly about street races with road cars. GRID Autosport is undeniably focused on circuit races. This may not look like a big difference, but it actually makes the game feel 100% renewed.I think I share the opinion that having to unlock the 75% of the cars in game sucks. Or that to race certain competitions you have to pass through the ♥♥♥♥♥est races in the ♥♥♥♥♥est circuits with the ♥♥♥♥♥est cars. At GRID Autosport they have broken up with that annoying tradition and you are completely free to start your career mode in whatever competition category you prefer. For example, if you hate street races you can always kick off the Endurance season if you fancy. A great kudos to Codies for that. Plus if you want to take up a quick race at any game mode you can race with any car in game. They are all available from moment you click the "Play" button on Steam for the first time.Another huge improvement in which most of the upgrades of this game are based is the graphics engine. 4K compatible and stable at 60FPS or more, which basically means that the game is ridiculously well built. If you don't own a top GPU which supports these new performance features, you still get a good bit with high FPS and affordable higher settings. GRID 2 was annoyingly bad in that way, with massive FPS drops and nonsense low FPS on any setting... Graphics are clear and textures are the summit of all Codemasters titles. Grass, tyres, tarmac trees are brilliant. Cars keep the trend of "so-so" quality though. Modelling is not extremelly accurate, but still decent.Physics were a huge problem in GRID 2. The 2007 GRID was much better in that field, and now these realistic physics are back. If you spin off the track and insane speeds and get onto the gravel, you are likely to end up rolling. Track bumps fit properly-made suspension works. If you go real quick on a staright and there's a steep lift on the track, you may take off the tarmac shortly. If you go full YOLO out of a turn and drive over the curb you can be sure to be going to lose control of the car. Just some remarkable examples of how well detaled this game is.Handling confirms that the latest addition to the saga is still an arcade. It would be better to say it is a mixture between a sim and an arcade. Handling is not at all precise. At any turn you'll have to make slight drifts to get hold of the car because if you just lock the pad axle on a single position the car is going to oversteer as if it had been kicked from the tail by Superman. This is common through all the previous games. If you get the purpose of this handling's characterictics you'll believe you're a pro racer saving the driving line with corrections. If not, you'll leave the game apart thinking it is unplayable. It's all a question of practice though.Codemasters warned that AI is so dirty in this game. They somehow managed to program an AI that is not dumb at all but behaves as any real online racer. It has personality... Plus the amazingly-superbly-awesome new feature of radio interaction with your trackside engineer. By pushing some buttons you can ask him for any information about race status and your car's damages and tyre wear. Also, you can tell your team mate to be more aggressive or to defeat his position. Real cool stuff.Sound field. I do think that at Codemasters they copy-paste the car sound files from one game to another. It is true that GRID Autosport has a wider range of hi-fi sounds like wind, crowd cheering and more accurate gravel and grass sounds when you spin off the track. Engines just sound the same, just a ridiculous high-pitched monotone sound. Of course it has some remarkable distinctions for some cars. Some Endurance cars sound just too badass, but the sound itself looks too simplistic.Cockpit camera was painfully missing in GRID 2 and now it is back. Interestingly there are two on board cams available, one nearer from the windshield than the other, more driver-eye like. At first sight you'll see a major difference from any other on board cam from any other game. I don't know if it is made on purpose to bring one of the best graphics effects ever on a racing game or a merely ridiculous attempt to hide bad work on the cockpits. The thing is that the interior of the cars are blurry and anything from behind the winshield is nitide. In my opinion it looks absolutely mega, but that's up to everyone's opinion.So does GRID Autosport stick to the scheme of the rest of the "Race Driver" games? Indeed. Career mode keeps the essence of being focused on you as a driver exactly as the 2002 game did. So many circuits with their variants and an impressive range of cars. It never gets boring.8/10
