content:
Posted: April 21, 2015
												Great racing game. Lots of cars, tracks and disciplines. The cars handle very well; you have to learn how to drive them properly around corners and the game helps with the learning through visual assists.Touring cars remind me of Toca 2.The AI really fights for every inch of tarmac which adds a lot to the adrenaline and competitive atmosphere. I love that and I think I felt it most at "medium" difficulty.I noticed many times the AI cars follow the racing line religiously(mostly while cornering) and in some cases they'll ram you off the track because of it, but that usually happens when driving kamikaze style, not like a racer would. You'll learn to be aware of other cars.The game doesn't have a storyline to help drive progression like in Grid 1. Instead you feel more like a professional driver fighting to climb up the ranks. You can play only one discipline if you want to.It's nice you can choose to stick with a team for a few seasons before moving to another one.The commentators before the race are a nice touch :)

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 10, 2015
												MY BIGGEST IN DEPTH REVIEW EVER! I previously reviewed Grid 2 and I will start with a familiar sentence those who read my grid 2 review will know. Codemasters, my dear old friend. I have been a loyal supporter since Colin Mcrae Rally 2.0, stretching from V8 Supercars 1, 2 (Xbox) to TOCA Race Driver 3 and even the Formula One games (My fave) Its only fair I review GRID: Autosport. In a nutshell, its an improvement over GRID 2. OK LETS GET INTO IT! Again I shall start with the cons.-ConsFirst the AI. Easy to catch, bloomin hard to keep them behind you. It seems there is a rubberbanding effect here where the cars behind get a performance boost when you pass, especially the top drivers (looking at you Westley). Rubberbanding provides a challenge to the player but it kinda makes it frustrating all your effort catching (even on hard difficaulty) suddenly goes to mud because the AI suddenly go faster. And on the subject of AI they REALLY get aggressive out there. For example in Open Wheel (more about classes in the pros!) It is supposed to be NON CONTACT. But they do not leave space, and I found myself getting spun when they slam into me in the breaking zones like im not even there or they re-pass on the inside and clip my rear wheels with their wing. THis is a long paragraph for a single con. -Damage. This is a pro and con. Its more about the AI damage. They don't seem to have any issues with damage. I went the wrong way, smashed head on into an AI at over 200kph and sent him flipping through the air. When his car righted again he just continued although he did have a lose wing and cosmetic damage... he finished 5th... SO work there needs to be done.-Multiplayer. Again... I cannot for the life of me find a public match. Inviting my only other friend who plays the game is ok, but sometimes hes not always avaliable to play. This needs to be fixed. It happened on GRID 2 as well.OK CONS ASIDE!! Lets get into the really great pros.-Classes. The best thing about this game. Different choice of cars. Its obvious not every one likes the same race series. I hate Nascar, I love Formula One. It is great to see you can choose 5 different choices, from Drift to Open Wheel to Touring etc. It is the best thing about this game, and it brings me back to my V8 Supercars years.-Damage. Much improved damage on this game, parts come off, or cause your car to pull to the left/right, even lose a wheel, and manage to keep on racing (Put this in F1 2015 pls? k thx) although some pit stops would be nice/-Career. A big con. The intro introduces you to the mechanics of the game with a 2 lap intro race which is good to get up to speed and you can select which class to start/end with maybe open wheel, or drift any category you want. -ONBOARD CAMERAS. YES. DRIVING CAMERAS. T-CAMS. ITS WHAT WE DREAMED OF. AND WE GOT.-Custom races. This is a great feature. Any class, any track, any team. Up to 3 events each with custom lap amounts, practice and qualifying and setups!!! Whats best is the first race can start from qualifying spot, but the second race can start from reversed 1st race position (finish 1st, start last, finish 2nd, start second to last.) Its great!!!-Graphics. Only one word Amazing!Overall a great game for any racer out there. Easy to use with my g27 wheel. HIGHLY RECOMMEND~~!!!

content:
Posted: December 26, 2016
												Just like Cities:Skylines seemed to be closer to a next-generation version of SimCity 4 was than Sim City 5, so does Grid Autosport seem to be the heir to the throne that was last occupied by DiRT: Showdown (D:S).It is a great half-way point between super in-depth racers from the PS2-era of GT2 and GT3 and the arcadey racers.  It has depth in what it refines.Does it let you race bajillions of vehicles?  No, just from playing the "street" vein of the game I can tell that only a small handful (under 10) are available.  But because each of those dozen or so vehicles vary so much in their physics, each vein yields new challenges to personal skills that might've plateaued if just left to rot in one specific type.But it does add some great advancements: "rivals" which seem like the next non-team guy in points above or below you is one of them.  Another is the flashback where you get -- by default -- five times during one race to rewind the action so that spin-out or incorrect judgement of the entry speed on a corner doesn't happen.Yup, car collection is still there but not a focus.

number of helpful: 3 of 4 people (75%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 26, 2015
												I'm a long-time fan of the Race Driver series and played every single one of them.The classic Race Driver games (especially RD2 and RD3) were absolutely superb games. Then came the first GRID and just added to it. It was a great game with decent cars, decent simcade handling, good racetracks (especially those Japan Docks). GRID 2 was a disaster. To anyone who knows Codemasters and the Race Driver franchise it's obvious that they just lost track of their heritage on this one. It didn't have a monetary system. The handling was changed to something that can only be described as super-arcade. The sponsor system was terrible too - supremely dumbed-down. And the AI was irritating. Generally just a bad bad Codemasters racing game.I told myself I'd never pre-order again, then came GRID Autosport.Which I didn't pre-order and bought on sale.BUTIt's a good game. Not GRID 1 good, but it's eons ahead of GRID 2. The single player mode isn't quite where GRID 1 had gotten it so right, with a lack of a monetary system and no ownership of cars. The music is about as bland as it gets too. The multiplayer, however, is where the game really proves itself. Earn money, earn xp and build your garage. Track your stats on RaceNet. Create or join racing clubs. Race vs friends, strangers or just AI. It really has a nice balance to it. There are community challenges to keep you interested and leaderboards to work against. Generally GRID Autosport is well rounded with handling only marginally below that of GRID 1.GRID Autosport proves that Codemasters have not lost their touch with racing games.

												Perfect mix between simulation and arcade racing. Beautiful graphics, really low loading times and endless settings can be changed if wanted. You can play this game just with the standard settings from the cars or fine tune them yourselves.I do recommend a steering wheel with pedals or at least a controller. I'm saving up for a Fanatec wheel with pedals and now  racing with a Xbox 360 controller. I also tried lot of other racing games like Project Cars (to much of a sim for me), Test Drive Unlimited 2 (too big of an open world for me), Need for speed series (too arcade for my taste), but since I started playing GRID2 I was hooked. Thankfully that nice balance between Sim and Arcade is still there in GRID Autosport. If you think you're not an arcade racer, but also not somebody who want's to play it too hardcore like a Sim, this is the perfect game

number of helpful: 3 of 4 people (75%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 23, 2015
												There's a problem with the Steam ratings system, and that's that you have a binary "YES" or "NO" as to if you'd recommend a game.  I need a third category for GRID Autosport, a wavy hand, non-committal noise, a sort of shrug.I'm a big fan of racing games in general and have been buying Codemasters racers since TOCA Race Driver 2.  I’ve bought GRID and GRID 2 and enjoyed them both, I actually wrote a positive review of GRID2 on Steam.  But GRID Autosport is...*does hand rocking back and forward motion*.So what's wrong?  The biggest fault in this game is the AI.  It’s bad, not terrible, just pretty stupid.  AI cars really want to hit that racing line.  Quite often you'll find them piling up at the first corner as they all try to take the same line through.  A savvy player can avoid the melee and gain quite a few places straight away.  More annoying is when you're taking a corner and the AI clips your back end sending you spinning out.  Of course, this happens in real world racing but it feels all to frequent in GRID Autosport making the AI feel cheap and frustrating.  It made me wonder if the flashback game mechanic was implemented because they couldn’t be bothered to fix the AI and decided that the player could just rewind and take evasive action should they get rear ended and end up in a wall!  But because the AI behaves so badly you don't really care about smashing them up to get ahead.  This can turn races into something of a demolition derby and ruins the immersion somewhat.  Far better was the system in Need For Speed: Shift which rewarded you for a more passive (or aggressive) racing style, that way you could at least play a persona.  Also the less said about the total waste of an AI race partner the better.  There's also nothing new here.  If you've played the last two outings you've seen most of what this game has to offer.  I might be mistaken but I think all the tracks are recycled and they've ditched the point-to-point racing that was so much fun in GRID2 (though you can get it back as DLC, it’s not part of the main career mode).  Drag racing could have been new and fun (reminiscent of the ace drag racing from Need For Speed Underground) but again, that comes as a DLC and isn't part of the main career. So what's right?  Graphically it’s quite the looker.  The cars are detailed (and there are quite a few of them), the tracks feel alive and interesting (racing through the construction site that is Dubai is a particular highlight).  The car handling seems to have been refined from the previous outing and the multi-disciplined approach means you really have to focus on how you drive as you, for example, switch between the easy to drive, stable at speed Touring Cars and the fast but skittish GT Race Cars.  Moreover the number of disciplines keeps things varied and interesting.  You'll be bumper to bumper racing in Touring Cars, managing your tyre wear in Endurance, getting sideways in Drift.  That you don't need to be the best in a particular discipline to progress is neat too (mid table finishes still earn XP, albeit slower than finishing top).There's enough in this game to keep me coming back (and I will do until I finish it because I'm compulsive like that) so because Steam only gives me a binary choice I'll give a thumbs up.  But this is likely the last GRID game I pick up.  The racing marketplace is about to get a whole lot more competitive with the exciting Project CARS on the horizon, and I reckon the GRID series, without an overhaul, will end up languishing in mid-pack.

content:
Posted: February 2, 2015
												First off, this is a great game, I would definetly buy it if I were you.The physics model is a perfect balance of arcade and simulation, much better than GRID 2, which was like driving on soap. That makes this game very fun and playable with w,a,s,d and arrow keys.The car selection is huge, you get everything in between hot hatches and formula 1. Touring cars, muscle cars, hypercars, you name it, they have it.The graphics are great, obviously not the best in the world right now, but still insane.The frame rate is very constant, I dont have the best PC ever, only 6GB of ram and a core i5, but it still runs at 40-50fps pretty much no matter what I'm doing. I cant say the same for games like need for speed.The track selection is immense, granted, some of the tracks are just variations of the same track, but it's still difficult to run out of places to race.Multiplayer is great as well, impact ratings keep all of the jerks out of the race and let everyone have fun without being killed by some idiot driving on the track backwards.However, there are some flaws. For example, when GRID autosport says you are going to drive formula A, or formula 1, it gives you an indycar instead. Indycar and F1 are NOT the same thing.Another flaw has to be the DLC, which has been a problem for all of the GRID games. There is so much of it, and none of it is free. You want an extra car? Better have $5 lying around. This also effects multiplayer, half of the time the party leader is using DLC that you probably dont have, and there is usually no other party to join.The cokcpit wiew is super blurry as well, not a big problem, but still something I want to point out.My final thoughts? Still an excellent game. DO NOT listen to the people who say you are better off with GRID 2, ive played the game before, trust me, you want this one. Although I do recommend buying it on sale, the GRID series tends to be on sale more than most racing games on steam, so I was able to get it for 10 bucks. Also, if you are looking for a racing sim, go buy asseto corsa, do not buy GRID.

number of helpful: 3 of 4 people (75%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: August 19, 2016
The best racing game on GNU/Linux... as of today.Until the day DiRT Rally comes out... if SteamDB is not wrong.So, after fans complained that GRID 2 was too arcadey, left cockpit view out of the base game and missed the real race tracks, GRID Autosport brings back what the sequel was missing, and rewrites the handling of the game so it stick closer to that simcade balance from GRID 1.In short, the game can be formulated as "GRID 1's spirit" + "GRID 2's technology and assets".The game may have its flaws, but it's ultimately a good experience filled with variety. I should also mention that it has split-screen multiplayer, a rarity on PC games (and even current console games).What differences this version from Windows' is that it performs worse graphically, so if the game runs flawlessly on Windows, chances are you may experience some frame drops (unless your computer is that powerful). As a reference, playing on Nvidia has the same performance as playing on Windows + AMD card. BUT, considering how GNU/Linux works, if the game freezes, it won't affect anywhere else on the computer, where Windows could freeze itself entirely.______________________________________________Oh, one last thing: if your country uses commas to represent decimals (0,3333..3 as in "one third"), use this command on launch:	LANG=C %command%Otherwise the game may not even launch!

content:
Posted: May 22, 2016
												(Singleplayer only)A really fantastic looking arcade racer that fills my racing fix when I just want to put in a few races. I normally can't put in more than two or three hours at a time though. It can't hook me in to play longer. I just end up getting bored. The game is now almost two years old now and it's still $40. It's not worth $40. I got it in a Codemasters bundle I think. Got this and a few other titles for $15 (great deal!). I really enjoy the Touring, Open Wheel, and Street seasons, but I'm not a fan of this game's Endurance (AI don't suffer from wear) mode and I hate Tuner.With a decent gaming desktop, I can run many of the settings on ultra, but have to lower some settings to keep the frame rate from dropping at high-intensity moments (especially when drifting with tire smoke). Ravenwest are my sworn enemies. When I get there, I will only run one season with them to get the achievement. They can screw off after that.Overall, it looks great, the AI are decent (but not perfect), and can fill that racing fix for about two hours at a time. Get it on sale. 50% off or greater.Edit: accidentally said Tuner twice. Changed to Touring

content:
Posted: July 1, 2015
												I have to admit that there is fun to be found here, but the game is still floaty as hell.  I honestly don't know what Codemasters is attempting to do.  With the first game, I thought they were going for the Forza/Gran Turismo market, which... they didn't succeed at.  With Grid 2, I have NO IDEA what the hell they were thinking.  So that brings us to Grid Autosport, which still doesn't seem to go for that sim feel, although it's much closer than Grid 2 ever was.  So if that's not the goal, this doesn't really feel like an arcade racer, either.  It just feels like a very pretty, but ultimately not-great racing game.  The entire series has an identity crisis, as if it doesn't know whether to be a sim or an arcade game, and that just leaves it teetering in the middle where nobody is going to be satisfied.

content:
Posted: August 24, 2015
												Nope!  This game is offensively too broken to justify spending even $5 on if you intend to be chasing any sort of game progression or steam achievements. Sure, the racenet site is pretty terrible, does a poor job of barely handling the minimal functionality required to support the features for which it is needed.  Sure, the AI and other humans are often out of sync between gamers in the same multiplayer game.  Sure, you will usually find multiplayer lobby empty unless you switch your Steam download location to somewhere in the EU.  That's all relatively trivial next to the known save game corruption bug that's wiped out my progress twice within 6 months.Twice now, the game has rendered my save data corrupt.  Both times, this was after normal quitting of the game through the exit option in the menu.  This is apparently not uncommon, and has happened with a number of others.  None of the online racenet progress is actually stored online in any way that can be recovered.  Nor, for some reason, is the Steam cloud being leveraged to recover one's lost progress. Some gamers have recommended  disabling Steam Cloud support for the game, citing repeated failures by codemasters to handle it properly in other games.  Further, it's been recommended that users go through the hassle of digging into their C:\Program Files(x86)\Steam\Userdata\<steamuserid>\255220 to save backups regularly.After the first time it happened to me, I disabled Steam cloud support, and made a copy of the 255220 userdata folder on occasion.  I eventually got comfortable and a bit lazy, and had not backed up for some time, at which point it occurred again.Hundreds of online races, purchases, upgrades, and funds lost.  Hundreds of career races and progress lost.  No way to complete the missing achievements without first redoing all the lost effort to get back to where you were before your save game data was corrupted.I honestly think this game could be good if the publisher could be bothered to fix the handful of bugs plaguing it.   It appears the developer has no intention of fixing any bugs in the game at this point.  Though one could argue hours of fun racing did occur, resetting users' progress when they are halfway through the achievements... repeatedly... is absolutely not an acceptable situation.Most active developers update their games with bugfixes as the need arises.  Codemasters apparently feels this game is complete, bugs and all, and is focused on putting their efforts into releasing new paid-for content instead of fixing the glitches.I could say save yourself the money, but honestly, save yourself the wasted time chasing achievements, and save yourself the frustration and anger at a developer who took your money and doesn't seem to care that the game is broken.Trivial lackings in addition to the above* no choice of tires* no choice of weather* no choice of road surface (all tarmac)* limited online garage slots prevent owning all vehicles

content:
Posted: September 23, 2014
												Despite there are wildly different opinions on this game, I find Grid Autosport to be a fairly enjoyable game with it's accessible yet fun driving physics, great content and a throwback to Grid 1 or even TOCA series that should set the foundation for the next Grid game. Grid Autosport also brings back the rather enjoyable multidisciplinary racing aspect of Grid 1 and TOCA series where the game features cars from exotic hyper cars, Australian V8 Supercars, Formula 3 Open Wheel, GT3s, drift machines and so on. The career is serviceable as the whole team management aspect in Grid 1 was axed so you are very much a driver for hire now which is disappointing to me. Personally, I would still recommend Custom Cup (or commonly known as Quick Race in most racing games) where you can choose to race with any car and on any tracks to your liking, considering all the cars and tracks are unlocked once you boot up the game. There are some issues with the game such as the poorly implemented multiplayer mode, AI that can be too aggressive at times and a lot of recycled content that some might find it to be a bit lazy. Still, with a revamped and improved driving physics, driving on tracks such as the licensed race track, Red Bull Ring in Grid Autosport is certainly more enjoyable than Grid 2.I do recommend Grid Autosport to you if you enjoyed Grid 1 or TOCA series but was disappointed with Grid 2's direction. Or you are racing game fan who is looking for a fun, accessible simcade with tonnes of content. If you stumbled upon this review on a sale, I do recommend you to pick up this game along with the Season Pass as there are some really enjoyable content in the Season Pass.

												GRID Autosport, a petrolhead must have. The game is really long and entertaining. number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 8, 2015
												GRID Autosport is a very good game yet there's something missing from it. It could be because we've seen it all before, as there's nothing majorly brand new to the series in this game, however it does feel more like the original GRID than GRID 2. Which is a good thing for the original GRID's fans. A lot of tracks are repeated from GRID 1 & 2, but that's not a bad thing as most of these are the 'good' tracks including the made up San Francisco and Chicago one's. There's a nice selection of cars in game which beats its predecessors, I think, by quite a bit. A nice bit of variety, but no way near the amount of vehicles that you'd get in Forza or Gran Turismo. Then again there isn't really any need for that many. The handling of the cars is more similar to the original GRID with that essence of both arcade and simulation (GRID 2's was arcade) however it does lean more on the simulation side a bit more this time. This game was made in about a year as it came out due to complaints from the original GRID's fans. Oh it also has in- car cam in it now, more about that below in the Pro's & Con's bit:Pro's:Nice variety of cars/ disciplines- Touring Cars- Street Racers- Open Wheel & more. Graphics- As always, great graphics from Codemasters. Sharp and shiny. Lot's of tracks- Whether they be made up or real life, you will find a track that you like.Online- Is (I think) better than the Career mode. You can look up or set up custom sessions. But if you can't be bothered looking through things let it plough you face first in to a mixture of races! You can also be in clubs and change car skins/ livery's whatever you want to call it. Menu- I like the menu'sHandling- I think it's pretty damn good, no more drifting in every single car like in GRID 2.Con's:Music- Lack's music. GRID 1 & 2 had more variety and had a big part in the games.In- car cam- It's there, it's just blurry. There's also a dashboard cam. I'm not too bothered about it, I just don't get why they would have a good one in GRID 1 and not its sequels.Repeat tracks- Only bad for people who have played the other GRID's and want something new. AI- This one was difficult, they're nice and aggressive, but you can't help but feel they have the upper- hand some of the time. It's difficult to spin them out, but it's easy for them to do it to you.Career- A bit bland the further you go in to it, plus having a teamate makes you not want to have one. Also you can't make your own livery's.

In Grid Autosport I feel like a driver racing for my team and trying to get the attention of better teams so I can further my career. It makes winning more satisfying and battling it out against rivals even more intense. Get it while it's on sale and you'll be pleasantly surprised.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 22, 2015
												I didn't want to do a review of this so soon, but I had the torrent of this and logged a good 20 or so hours into it before it went on sale on Steam, so I think that is enough to have a good enough idea and experience to do one.First off the presentation of GAS is very well done. The introduction, the personalization and the way everything flows is very refreshing. The racing scene is pretty deep with various disciplines to choose from, though you will eventually have to do every one of them to get into the GRID series.The visuals are absolutely spectacular, especially for a game that only came out for PC and last gen consoles. GAS really shows off the best the EGO 3 engine has to offer and what's is capable of, even if it was built and made for 360/PS3.The AI is much improved over GRID 2 and the "hard" difficulties are actually a challenge for once. Codemasters said this was wheel to wheel racing and that it is. Before I dwell deeper into the review, here is a breakdown of the pros and cons IMO;+Graphics/Visuals+Sound+Presentation+Multiple Disciplines+Teammate-Forced Drifting-Upgrade System-Teammate (yes both a pro and a con)-Lack of detailed in-car cockpit view -Forced to play all disciplines-Some disciplines not as well done as others-Lacking car selection-Team OffersOne of the stand out negatives you will be faced with, is the fact you are forced to play all disciplines and some of those disciplines are clearly inferior to others. Open Wheel, Street and Touring are very well done and thought out. However Tuner and Endurance is a joke. Tuner would of been great, if it wasn't the one buzz kill and sole aspect that completely ruins the discipline and that is drifting. Drifting in this game, as most other games that incorporate it are utter trash and more work than it needs to be. Codemasters stated that GAS was "bringing racing and the series back to its roots". However, drifting is not grass roots racing, nor is it really racing at all. It is an extreme niche and is more of an art form then racing, and should of either been taken out completely or been an optional DLC add-on like Drag Racing is. I liked Drifting, 10 years ago when it was a fad....Some other notable negatives to touch on is the team mate mechanic. Though the presentation and potential is there, the execution is not. Not sure what the point of them really are, as more often than not, they suck and almost always bring your team rating down. They give you the option to assign various driving mechanics to them while racing like HOLD, PUSH and ATTACK, but I’ve found that none of the settings really matter and even on PUSH and ATTACK setting they still more often than not, drop back in the pack. I hope they expand more on this in later titles and have more customization for the player to fine tune teammate(s).The last thing I want to mention are the team offers and upgrades. Team offers are somewhat pointless as the only differences between them are the level of tuning you can do, XP you can earn and simple pre-installed upgrades already applied to the team cars. Why offer any type of "upgrade" mechanic if the player has no control over them, other than to take them off? Better teams have more upgrades pre-installed, but it's a roll of the dice on which ones you get and it seems to be based on what difficulty you had set the previous championship. i.e. you have better team offers and pre-installed upgrades the higher you set the difficulty,  which this alone is counter-productive. I always tend to set my racing games to the hardest they can be, but I am not everyone.All in all though this is a great game. By no means is this a racing simulator, but I would rank it up with Shift and Shift 2 as not a full on sim, but not a full on arcade racer either. Though at least with Shift 2 you have an upgrade system lol.Stunning visuals and sound will leave you wanting more. Plenty of real world tracks and rendered cities to race in with a mediocre amount of cars, but good enough selection, though some choice as to what cars we race in would been better.In the end I give this a 7 /10

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 23, 2015
												OK So I am a GRID tragic, I played the first GRID right through career multiple times, got to Legend status online then started again multiple times, and thought there would never be as fun a simcade as GRID. So I had high hopes for GRID 2, eagerly awaited it while still churning out laps on GRID. GRID 2, put simply, was an abomination that Codemasters should be ashamed of. But then, to atone for their sins, along came GRID Autosport.It is everything GRID 2 should have been. I feel like Codies made this game purely to make up for the god awful retch of a game that was GRID 2. But Autosport delivers the original GRID experience, but expands upon it in so many new ways. Better models, tracks, detail, and racing. It is deep, challenging, and fun. I am playing through Career on Hard and though I get the odd win here and there, it is a struggle. Which means the learning curve and difficulty is almost spot on. The AI does not race like real racers do, however. They are way too aggressive, if you are on the racing line and ahead of them, they will hit you every time to put themselves on the racing line, often taking you out. It is a robotic AI, not so much a 'real racing' AI. But you have flashback, and once you become aware of how the AI drives and corners, you can work with it. It's not so bad as to become a real problem, plus as with all racing games, you can ALWAYS OUTBRAKE THE AI. I would love to find a racing game one day, where the AI throws caution to the wind and overtakes under brakes more aggressively than a human can. As with GRID Autosport, like most other racing games,  the game is won and lost in the corners, and who can outbrake the best. Once day, a racing game will realise this - and adjust to the way a human drives - or at least, combat outbraking by outmanoevering or using [prediction, as a real human racer does. But all in all... I love GRID Autosport. I use a Hyperdrive ockpit and Logitech MOMO Force wheel and pedals. Sometimes I will even put my motorbike helmet and gloves on to race. I'm that much of an e-racing Nerd. But I don't care. Thanks Codemasters, for delivering on the GRID Legacy. Just a shame you didn't also deliver it to next gen consoles.  Cause in a month or two, it's gonna be all about Project Cars and the Legacy of GRID will fade again. Until then, I'm still a Legend in my own Garage.

content:
Posted: November 14, 2015
												I have to say this is one of the most fun racing games I have ever played (i've also played F1 and rally games). There are five disciplines to play, to provide quite a nice varriety of racing types. But what I like the most, and makes the game fun is the AI. The AI is very competitive, but acts somewhat human and not mechanical, it blocks when you try to overtake, goes for the inside when it's overtaking. It is also prone to mistakes. I've seen many times cars flip over, colliding between them allowing you to pass past them. I've read some people complining that the AI is to aggresive, and they are somewhat right, but that's how this kind of racing are. The AI is not that agressive that it's oblivious to you, but they do try to bump you of the road. I think CM have found a good balance for the AI. One other thing I like is night racing. Sepang or Circuit of the Americas is amazing at night. The game is not perfect, the tracks tend to repeat themselves, but there are enough not to get boring, and also there's not a huge selection of cars, but again there is enough so to give you plenty of hours to try them all. 30 hours in and I have still not played all the tracks and all the cars. Another complaint by a lot of players is the interior cam, which looks poor and is barely usefull, but it didn't stop me from enjoying this game so much. I suggest that if you like racing games, you owe it to yourself to play this game. It's one of the best.

content:
Posted: February 20, 2016
												Overall rating: 8/10RACING:GRID Autosport is not at all like GRID 2. Drifting is slow where as a smooth and clean racing line gives you the fastest lap possible. The difficulty is perfect for me. I'm playing on the "very hard" difficulty and winning a race is really difficult which is why my win rate is like 15%. For me, this is great because winning feels like a great success and does not become normal.The AI fights with you around every corner. Oftentimes, they crash into me and all of a sudden I'm no longer 4th but last in the grid. That is very frustrating. Sometimes, it might be better not to fight too hard but just to let the faster car pass and savely drive at your pace. But fighting against the AI makes a lot of fun because they try not to let you pass and stuff.CAREER:The career is okay. It's dumb that you only earn XP. That way, you cannot really achieve anything. The only way you "rank up" is by getting XP and then competing in more advanced cups. Also, if you did good in a cup, team offers will change to more successful teams and the demands a team offers are higher.So actually, the only thing that I don't like about this game is that there is no real story to the career. But if you just want to race, it's a great game.I'm playing with a controller and it works just fine.

number of helpful: 2 of 3 people (67%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 30, 2016
												My experience with Autosport has been mixed, but mostly positive. On one hand, I enjoy the game. It's different than grid one and two being that it lacks customization and a sense of progression as a racing team. Rather, you're a driver for hire racing for multiple different teams. You don't buy your own cars, you don't customize them, you simply choose a contract and race a series for them. I can see how this would turn fans of the series off. However, the racing itself I found to be very well done and, despite some flaws, fun to play. It feels more like a racing sim such as project cars (albeit with assists and the signature rewind feature of Grid), yet still playable for casual fans of the genre and those looking for more of a easy-going racer. The thing I like about the racing is the ai. Whether you think it's good or bad ai, i still found it fun to play against. The reason being that the ai is more aggressive than a typical racing sim and thus leads to a more interesting experience. You find yourself dodging pile-ups, trying to powerslide around corners, and trying to avoid being taken out by opponents that are set on winning. That's a turn-off for some, so it's up to you whether you like that hectic style of racing. The game works great with my cheapo thrustmaster wheel, so I assume if you have a racing wheel it won't have much problem calibrating with it. The game is also optimized very well, and being that it's made for intel cards I assume it'll be perfectly playable on a standard computer without a dedicated GPU like Nvidia or Radeon. However, my particular model of GPU (Nvidia gtx 860m) gave me some issues with the game, which I suspect were from the windows 10 upgrade since it worked fine on windows 8. The game would crash after 15 minutes of gameplay on the nose with no error message. Apparently this is a somewhat common issue among Nvidia users. This problem never resolved itself until eventually I got a new computer with a 960m. If you have an 860m and run windows 10, be careful.If I were to rate this game out of 10, I'd say it deserves 7/10. It leaves a lot to be desired for hardcore Grid fans, yet might be exactly what you want for others. I for one enjoyed it for what it was.

number of helpful: 2 of 3 people (67%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 5, 2015
												Ok. Look, here's how it is. Grid autosport is a beautifal game. The racing is pretty fun and more challenging than I was expecting, which is good. Unlike most games you aren't expected to win first every time and 4th-8th is acceptable for most starting racing contracts. You start off racing small class c touring cars so Ford Focus, Honda Civics and the like and then proceed into other classes. I haven't got to them all so I won't comment on that. I guarantee one of the ones around this will have.And whilst the UI is beautifal and well the whole game is beautifal, this WHOLE game feels like an after thought. I mean for starters when I first opened the game it felt empty, something was missing. I don't know what to say about it really. It lacks immersion maybe? And one of the most shocking things out of the box was that you HAD TO MAP IN XBOX 360 CONTROLS! WTF CODEMASTERS!!Instead of a cockpit you have the cockpit kind of blurred out, and it's modelled horribly in there. No dials in there work etc. Honestly one of the worst things I have ever seen and I want to slap whoever at codemasters thought that was ok. Because it isn't. It gives a nice effect I get that, but at the same time it is horrible and i hope i never see it in a game EVER again. THAT is one of the biggest gripes I have ever had with a game.Apart from that it's pretty good, and seems to be sponsored by Intel HD Graphics weirdly enough so i am curious to see how well it might run on my new macbook air (in bootcamp obvs). Should you get this game though... well here's how I am going to lay this out. If you play A LOT of racing games you probably won't have an issue here. If you're like me who plays them occasionally you might enjoy it. If you like forza motorsport 4 and 5 well you will enjoy it but you cannot mess around and tune stock cars as much as you can on forza. This game needs to be taken seriously. And finally if you want this game as kind of SERIOUS simulator like i did save your money for project cars or assetto corsa. Don't get me wrong this is a nice game, but for some reason it's just not completely for me. No game has really come out for PC with the kind of arcade / simulation style of Gran Turismo and Forza and thats really starting to bug me. I like forza because if i dont want to play career mode, i can just buy cars, tune them and play online and set insane lap times (1.11.459 around top gear test track nissan GT-R, 7:49 nurburgring). Which is great because forza's career mode takes hundreds of hours to do, and I don't have that time. After all this though do I recommend it... Well... If you can deal with the crap I talked about then yes. Else, save your money.

number of helpful: 2 of 3 people (67%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: May 26, 2015
												8 out of 10Grid Autosport is a great return to series roots with much improved graphics and sound then other versions. featuring over 100 cars to choose from (including DLC), from cars like Nissan Skyline, Honda Civic, Mini Cooper through to the Bugatti Veyron 16.4 super sport, Lola B12/80, and the GT40 mk1 spanning several motorsport types from touring car, tuner, endurance (the races aren't that long), open wheel, street racing and party mode (which is basically demolition derby). from those modes they are split into different race modes including drift, JDM, unofficial V8 Supercars (Super Tourers) using only the VF Commodore and FG Falcon and unofficial Indy Car series (Formula A) using the  Dallara DW12 chassis.With 28 locations and 130 track layouts from street circuits and closed racing circuits (real and fiction) to choose from including, Spa-Francorchamps, Brands Hatch, Mount Panorama and Indianapolis. Also featuring day and night racing (night racing on selected tracks only). Unfortunately there is no Nurburgring or Circuit De La Sarthe.Features a new and improved damage system, enhanced physics and flashbacks. It is an overall solid action racing game but is still lacking in great and important features that would greatly improve the series like better AI, pit stops, dynamic weather, dynamic time of day change, rally racing, longer races and get rid of that dam cockpit blur. Overall I give it 8 out of 10 for the great graphics, car selection and the replay value.

content:
Posted: July 4, 2014
												Codemasters have done something good with this game. The tracks, the cars, the gameplay - all great.The different classes of race and cups, the simple increase of level of each class and the selection of sponsors give this game a good linear direction. Something which was missing in Grid 2, which was all over the place like a crazy woman's makeup.The upgrades on the cars are a bit restrictive, as it the setup on some sponsor cars, but having no control over that makes for good playability as you need to adjust your driving style for the car. And I like that.Graphics are nice maxed out, some dodgy 8-bit styling coming from building reflections on the cars.. But that's really just nit-picking. The engine seems to be a lot more polished and infinitely more optomised. A massive step up from G2.Where the game falls down are, in my opinion, the strength of team mates and the audible names. 3rd generation of Grid should at least have more names than the first. I mean there are completely bizarre names on there, but Doug is still left out! *huffs*All in all a great little game from Codemasters, but I just can't understand why they made this a full product and not just an epic DLC for Grid 2.

number of helpful: 2 of 3 people (67%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 26, 2014
												I was surprised at how decent this was. Looks great, sounds good, and actually plays really well once you get used to the new handling physics. Handles more like Gran Turismo 4 than it does the original GRID, but that's not a bad thing, it's just different. My primary complaint is that all variations of every track are not open to every class of car in time trials. You can only drive hatchbacks on the Okutama Sprint Circuit, for instance. The Grand Circuit is not an option. The menus are nice and sleek, too. I'd rarely make a point of that sort of thing, but it impressed me a lot for some reason.It's a good game. So far, everything I've driven has been fun to drive, from Open Wheel, to Street, to Tuner, which I can't say for the original GRID (some of the EU and US events weren't very good). Just don't go into it expecting something which is exactly the same as GRID 2, or something that behaves like a proper simulator.

number of helpful: 2 of 3 people (67%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 11, 2016
												Purchased this game because it is available for Linux.   I have owned  and played Codemasters games (Dirt and others) in the past and was quite impressed, so my expectations were quite high...  Installation went well on Ubuntu 14.04LTS (Specs: I3, 3Ghz, 16GB RAM, nVidia GTX250 "Dark Knight" 1GB). nVidia 340 proprietary driver.Game started fine and I was able to access options menu and configure my Logitech G25 wheel.   BONUS! Started the first race with great expectations.....   Oops.   Black screen.   Sounds in background....  Crash. After some messing around,  managed to get the game working in very basic graphics mode using open source Linux driver.....  Game plays with minimal graphics at~40fps....Love the game,  but obviously the graphics need fixing on Linux.Later Edit:  Installed the game on a better computer (i7, 930, 2.8Ghz, 12GB DDR 1600 RAM, nVidia Gforce GTX 760 & nVidia Linux driver) and it runs very well.  Still can't run it on the highest graphics settings but am getting ~50 -60 fps on high.The good stuff:I like the variety of races, tracks and cars.  I like the idea of being offered a contract to drive for various teams and even though the choice is limited (2 teams at a time), but this is mostly a good thing as it makes the choice easy.  I like the graphics effects, dust, smoke, car parts flying around....  etc.  I prefer to use the internal camera view and like that there are two options.  Others have commented on the quality of the internal dash graphics but I can appreciate that if you are focussed on the road ahead, the dash would be out of focus and is not important anyway....  so it works for me.As mentioned above, my Logitech G25 is recognised and works well, including Force Feedback (a big plus on Linux!)...  more on this below.The not so good stuff:The AI drivers are very aggressive.  I have fought to gain a respectable position near, or at the front of the pack, only to be shunted out of the way on the last lap with no way to catch up again..... Frustrating!  Put it this way, if I ran a club and other members of that club drove the way the AI do in this game, I would kick them out of the club!I know there is a flasback option but I find myself using this more to 'correct' problems with aggressive AI behaviour than I do to fix my own mistakes.The game (Linux version) does not store or remember my Wheel settings, so I have to go in an reset everything everytime I start the game.   There is a preset option for Logitech G25 but it is all wrong for my setup?  OVERALL:I recommend the game to anyone who enjoys racing without the extensive tuning and tweaking required by some other racing games.  Just jump in a go.Be prepared to fight to gain and hold your postion.   The AI play rough!It works well on Ubuntu 14.04 (with appropriate hardware)....

content:
Posted: July 13, 2016
												If you really MUST pick one between Grid Autosport and Grid 2, go for Autosport to avoid all those pile of SHXT arcade drifts.IN TRUTH THOUGH, even Autosport has less realistic handling physics than GRID 1 (acceleration/braking is better in AS though, without being exaggerated). Handling in GRID 1 was so good that it could rival the top ultimate sim games (e.g. rFactor) in not all but at least few aspects (despite it was never meant to be full-sim).  GRID AS, despite its richer content, failed to recapture the handling magic of GRID 1, and the driving experience is too detached and easy(simplified) in typical modern Codemasters way. (same for Dirt RALLY, yes people gonna hate me for saying this but it's FACT).IF SIM is what you have in mind, FORGET AUTOSPORT. At least GRID 1 one aspect close to sim level which makes it worth considering, but AS doesn't. I'm still waiting for GRID 1 v2 dear Codemasters.

content:
Posted: April 3, 2015
												GRID Autosport is by far the best racing game i've played. What I liked about the game:---------------------------------------The graphics are stunning, and can definetly be deemed as the best graphics to currently be implemented into a racing game. (Just don't open the car doors and you'll be fine!) -The sound is sharp and realistic, and really makes the game that much more enjoyable to play.-Multiplayer is a blast, and I have made alot of friends and had alot of fun in the meantime. Just watch out for drivers that don't know how to use the breaks when reaching corners.-The singleplayer/campaign is recommended by me as it gets you to grips with the game, and gives you an experience that you will never forget! Heres some tips for those critics out there:---------------------------------------------------------Don't like the interior "blurry" view? Don't use the interior camera then.Don't like the game overall? Go complain to a community that actually cares and go back to playing Mario Kart. WE LOVE AUTOSPORT! <3  Honestly I love this game, and I can't wait to see what else Codemasters brings us in the near future.

My favorite type of race in the game is the Street Race and after the Touring race, and I find these twe the most exiting part of the game! The gameplay is very good and compined with the tuning part it's getting even better. One thing that i don't like it's the way that the replay shows too much copkit view, the hud view and the rear spoiler and it shows less from a view that you can see the whole car and the other cars around you! Also, I really think it should have more manufactures and more cars like Subaru Impreza WRX STI, Mitsubishi Lancer Evolution, Porsche, Lamborghini, Toyota Supra, newer models of Camaro and Corvette, Haven't played much multiplayer yet so I can't say much but all the times i had played with others there was no lag and we were more that 10 people in one race! number of helpful: 3 of 5 people (60%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 27, 2014
												ok, this is not an average review. i will not mention other grid titles. i am reviewing this game as a game in its own right. this game is not a simulator. if you want a sim get a sim. this isn't an arcade racer though either. it cuts a happy medium. the handling is somehwre between assetto corsa and nfs: shift2 unleashed. its very accessible, but very rewarding and has subtleties and nuances that will have you clenching♥♥♥♥♥cheeks and leaning in your chair. the racing is great. the AI isn't bad. a bit ruthless at times, but then so are you. the amount of different races is fantastic. plenty to do. the graphics are excellent, and it runs really well. no hitching or stuttering. no obvious glitches. menu system is great. joypad integration is faultless, and the cars handle perfectly well without having to fiddle with deadzones and gamma. you'll see no twitchy driver hands here thankyou assetto corsa. the cockpit view which seems in contention is fine. press the view button enough times and you get a set back view where you can see the steering wheel. its fine. overall i would rate this game a 9 out of 10.

number of helpful: 3 of 5 people (60%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: August 23, 2014
												It's a very good game indeed, not worth 50€ though, maybe 35€ or 40€.The stupid drifts from GRID 2 are gone! (Yeeaah!)This game is now closer to the good old GRID, but forget the handbrake lad, you won't be using it as you would on GRID :)GRID Autosport's assist are VERY well done, in my opinion. The old GRID assists would allow you do "derp" around with the handbrake, allowing you to go into a corner at full speed and just go around it with a perfect powerslide.Now Autosport's assists are an "assist". They don't give you the power to "derp" around and win, but they limit your car, in a way newer drivers would be able to feel how the game is, and drive around, but not to get good lap times.When you get rid of those assists (don't get off ABS so soon though :) ) you'll be able to really get into Hot Lapping, and getting the drifty feel around a corner and therefore going around it faster.ABS should be the last assist to get rid of. Why? After letting your car oversteer all it wants, getting the brakes to lock isn't a very good idea, so, get those oversteers controlled, and then you can get into the brake locking, and being your own ABS.Without ABS you'll be able to lose speed faster on a smaller amount of space, and time, therefore improving your lap times.Now, let's get into the game, not the driving itself.The career, I found it a bit boring, but that's because of another factor we'll talk about later, and you won't be able to make your own livery ( :( ), but you'll be able to race with real sponsors, and choose the one that you want to race with.Each sponsor can have a different car, but they have different rewards on XP. You won't need to buy a car, since the sponsor gives you one, or several if other vehicle is needed on the event.Sponsors also give you different possibilities in terms of vehicle setup and parts to install to improve your car's performance.Okay, I said the career was a bit boring because of the... Car color :( Nah, the Artificial Intelligence (A.K.A. AI).This is where the juice gets sour.The AI is a bit dumb, let's say. I've only raced it on very hard, but I think they act the pretty same on the other difficulties.I've experienced ramming, pushing you out of the track (into the grass, dirt, W/E), dumb lines on corners, and other "derpy" movement.The AI is VERY aggressive but at the same time dumb and suicidal (who knows why...).On the first races I had I found it very hard to get past the Ravenwest guys, their cars are a bit overpowered comparing to yours, and if you don't get them at the correct time, you'll have a VERY hard time, or you'll even lose the race.AI fails reacting to braking, even to other AI driver's braking, and it's a damn ramfest at the first corner.Once I saw a Focus Touring car at the Hockenheimring just going straight past a hairpin, and flipping on the gravel (spooky).So, biggest fail? AI, definitely.About the online.Now, here starts the fun. Racing people worldwide! Now that's amazing :)I'm a HUGE fan of online racing, but not on Sim Racing games, GRID Autosport IS NOT A SIM, it's a sim/arcade as people would call it, and this game fits me perfectly!They have done a really good thing, so you can point out who's a rammer, and who's going to keep their line and race with the minimum contact possible.Followed by the online name of the player, comes a plain circle with an exclamation mark in it.It goes from Orange to White and can have 4 colors.Orange - Avoid this guy!Yellow - Contact is commonGreen - Contact is possibleWhite - Contact is avoidedYou'll start with a yellow circle, but don't worry, you'll get that to green or white in no time, if you race properly :) (Not like the A.I. ^^ )I've experienced some lags, like ramming the guy that was in front of me, but I didn't even touch him, but hopefully that's going to be fixed, also my connection isn't a big deal.Now, on the online you can create your own "Club", and people can apply to join it.You can create your own livery for your club, just like how it was on GRID 2 :) You can change and paint wheels as well.But, you'll have to buy your own cars. Don't worry if you don't have it, you'll be able to race anyways, but with a car that isn't your, therefore you can't change it's setup, install parts or repair it. (We'll get there very soon :) )When you buy your car you'll be able to level it up, and higher the level, you start unlocking setup packages, that allow you to change your car's setup. The higher the package, more freedom on setting it up. Level also unlocks parts to improve your car's performance, but everything will cost you GRID $, but not that much, a race or two can pay those :)After a race, you'll have to repair your car, because it was worn. It's called condition, and it's measured in percentage, the higher the percentage is, the best the car will react on an impact (more durable), and better it's performance, so keep it always on the 100% :)The online prices are very good and equilibrated, you can also buy used cars, that are cheaper, but they have more mileage, and more mileage means the more expensive the car is to repair after it being used.I've never bought a used car, always stuck to newer ones, because on the long-run you'll save more money.Used cars are more for flash using, let's say.TO SUM UP!What a huge review, huh :D-A bit overpriced, probably less 10€ would be it's price, but we don't know what's behind the making of the game.-Assist system is very well done, a newbie driver will feel safe driving on this game, but won't be faster than someone without assists.-AI is a bit dumb and aggressive.-Online is very well done and promotes fair-play.-I recommend this game, but probably you should wait for a discount.Hope it helped :)

content:
Posted: June 28, 2015
												Grid Autosport...I've got this game with my Intel I7 4790k... looks good , runs good but loads of problemsThe AI ... as many other reviews have stated ... well , its not bad but its not great either , if you get in the lead , on higher dificulties , the ai will start smashing into you breaking your car , while it doesn't take any damage.One major surprise i've had with this game is the awful textures. The spectators are sometimes zoomed on when you finish the race and god , did those PS2 graphics give me nightmares. And one extremely important thing that a '' profesional '' racer must have?  Well , if you're gonna include a 1st person view god f-in dammit include some hi-res steering wheel and speed meter textures? NO , of course , just more PS2 graphics , blurry as hell...My verdict? number of helpful: 4 of 7 people (57%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 8, 2014
												Short version: GRID Autosport is a fun and enjoyable game; it has its flaws and little problems, but overall it's a very good experience and I recommend it.Now for the whole review: in my opinion Autosport is what Grid 2 should have been. The game takes as its inspiration mostly the first Grid, with some features and ideas taken from the sequel and some new things to complete it.GRAPHICS: G:A uses (again) the Ego engine. In my opinion it works really fine, the graphics are still very nice (especially with the HD textures pack) but at the same time scalable and lightweight; I can play without problems on my not recent laptop on medium-high settings without any problems. Sometimes there's a little freeze of half a second (it seems a common issue regardless of the pc), but happens once every 5-6 races so it's not really a problem. There's the controversial point of the cockpit view: it makes its return from the absence of Grid 2, but we don't have the detailed cockpits of Grid; instead we have non-functional instruments (only the steering wheel turns), "hidden" by a blur filter. It's better than not having one, but it's quite disappointing (seeing also older games like Shift series having beautiful cockpits).DRIVING MODEL: it's known that the game doesn't aim to be a simulator. The game tries to be halfway between an arcade and a simulator, and in my opinion succeeds. The game is accessible enough, with a lot of driving aids like traction control, ABS, racing line, etc. but with all deactivated races become challenging enough without the "frustration" of a simulator. Clean driving and racing lines will net you good times, and the Grid 2 drifting is completely gone. Sometimes the car behaves a little strangely (from a realistic point of view), but it's natural in the game's system.SINGLE PLAYER CAREER: one of the most disappointing things of the game in my opinion. The scheme is: you have 5 disciplines to choose from, every championship won will make you level up and unlock more championships of the same discipline. But there's no other progress: you always drive as a hired driver and won't create your own team. There's no money earning nor car customization - you simply choose a championship, one from the teams that offer you a car and race. Honestly you can do exactly the same by playing custom cups, with the execption that everything's unlocked from the start.MULTIPLAYER: the real strong point of the game. As in the single player, there are 5 categories of racing (Touring, Open Wheel, Endurance, Tuned, Street). When you decide to go online, you can create or join a custom cup (which specifies the events, tracks, cars, etc.) or jump onto a default playlist, which spawns across the various cars and tracks available in the discipline. When you play online you can use rental cars or buy your own with the money earned from racing. The advantage of using your own cars is that everyone has its own "level" and gaining experience will unlock you upgrades, but only for the SPECIFIC car. So even if someone played 200 hours but never touched, for example, touring cars he won't have any upgrade available - and you can see that because there are 5 separated experience levels for the player, one for each discipline. You can create or join clubs, customize your liveries and so on. The races are really smooth and there's rarely lag. For me the multiplayer is a really good point.So, to summarize, this game feels like the "real GRID2", it's the sequel of Grid. The average review scores are derived by the fact that this game has nothing "extraordinary" with respect to Grid 2, it seems like that Codemasters acknowledged their mistake with the second game and made this to return on track. It has many tracks and cars, it's a great experience, but if you were burned by Grid 2 you will be pleased by the return to the roots of the series. It's worth its price, but you can feel "cheated" by this game that should've been released years ago with the name Grid 2. In this case, it's better to wait for a discount before buying it. For the others, it's one of the best racing games of its genre, and it's still recommended for everyone, especially if you plan to play online!

												The game is a lot of fun, when it comes to the realism, and is in many ways similar to Grid. Grid though, is somewhat old now, but believe it or not, the AI worked pretty well in the first game. In Grid autosport, that is not the case, they have somehow gotten worse. The AI takes no account for you being on the track too, AT ALL. The game is a lot of fun, when playing against players, but when I bought this game I had hoped singleplayer would be just as fun, maybe even better then the first one, which had me entertained for a very long time. The way the difficulty works in this game, isn't how good the AI is at driving, which it should be, when you turn up the difficulty, their cars are simply faster than your car, and impacts doesn't throw them off course, which it most certainly does to the player. I can only hope, since this is a fairly new game, that these things are problems they will be fixed through updates, this game could be so much more fun, and it would be a shame for this game to never reach the same level as the first Grid, because if not, this will be the last Grid game we might ever see, since no one can afford to very bad games in a row.

number of helpful: 5 of 9 people (56%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 16, 2014
												Grid Autosport is tantalizingly close to being great. All the ingredients are there. Impressive technical competency, a large amount of content, outstanding attention to detail in graphics & audio. But it fails at the fundamentals. The driving just isn’t as fun and interesting as it is in Gran Turismo or Forza.In order to make a track racing game interesting over the long haul, the tiniest details need to be just right. Not only does the underlying physics model need to be complex, but it needs to be communicated to the player just right so they can instinctively feel what’s going on. The camera angle plays a huge part in this, which is easy to demonstrate in Gran Turismo. In Gran Turismo the bumper cam is the defacto way to play the game. The alternative angles, like behind the car, are all hilariously awful in execution. You can’t see properly where you’re going, it’s completely stiff in an almost unnerving way. When you use the bumper cam you can see the car rearing back, diving forwards, tilting to the sides, all in subtle ways which tell you how stable the car is, or if you’re about to spin out etc.Grid Autosport feels simplistic. It isn’t complex enough, it’s too smooth. It’s almost hard to nail down exactly what it does wrong, because there’s plenty of great arcade racing games which aren’t boring. They’re usually much faster than Grid Autosport. Like the original Grid which met criticism from simulator fans who thought it felt like a racing sim sped up to 200% speed. I loved that aspect of it! When you drive down the same tracks in Grid Autosport at a more realistic speed, you’re given time to reflect on how nothing interesting is going on in the game. In Gran Turismo it’s engaging to drive slow piece of crap cars thanks to the exceptional feel of the physics. In Grid Autosport I’m struggling to be excited about the fastest cars in the world.The career mode in Grid Autosport is easily 50+ hours long, and I will never finish it. The game isn’t good enough to hold my interest. When I first got the game I played it a lot. Now I fire it up once a month and play it for a hour or two. That’s the level of engagement I get from it. And that’s fine! It has its merits, which make it a nice experience. But when their novelty fades, you’re left with only the underlying game to carry it. That’s where it fails.Despite this, I’m recommending it. It’s ok! Good enough to grab on sale. The first 10 hours or so are great. It’s only after that the tedium hits you like a ton of bricks.

content:
Posted: July 12, 2014
The Good Physics improved a lot. Now actually have to break. Car suspension is not made of cheese anymore. Well optimized. Will run on mid, low-end pc`s as well. Looks fine. Actual racing tracks. Long career mode.  Ravenwest do not use "Catch up" system anymore.  Cars handle very nice. Each have unique characteristic. Game uses both screens!!!!! Game on first, tv cam and real-time standings table on the other! Most awesome feature of the game.  Racenet race clubs are nice feature. You can make your own teams and team colors for cars to race online. Tons of things to do. Long single player career, splitscreen, sort of online career mode with online garage and leveling, like in GRID 2.  Online racing still very fun, when you can find actual people to race with. (! Online TIP  - in Europe set Steam download location to UK, to find lot more people to play with... go figure, but it works! ) Sound effects are on Battlefield level. This was one of the biggest surprises. Sound is just ♥♥♥♥ing awesome.  AI is aggressive and not affraid to fight for position unlike any other racing game. On highest difficulty modes even challenging. Some of the best AI I`ve seen in racing games lately.  Plays very nice. driving itself is fun. Still very arcadey, but improved a lot. Cars actually feel somewhat like cars with weight. Gameplay fluid, snappy, quick jump-in. Technically well done, feels finished. The Bad Multiplayer full of cheaters again. "Over the white lines" penalty ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥t is more annoying than ever. Succeeds at punishing for normal racing and ignoring obvious corner cutting as long as you release throttle.  Drifting is not racing!!! You will drift the ♥♥♥♥ out of championships to open higher tier races in career. You cannot just do single racing type to advance. Choose what you like, but you`ll have to drive them all! Collision detection system still broken and exploited in online races. Do not prevent MP griefing at all.  You can buy cars on online career, but you have very limited garage space. Each car have separate levels you need to unlock upgrades and even car setup, but cars are separate in million different categories with only  1-4 vehicles in each. And you will need a lot of cars to race and level your own not loaned ones.  A lot of content are recycled from GRID 2.  Too many levels in online mode. Racing category levels, car levels, main character levels, I`m just confused and don`t understand how to keep track on all of it.  No pitstops in endurance races. Tyre deterioration not really influanced by your driving style, but more by how far you are in a race. Feels pointless. No rain. No Mirrors ! Sponsors (provide XP) reward for doing ♥♥♥♥♥♥ on qualifying. You won`t always get rewards if starting from 1st position.The Ugly Cockpit view. WTF Codies?7/10

content:
Posted: December 25, 2014
												A very solid racing game indeed. It comes highly recommended from me. Codemasters have been perfecting their racing games for many years and this one is perhaps the best, I think since TOCA 2. Brilliant car physics for both the open wheelers and the tin-tops. A great damage engine, the graphics are the best yet in the Grid series. If you like arcade style racing and or doing your car up with shiny decals and nos look elsewhere. This is a serious racing game. Not as serious as R Factor but it does suit someone that is a fan of motorsport and understands the sports subtleties. For me its a good thing, but for a NFS fan it might not be so. Although there is a nod to arcade racing with the 'tuner' and 'street' classes this Grid title also gives back more to the anoraks than previous incarnations.Where the game is a real winner in the longevity stakes; is the online mode. I have had some dramatic and close races online with some serious game racing competition, you are able to run nose to tail and dice to the flag.The AI are pretty good. Probably one of the best AI in a racing game although they are no match for myself of course they can fight back and hold their line. One of the things I find an issue with many racing games AI is that they are too tentative when attempting to overtake. Not shy in this game however! The Grid series was for me a little pretentious in places. Especially Grid 2 where it seemed almost every car could only driven with an annoying arcade style drifting style. Not so here. Just like real racings its all about braking, taking the apex nicely and getting the power down fast out of the corner minimising wheelspin. You can even adjust the setup so this can be done smoother although that aspect is fairly simple this is surely a good thing to everyone except a car mechanic. The handling on most codemasters racing games is very good. The rally style handling of the Colin Mcrae games really was spot on and they have always seemed to have a good grasp on that aspect of racing since. Where GTA and Forza often seem to suffer from box-like understeer or wild oversteer you can really get a nice feel for most of the vehicles in Grid. Realistic or not they are satisfying to use.You will however get more than a hint of deja vu if you have bought the previous Grid games. This is more of an update of the previous incarnations than a new game. For me though for the price you cannot argue. The game bears the name of a popular motorsport magazine and herein lies the key difference in the Grid series that makes this one stand out. The racing is a sober and realistic (without being too realistic). They have stopped trying to copy Need For Speed and actually produced something reminiscent Codemasters great racing games of old. As a bit of a purist I wasn't sure about the rewind feature, although on reflection I think its actually quite handy. Especially in a long race against the computer cars (where you would have had to restart the race on older games).There is a wide selection of cars and tracks on offer. I think this is where the game progressing from the earlier titles comes in handy, since much of the old content has simply been given a lick of paint whilst new machinery has been added on top of that. The tin tops and open wheelers both handle characteristic to their class. Such great tracks as Spa, Brands Hatch and Hockenheim are all beautifully rendered.  The damage engine much like previous Grid games is very satisfying. The only game that I recall that comes close to its level of intricacy is on of the recent GTA games. You can enjoy some epic and frightiningly realistic looking shunts. Here is also where improved technology in the visual department is beneficial. The sense of speed is more tangible than ever and when you do get it very wrong you thank your lucky stars its a game and you are not inside the roll-cage! I am not a moaner and realise you don't always get what you want in life. But if I had to criticize this game I would probably say I would have liked a few more real permanent circuits (even if that meant less fictional street circuits.)  Also to complete career mode you have to total every class of racing in the game. Certain classes I like and certain ones not so much so they became somewhat of a chore. I also think the endurance class was quite interesting but they missed an opportunity to put in much longer truer enduro racing with pit-stops. Pit stops were one of the reasons TOCA 2 is one of my all-time favorite games. Overall this is a game for race fans by race fans and they have done a tidy job.

number of helpful: 2 of 4 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: August 17, 2014
												Like many others I was a huge fan of the original GRID. Like many other I thought Grid 2 was a huge misstep. Like many others I think this is even worse. Welcome to the new era of annual releases packed with day 1 DLC. I definitely do not recommend this game. The career is a farce, in my opinion. You don't progress or improve so much as you simply pick a new team in between every race, and drive a borrowed car. There's no sense of ownership in your accomplishments; the online is no better. Don't listen to what Codemasters says about listening to the community. It's all nonsense. The cars handle the same as G2, the career is infinitely more bland, the AI still attempts to kill you at every turn, and the online has no accountable match making system. My advice would be to simply re-play GRID 1. It's still the superior experience. A waste, and a squandered opportunity. This will be my last Codemasters racing game purchase for a long time. They've got a lot of work to do to earn my trust back.

number of helpful: 2 of 4 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 23, 2014
												Here it is.....bottom line.  This is a good game, it has its flaws, absolutely, in fact, I will list them:- AI is not great- AI is very aggressive in a non-realistic manner (i.e. ramming, bumping, etc.)- Racenet online challenges need to be sorted because many are leaderboards based on timed laps, yet the AI is there preventing time to really be the challenge due to the above issue.- Codemasters loves DLC, so much so that key components that should be present in the game, are pay for (i.e. garage space, additional "special" vehicles, and the one I am most irritated by is XP boost.- No Touge for drift, though we are told it is coming as a DLC (and see my point above)Now the good, then some explanation on the reason I reccomend the game.The good:- Fantastic sim-like racing- Each vehicle handles a little different, and you need to learn the vehicle, the track, and improve your skills based on that.- The multiplayer, although lacking spectate (ahem, this is needed yesterday) is really tons of fun with friends.- Racing teams online, thats right you and your besties, can enter as a team, in custom cups or whatever, ultimately competing against other teams and their standings.- Relatively good visual graphics and audioNow, after reading all of that, the game is a brand new release, and here is why I reccomend it, regardless of the negatives.  This is the best there actually is right now in PC racing.  In fact, I would venture to say that for a while this will be the standard, although we will have to see how Assetto Corsa and Project CARS turns out, but as for now, this is the crowning king.  However, the DLC, about that, yeah, I don't like it, but I think that if the company themselves would market this as an MMO with a monthly, then release the features as they have been, then everyones jimmys wouldnt be rustled.  The bottom line, right or wrong, DLC is the new gaming concept over subscription.  Think about it ESO $50 then $15 a month, WoW pretty much the same, SWTOR on its release was the same, you get what I am saying.  In fact many MMO's especially FTP, and games like The Secret World, offer issues on a quarterly basis, that expand the game, this is really no different. Am I defending the DLC tactic, not really, but on the same token the company has to have some motivation to support the game after launch, unlike MXGP, and other lesser games.  The true test will be what this game is like in a couple of months, and then see if the bugs and AI issues have been sorted out, at that time I will eat my review, but as of now I reccomend the game, and hope these issues are sorted.
