number of helpful: 1 of 2 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: August 31, 2014
												[h2]The Good:[/h2]* Beautiful graphics, even without the texture pack, pumping all the sliders to maximum produces some very pleasing pixels.* Strikes a good simulation / arcade balance, most of the time your car behaves the way you would expect it to, very occasionally they seem to have far to much grip, and then some other times none at all. * Great selection of different cars that sound very similar to the real deal.* Challenging AI will punish you for almost every mistake, and will make you fight for every position.* Clean and Intuitive User Interface, not as "pretty" but far more usable than the dirt games.* Varied game modes that I, personally, will take a while to master, Touring and Street racing are my favourites, and the Endurance, Drifting and Open Wheel events are quite challenging (maybe not open wheel for F1 vets?)[h2]The Bad:[/h2]* AI that disobeys the rules the player must stick to, quite a few times I've been tailgating an AI opponent and been penalised for going off track, with the AI racing off ahead of me. * The game lacks personality, the DiRT 2 and 3 games were brimming with character and style, that could be a little cheesy, but enjoyable. This game feels barren in comparison.* Could Ravenwest win a few less competitions next time ;-)* I feel that the multiplayer and singleplayer "career" progression should have been the same, or could even have been tied together (without needing to play both to progress of course.) Missed opportunity there![h2]The Ugly:[/h2]* Nearly everybody before me has said so, I feel I must also stress those car interiors. With nearly everything else about this game been so nice to look at, going inside the cars can be a bit of a shock to the system. While not a complete deal breaker, it was definitely disappointing seeing how bad they looked for the first time. * Turning off the HUD for full immersion is likely to see you hit a wall (in-game, not figuratively).[h2]Overall:[/h2]It's a solid racing game, it doesn't do anything truly great, or really bad.

number of helpful: 3 of 6 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 26, 2014
												Grid Autosport is as fun as the old Toca series in multiplayer physic wise. They even took the giant track in reverse like the spa which force you to learn a lot when it come for track layout. The car physic isn't too hard. the most fun part is that some different cars physics feel a lot different on each class. It may seem easy, but it's between sim & pro sim in Toca 2. If lose traction, you may not be able to recover if the angle is too high. Implementation of rumble strip act more like rumble strip & the grass tip your car to fall on the top is awesome(exclusive).The tracks are simply gorgeous. I'll probably say it is the best looking track I've seen on PC so far, normally you see the graphic all concentrated into the cars & the rest look like crap. The cars look great & detailled too, but not in the photo realism level. The wheels still look in 3d unlike forza motion blur that make the wheels look in 2d. The cockpit cam is simplified & I'm one of the believer that it's a waste of time to put too much effort there. Replay camera have been fixed & look more professional. I can now enjoy watching the replay, especially the drift event. With the RX7 grey, it look nearly real. One thing that bug me a bit is the physic being like Toca make the car all float around the track in the replay, except for the drift which look realistic. I believe some fake steering input animation implementation would fix the appearance during the replay. Automatic wings & the tailpipe boom boom spitfire is well animated with sound.The content, I didn't have the time to explore the whole game, but I can definitely write it has enough contents to make your gameplay past 40hours for sure. It has qualification, practice & someone who help you to know what's happening in the race by a press of a button. You can command your teammate to drive aggressively or not during the race(It can be helpful to win position or block the AI path). It has many series with different car handling with load of tracks & many are real world ones. If you play online, expect to play a lot of hours. The car won't throw off like ping pong if get touched & it's very good for a close race.

number of helpful: 2 of 4 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: September 8, 2014
												I purchased and beat Grid 1 and had a pretty good time with it. Then Grid 2 was announced but they said they weren't including cockpit view. That's lazy as hell and I skipped Grid 2. Then Grid Autosport was announced and cockpit view was making a return. YAY! Just recently all of Codemaster's games recieved major discounts. I picked up Grid Autosport and gave it a try. I'm over 10 hours in and while the game is fun overall, there are a few things I don't like. The main thing is that yes, the cockpit view is back, but only sort of. The view is there, but the gauges are a static image, any car that has shift lights don't actually have working shift lights, and then the entire dash is blurred. The rearview mirrors don't even work and they, too, are blurred. There is also the lack of a field of view option.There is also rubberbanding. It's the strongest in the touring car discipline. You can disable it by deleting a file but that file is tied to the game's anti-piracy system for some reason. This means that if you delete the file to get rid of rubberbanding, the game won't let you save your progress. That's ridiculous and pathetic. The AI is also extremely aggressive and will slam into you when you try to pass them. Codemasters wants this game to have some sim-like elements but won't include a full cockpit view and adds rubberbanding. It's like they want to make a racing game but also don't want to make a racing game.There aren't a whole lot of tracks present but the ones included do look alright. The cars look nice as well. There's some DLC available (of course) but I'm not spending any more money on this game so I'm not sure how that content is.There are some positives, though. The graphics are okay and there's no FPS lock. The game runs pretty smoothly. There's a few different disciplines and a decent variety of vehicles. Lots of input devices are supported and there's a nice amount of graphical options and difficulty options. The sounds are pretty good, from engine noises to crowds and track sounds, everything sounds nice. So while the game can be fun, I can't recommend it due to the half♥♥♥♥♥♥♥cockpit view and inclusion of rubberbanding AI. And I definitely wouldn't recommend it at its normal $50 price. Wait a while and pick it up when it gets to $10 if you really want to try it.

content:
Posted: September 1, 2014
												Good racing game.  Takes almost everything I like from Grid and Grid 2 and put them together.  You have 5 different disciplines to race in.  Each has its unique cars and challenges.  Once you reach certain levels in all 5 disciplines, you unlock the Grid racing for that level.  The variety of cars and tracks keeps you on your toes.  The online is good too as long as you don't end up in a room full of rammers.  If you don't particularly want to race against opponents, then there is the weekly challenges that you can race.  You compete for level awards and can compare yourself to others.  If you like the Codemaster racing games, this is a no brainer.

number of helpful: 1 of 2 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: September 1, 2014
												This is a game for true motorsport lovers. Here you can go straight to the point - drive the best available race cars out there in professional championships and make a name for yourself changing between the categories of your choice anytime you want (rather than being forced to drive housewife lemons in endless itty-bitty cups to climb in your career, such as the likings of Gran Tourismo and Forza). The career mode offers a great experience where you'll have to beat rivals, help teammates and please all your sponsors in order to make progress throughout the seasons. Gameplay can be completely adjusted to your skills and likings, so if you prefer some more pedal-to-the-metal arcade race with no damage or a full simulation with deep physics it's all up to you to set. Graphics are simply stunning, and the sceneries are richly detailed, which comes in handy considering you'll be visiting many metropolises around the globe.Bottomline, best racing sim ever.

number of helpful: 1 of 2 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: August 28, 2014
 Disappointing Let me start off by saying I was a huge fan of the original GRID. It wasn't realistic, but it was fun.So how does GRID Autosport stack up? It has its similarities to GRID but it isn't as good.PROSThe game is fun and there is a large variety of different vehicle types to choose from. The handling is a bit slippery but it's really easy to handle even with all assists off. This allows you to go around corners at really high speeds which adds to the excitement at the expense of realism.CONSThe game is NOT complete. The interiors are nothing but blurry pictures. Even at night, you can't see any lights inside the vehicle. What's the point of a cockpit view if you can't even see your own speedometer? The game also lacks content. Sure there are a wide range of different types of vehicles (Indy, Coupes, Touring, etc) but considering how the interiors are non-existent couldn't they have stuffed a little more in there instead of releasing an early DLC? The track selection is adequet. There are lots of famous tracks and a lot of city tracks but the number of different tracks is still relatively low. Finally, the game itself can get quite boring. The campaign is like any other campaign. You win races and you climb up into better and faster cars. The problem is, for the first several hours, you're basically driving the same car on the same tracks. This gets tedious especially since some events require you to complete the same track twice.CONCLUSIONWith games like Gran Turismo 6, Forza 5, F1 2013, and Shift 2 out, it's hard to recommend this game content-wise. The gameplay however is not lacking although it may feel dull at times. The conclusion? This game feels rushed and Codemasters should have spent more time on it.

The rearview mirrors don't even work and they, too, are blurred. There is also the lack of a field of view option.There is also rubberbanding. It's the strongest in the touring car discipline. You can disable it by deleting a file but that file is tied to the game's anti-piracy system for some reason. This means that if you delete the file to get rid of rubberbanding, the game won't let you save your progress. That's ridiculous and pathetic. The AI is also extremely aggressive and will slam into you when you try to pass them. Codemasters wants this game to have some sim-like elements but won't include a full cockpit view and adds rubberbanding. It's like they want to make a racing game but also don't want to make a racing game.There aren't a whole lot of tracks present but the ones included do look alright. The cars look nice as well. There's some DLC available (of course) but I'm not spending any more money on this game so I'm not sure how that content is.There are some positives, though. The graphics are okay and there's no FPS lock. The game runs pretty smoothly. There's a few different disciplines and a decent variety of vehicles. Lots of input devices are supported and there's a nice amount of graphical options and difficulty options. The sounds are pretty good, from engine noises to crowds and track sounds, everything sounds nice. So while the game can be fun, I can't recommend it due to the half♥♥♥♥♥♥♥cockpit view and inclusion of rubberbanding AI. And I definitely wouldn't recommend it at its normal $50 price. Wait a while and pick it up when it gets to $10 if you really want to try it.

												This is a game for true motorsport lovers. Here you can go straight to the point - drive the best available race cars out there in professional championships and make a name for yourself changing between the categories of your choice anytime you want (rather than being forced to drive housewife lemons in endless itty-bitty cups to climb in your career, such as the likings of Gran Tourismo and Forza). content:
Posted: August 28, 2014
 Disappointing Let me start off by saying I was a huge fan of the original GRID. It wasn't realistic, but it was fun.So how does GRID Autosport stack up? It has its similarities to GRID but it isn't as good.PROSThe game is fun and there is a large variety of different vehicle types to choose from. The handling is a bit slippery but it's really easy to handle even with all assists off. This allows you to go around corners at really high speeds which adds to the excitement at the expense of realism.CONSThe game is NOT complete. The interiors are nothing but blurry pictures. Even at night, you can't see any lights inside the vehicle. What's the point of a cockpit view if you can't even see your own speedometer? The game also lacks content. Sure there are a wide range of different types of vehicles (Indy, Coupes, Touring, etc) but considering how the interiors are non-existent couldn't they have stuffed a little more in there instead of releasing an early DLC? The track selection is adequet. There are lots of famous tracks and a lot of city tracks but the number of different tracks is still relatively low. Finally, the game itself can get quite boring. The campaign is like any other campaign. You win races and you climb up into better and faster cars. The problem is, for the first several hours, you're basically driving the same car on the same tracks. This gets tedious especially since some events require you to complete the same track twice.CONCLUSIONWith games like Gran Turismo 6, Forza 5, F1 2013, and Shift 2 out, it's hard to recommend this game content-wise. The gameplay however is not lacking although it may feel dull at times. The conclusion? This game feels rushed and Codemasters should have spent more time on it.

content:
Posted: July 1, 2014
												The GRID series of games from Codemasters is probably one of favourite franchises out there and I've been following them for quite a while, since TOCA 3 infact.Where as GRID 2 appealed more to the arcade driver with less emphasis on realism. GRID Autosport is going back to its roots and feels much more like a simulator as seen in the TOCA series of games and GRID 1 ( if you guys have been following the series for that long, you will know what I mean ). The driving in this game definately appeals more to hardcore "Sim" racer ( by bringing back cockpit view among other things ) and this game definately rewards you for that by giving you XP bonuses for driving a clean race without collisions.Right off the bat, the game looks graphically similar to GRID 2 but there are noticeable improvements in car textures ( Free DLC to update car livery textures to 4k res ), lighting and shadows. Multiplayer is quite fun with you having to work your way up from the bottom. Each car you own in Multiplayer has its own milage, so the higher the milage the more the car will cost to maintain. 12 players lined up on the ( AI can be used to fill in the blanks ) all racing to the finish line. This is a blast when playing with friends.To sum up, this game is made by petrolheads for petrolheads and that's why I enjoy it.

content:
Posted: December 30, 2014
												Almost as large of a disappointment as Dirt 3. I was lucky to get the game off♥♥♥♥♥for 10 bucks but that does not fix glaring problems I encountered in the first 3 hours of playing this game. First off loading into the game, I setup my G27 and enter career mode. My steering wheel has zero force feedback going to it. Why would this be turned off in a racing game? Even after 30 minutes of tinkering I got a setup that was atleast driveable but sill felt disconnected After racing for a bit I only got further disappointed, handling is bleh, braking far too sharp and the worse part of this game, the AI. The AI is literally pants on head ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ or overly aggressive, with any contact resulting in bouncing off of them or you spinning out. Interior view has everything from the dashboard back looking like a camera lense with vaseline on it. No idea if the high res texture pack fixes it but I refuse to download a 3GB "patch" for something that should have never been left like that in a title such as GRID.The good, I really do like the option of having a second monitor display race information in a broadcasting layout. Would have loved it even more to pick what items to have up on the second monitor but I am not complaining there. I also like the benchmarking ability to better optimize your ingame graphical settings. Past that it is just another mediocre racing game that does nothing new nor does anything well.

number of helpful: 4 of 8 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 7, 2014
												This Review is more of a First Impressions to be honest. The Only reason I got this game was because they announced VR support and fully support the Oculus Rift DK2.A massive tip for those that want to run the game in vr is to get OBS.OBS acts as a way to be able to view the game mirrored to a monitor via the preview option. This enables you to have full visibility of the menu as the menu's do not currently render in VR (This is understandable as they were never meant for it)Initially I was underwhelmed with the game after I managed to get it running,The VR is actually done very well with full positional tracking enabled realistic 3d environments with a cockpit view. The cockpit feels like an after thought though. It is too basic and other games do a far better job with interiors. The mirrors are not usable because they are very dark to the point where you can not see anything other than the sky reflecting for some reason? The recent patch does add a rear view mirror though which is great but I would love to be able to use the side mirrors to block overtakes and judge where the competion is.I play full manual with the Logitech G27 which is fully supported. BUT THERE IS NO OPTION FOR FORCE FEEDBACK only vibration... BUT... you can download Force feedback files from GRID 2!! UNOFFICALLY then overwrite and BOOM full force feedback enabled and this is a game changer!!This brings the game to life and actually lets you feel the car like you should. These files should have been implemented WITH the game though and this is a serious issue that many will not be able to overcome. This will probably mean that I cant go online in GRID because of modified game files.....The single player game is such a challenge though that even on the lowest setting you will be in for a fight! The racing feels exciting and reminds me of aggressive touring the game is very exciting when you are trading paint in the pack hustling and fighting for positions.There is massive room for improvements to be made. I would still 100% recommend this game to anyone with an Oculus Rift and will be putting a lot of time in and do not regret the purchase.Hope this helps

content:
Posted: July 4, 2014
												I don't like to write reviews for a game if I have less than 4 hours of gameplay, but I'll do it anyway. (106 minutes when writing this).If you're looking for a racing sim: this is the wrong game for you. If you're looking for a fun arcade racing game: you could try this game, but Need for Speed or Grid 2 would be recommended if you're an arcade racer. This game is in the middle of being a racing sim and being an arcade game.You have to be able to control a fast racing car on track to play this game, but you don't need to driver super realistic. Sliding a bit trough corners are OK, but you have to fight cars in this game more than in Grid 2. I, my self, am a fan of the racing sim games, those were you have to hit braking points and apexes about perfect to have a chance, where sliding trough corners isn't the fastest way to finish. For me this game is fun to play, but not a game that satifies my racing sim needs. This game is just for fun in my opinion, not a game where you try your hardest.AI may not be perfect, they love to drive into you hard or gentle, enough to make you annoyed at some times. ALWAYS be careful when overtaking or defending. The game still is fun though, but again: just for fun, not a game for the hardcore sim racers.The game runs very nicely on my computer, with high graphic setting. Average FPS on a decent gaming PC with high graphics can be between 45 and 50 FPS, so its fine.I would recommend this game, but remember: not a sim racing game for those of you who want that. Don't expect that. Handling is much better than arcade games though, so its not too unrealistic.

content:
Posted: July 7, 2014
												GRID Autosport is the third game released under the GRID franchise from Codemasters. If you were a fan of the original GRID release but not GRID 2, you'll be pleasantly suprised by Codemasters sudden switch back to the more 'Simulation' side of the franchise over the arcade style of GRID 2. It is no way a competitor to serious sims like rFactor or Assetto Corsa. But it is a much more serious take on driving over what was done in GRID 2. The first person drivers view is back, after so many PC gamers questioned Codemasters decision to remove it in GRID 2. This time around they have not as many racing disciplines as the original GRID, instead focusing on 5 specific which are: Touring, Open Wheel, Endurance, Tuner and Street.While I definitely will miss events like Touge and Destruction derby. I am very pleased by the move back towards the experiance I had in GRID. I loved driving in the game from the drivers view with Track IR, it add's so much to the game that I'd recommend it just on that.

content:
Posted: June 27, 2014
												This is an overhaul of my original review, where I did not recommend it at that point. I wrote it out of pure disappointment and frustration, that I could not get the game working in full screen. Well, the game itself was working but my keyboard and controller didn't respond. In the end the solution was a silly mouseclick after the game had started! At the moment there are more people reporting full screen issues, that are bypassable. However, CM should really fix this.I played the game for a good five hours now and I can give my first impressions of it. First of all, the thums down has changed to a thumbs up. I'm really enjoying the game so far. Car handling is just what I expected; semi-realistic but not too hardcore. I'm not a professional so I can't judge how realistic they actually are or aren't. There are some 12 year olds out there that can go really in depth on how spot on the physics are or why they just suck :)  For me it's just a really nice simcade. Totally different then Grid 2, wich was a total driftfest, wich got a bit boring in the end. Graphics and sound are really good too. It's not a big improvement over Grid 2 but that game already looked fantastic imo. Graphics options are highly adjustable. The game can run smooth on both high end and not so high end hardware. The whole game focuses on a more realistic approach on motorsport, with more believable contracts, the ability to practice and qualify before the race (thanks you CM!) wich is optional by the way. There's also the option to multiply the race duration in the career mode, wich is really welcome and adds again more realism. Some races are over too soon, with just the standard 3 or 4 laps. The AI is also quite good. On higher difficulty levels they are really competitive. I'm someone who enjoys racing against good AI more then against random people, since AI cars don't try to ram you off the track as soon as the race starts but actually race you. That's why I didn't touch the MP yet. I'm only interested in clean racing against serious players. If you're looking for that too, feel free to add me :)  So these first impressions were all about single player. I did however some online Racenet challenges that are renewed weekly, just like in Grid 2. So all in all a really good game and a massive improvement over Grid 2. If you loved the first Grid but didn't like the second one due to it's arcady physics you should really enjoy this one.

number of helpful: 3 of 6 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 5, 2014
												Bloody good game. I was skeptical at first, but the more I play it, the more well designed I think it is.I read an article that Codemasters designed the game to be a mix between sim and arcade, trying to hit a sweet spot. I think they did a bang up job. The racing is solid. Cars take damage and you can check the condition. When car parts like bumpers and side view mirrors come off, they hit the road and bounce just like they would in real life. The single player is a lot of fun.Now here's some important info. You do level up in the game, and how many points you get is determined by what options you have on that make driving easier. The game takes away bonus point percentage if you are driving automatic instead of stick, if you have the camera view outside of the car instead of in the interior, the difficulty of the bots, if you're using a trail marker, stuff like that. I think that's smart and will cater very well to the hardcore crowd. The AI in this game, is the only thing on my list of complaints. They will slow down to not slam into you, but they will run you off the road and slam you from the side. It's like playing with 12 year old trolls. You can race many types of cars in this game, and they are categorized by 5 disciplines. F1 cars are also included. The amount of cars in this game will have you hooked. Very key in a racing game.How's the online? For one, I don't notice any lag, really. I think the game might have a server system because I've been racing with mostly Americans/Canadians. I am located in Miami, FL, FYI. Also, you can play with your euro buddies as well. I just haven't ended up in matchmaking with any, but I'm sure others probably have. Let me make this clear: YOU CAN ONLY UNLOCK CARS ONLINE. The single player is fun but its just for achievements. You unlock everything in multiplayer. You can play with other people or do the RaceNet challenges to make money and XP. Very important. You can also start car clubs and earn XP for it. You have to go to racenet.codemasters.com to do it. As far as registering an account, you can do that in-game and there's no e-mail verification.To conclude, I will tell you something you don't hear often in this day and age. This game has little to no bugs. I haven't experienced any. It is very fluid and well-designed. After playing this game, I am extremely satisfied with my purchase. I've been recommending it to friends. I say get it. It's not a complete sim and it's not a complete arcade.

content:
Posted: July 9, 2014
												Recommended, recommended, recommended!I'll opt for an 85% rating for Grid Autosport primarily because;* Pack racing is back with softened handling models!  Think more PS1 ToCA and a bit less Grid2.* Awesome selection of circuits/tracks and vehicles.* Multiple racing disciplines catered for (like Grid2) with Touring, Endurance, Street, Drift/Tuner, Open-wheelers.* Wear and damage mechanics fits the gameplay very well.* Vastly improved UI for tuning tweaks between races.* The garage system and XP levelling works very well, with a fairer upgrade system.  Aids longevity.* Streamlined menus and navigation (compared to Grid2 especially.)* Solo career mode is actually engaging this time.  A definate nostalgia nod to the Alain Menu rivalry of PS1 ToCA days.* The visuals and audio are highly optimised throughout for low-ultra PC system specs.* Above all - it's a fun, varied racer with that "i'll just have one more go" factor!Deductions and downsides are;* No text chat (or even spectator mode) that makes waiting around in lobbies for the next race rather dull, and democratic custom cups changes almost impossible.* Region-locked lobby creation is promoting tumbleweed already sadly... - i've only met 4 Americans and 1 Canadian all week [tsk, I fully realise some friends see this as a positive! rotflmao :)) ]* No gamepad/joystick calibration options contrary to supported wheels.* Disfunctional team radio feature (and absent from MP.)* No mirrors (or acceptable interiors for PC due to PS3/Xbox limitations) and fixed 90' headlook views.Upshot;* Touring with twelve car Mr Bean-esque pack racing in Minis around Brands Hatch is an arcade game exclusive and hilarious!  Truely it's a sight to behold, so come and join in folks.* Why sit there reading this Grid Autosport review when you could be on track having fun?

content:
Posted: August 30, 2014
												GRID Autosport and Assetto Corsa brings us PC gamers closer to that Forza Motorsport and Gran Turismo level of racing. This is my review of GRID Autosport in the time that I've played it and I hope you enjoy reading it.Gameplay:GRID Autosport provides a fun environment plus intense racing to give you the perfect balance between Simulation and Arcade.The driving model is very good as it's not too challenging but at the same time you can't underestimate it or else you'll be put into a wall.There are 5 disciplines in this game: Tuner, Street, Open Wheel, Endurance, and Touring.These 5 different disciplines all bring a unique selection of cars and unique gameplay.This all works very well in making a fun yet challenging game that can give Forza Motorsport and Gran Turismo fans such as myself the same level of entertainment except on the PC platform.Codemasters have made a huge improvement to their racing franchises (since the fall of quality aka. DiRT Showdown) by listening to the community and what they want in a racing game.GRID 2 had a extremely arcade like driving model and lacked many features including interior camera, since then they've taken all the feedback and produced this great game.AI is extremely well done, they know what they're doing (most of the time) and have proven to be a formiddable opponent at higher AI difficulties.Also there are many many camera angles to suit anybody's preference. Story:This game features quite a flexible campaign to become the best at all 5 disciplines and become the GRID Champion.It's pretty much the same as Forza in which you choose a series to do and then you do it.GRID makes this concept more enjoyable by making you pick what team you'd like to race for the series and that team has objectives to complete during that season and certain vehicles picked out for you. You also get a teammate in that series (Beware, They're pretty damn bad) which you control their aggression through 5 stages.Defend Position, Hold Position, Balanced, Push Position, Attack PositionThis makes for very dynamic gameplay as you also have to focus on another AI's aggresion of the race and estimate their stress levels.Each team has a livery for particular vehicles such as: Kicker's Volkswagon Golf Livery. The real joy is in the Multiplayer portion of the game.Multiplayer:In Multiplayer you have to earn money by doing challenges and racing other players in intense races.Normally that's all a Multiplayer is? Yeah but not in this game.The real joy of Multiplayer is managing a garage of vehicles you've purchased and then making custom liveries for them giving a sense of personalisation and pride.The higher the rank the more range of sponsors you can put onto your vehicle.You can also make a Club of friends or strangers that has a custom made livery for all members to use.Cons:This game would be great if only these four things weren't on this portion of the review.         - Interior is poorly textured and blurred. Originally made so people would focus on the track instead of the interior making                         a saddening atmosphere in the vehicle.         - No looking around the vehicle's interior. Another let down but at least 4K users get a great version of the game where               they can see all of the cockpit.         - Blurred out mirrors. The side and rear view mirrors are blurred out and don't actually work at all which is another             saddening aspect of the interior viewing.         - Not many people playing multiplayer.I hope you enjoyed reading this review and I hope this helped make you decide if you'd like to buy it or not.I give this a 9 out of 10

												If you enjoy fast paced racing Games on a team, You well enjoy this game. Grid Autosport has come a long way from grid 1 and 2. It's still that eye candy master piece of stunning HD graphics it has alwas been but has grown into a sophisticated racing sim with real world vehicle handling/physics compard too Grid Two's sloppying push it to the edge racng (Drifting and Power Slidding through every corner). Offline contains 5 different disciplines with multiple tournaments allowing you to level up each type. Online is ok, you can use all the cars and are givin the option to level them up with upgrades as you progress through each disciplines and car level. The only issue i have is each race group is broken down into groups that contain 1 to 4 cars and your only allowed 6 cars to custom, leaving you to a very limited amount of veriety for racing compared to other racering games. 8/10

number of helpful: 4 of 8 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 6, 2014
												I love Autosport, it really does feel and play like the old TOCAs and Grid 1. Combined with tracks that are very fun to race on, like Mount Tremblant, Autosport Raceway and Okutama (which I love trying to take flat out), Autosport is just fun.I have only raced the AI in Street and Open Wheel so far, haven't gone online yet.I love racing the AI, they are tough to pass at the higher difficulties and are quick. They tend to be brick-like and absolutely stable on the track when you collide with them (which you will because they tend to be a bit blind and don't acknoledge your car at times). You will spin and they will not. It's a great thing that you can't just shove them out of the way, however it does feel one-sided because of how easy your car gets shoved out of the way.The career mode is nice but does not hold a candle to the career mode in GRID. In Autosport you only sign contracts to drive with other teams, with minimal ability to change the car's handling/sponsors/liveries. You don't have that team building you had in GRID, so you can't hire a teammate, upgrade your car, change sponsors for more XP, etc. In the different disciplines you do tend to race on the same tracks over and over, just with different configurations, which also makes career feel a bit thin. I read that sometimes you get stuck with different events in career that do not align with the path you chosen, meaning that if you choose to do street you get stuck with a drift event. I'm not sure if I will like that, however I haven't come across it yet.While racing, depending on your settings, you gain XP which is used to unlock higher disciplines. Going without assists, locking your view to cockpit (why would you do that, the cockpits are terrible), and higher difficulties = higher XP gained and faster career progression. You can eventually unlock a GRID league, which is all 5 disciplines combined.Graphically, the game seems really optimised, I have 50+ fps on a rig with a GTX 580 on ultra settings. It is pretty nice looking, with nice details on the cars (not project cars good). CM did a great job making the racing environment seem alive, with announcers announcing incidents, the crowd cheering, helicopters and other outside events making the tracks seem 'alive'. The cockpits are terrible however, they were just put there to appease those who complained about them missing in GRID 2. They are blurry, the mirrors are useless, and it is a bit distracting for me to drive using that view.Need to try out online before I give my final verdict, but I do really love the game because of the racing. The racing is pure fun, the packaging can use a little more work.Pros:The racing AI is tough at the higher difficultiesCan choose what path in career to take (in a way)Lots of tracks and cars to useCons:Career mode is a bit thinThe AI are tanks and blindCockpits are terrible

number of helpful: 3 of 6 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: September 7, 2014
												I've only just bought this game. I didn't like the original Grid so I skipped Grid 2 but a friend of mine toldme to check out autosport. Turn off all your assists and set the difficulty to your skill level and the racing is absolutely intense. The AI are smart and won't just smash into you like in other games (Forza). The crash physics (as always in codemasters games) are fantastic. The handling may feel a bit arcade-like but it is much more realistic than most other racing games on the PC barring actual simulators. The car selection feels a nit short because I'm used to Gran Turismo and Forza but it is an interesting mix and the class system is done pretty decently. I have not yet tried online play but from a single-player standpoint, I'm have a great ride.

number of helpful: 4 of 8 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 6, 2014
												Another Grid game, I have played all the Grid and Dirt games. Pro's: Nice graphics if your pc can handle them. Good controls for pc controllers and the xbox 360 pc controller does very well. The Logitech G27 works well but you might need to do some tweaking. For hardcore racers you will know a lot of the tracks from other racing games. Sound is awesome again in my opinion. There are day races and even some night time races as well. A ton of cars to choose from! Multiplayer runs nice and smooth and i have come across a lot of clean drivers.Cons: Single player cars DO NOT carry over to multiplayer.. Some people have mic issues with massive echoing etc. People can be easily voted out of rooms if they are bad drivers. Sometimes people that win all the time are also booted which i don't agree with. Starting out in multiplayer can be pretty confusing and you have limited garage room.The game is overall good and would recommend this game for fans of the series and racing!

content:
Posted: November 24, 2014
												PROS: - Cars look awesome from the outside, Tracks and locales are breathtaking when graphics are turned up. - Challenging in a way that makes you want to get better. Not easy, but gratifying when you master turns.- I personally, in real life, drive a recent model Ford Focus, and the control of the Focus ST in the game is as i would expect when driving the ST version of my car. If i made it a point to negotiate turns as i would in real life, it worked out better. CONS: - HOWEVER (on the last point) the ST is known for it's ludicrous cornering ability, and i had to upgrade the car and Soften the front suspenstion/stiffen the rear suspension to get the most realistic driving experience one should expect from the ST. I could be biased but the car is an autocross machine and handles perfectly well just as stock. - car interiors ARE A JOKE. I only play racing games in first person in-car view so as to fully immerse myself in the experience. i hate to compare this to Need for Speed, but if you look at Shift, the interiors, even for the low-end/old drifter cars, are immaculately rendered, and you can look around. in Grid, looking left or right blinks the screen left or right to an un-interior generic side view, giving me no frame of reference because my driver didn't turn his head. In addition, on graphical settings where the cockpit isn't blurred, the instrumentation is blocky and disgusting. at night, no dashboard or other interior lights are visible. Again, i drive a focus, and although the shape of the top of the dashboard is correct (even reflecting *almost* as i would expect when the sun hits it, i'm sorry but at night that console needs to be LIT. So yeah, Codemasters, MASSIVE missed opportunity with the car interior. i can't bring myself to look left or right because what i get is a generic blank view of what's on the left or right because my driver doesn't turn his head like NFS Shift so i have no frame of reference, and the worst part is it's just as well because what IS rendered of the interior of the car is a half♥♥♥♥♥♥♥POS anyway in both texture and polygon terms. Bad bad bad car interior. That's it, every other part of the game is straight up FUN, with beautifully rendered and presented cars on beautiful tracks and HOLY♥♥♥♥♥♥I'M DRIVING IN PARIS THIS IS SO COOL and the driving is awesomely gratifying in just the right realistic correct way that one can get better at before they know it. Car interiors are disgustingly, DISGUSTINGLY disappointing though. Need for Speed: Shift, i'm looking at the exact interior of a Lamborghini Reventon from radio to seat stitching to AC vents. Grid, i'm looking at something a 6 year old made using Duplo bricks. [ ]PS: the yellow paint is on the stock ST is just the right hue, and it is indeed shiny but not as much as is presented in the game where it looks as glossy as a trombone. The real Tangerine Yellow ST is almost almost flat with a slight metallic shine to it. But don't worry, NFS: Most Wanted got it wrong too. Thanks for the great game!!!! :)

number of helpful: 1 of 2 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: August 21, 2014
												TL;DR - This is a mostly neutral-to-positive review. While i find it hard to reccomend at full price, i'd still do so.Okay, first things first, what have you guys done to the name of this game? While it's safe to say the GRID series isn't nearly as closely related to the toca race driver series as it used to be, simply naming the 3rd iteration GRID Autosport sounds off to me. Having to explain to people which GRID title i'm referring to is time i could've spent talking about your title instead.I have no idea what to say about the carreer mode at this point, so far, i'm under the impression Team Ravenwest is the hot stuff in town, and i'm not having any of it. I'm far too busy fighting it out with the track and the people right in front or behind me. Atleast they've let me play around with whatever discipline i felt like doing without forcing me to do something else for a change of pace just yet.The handling and physics are pretty similar to GRID2, and while i miss RD:GRID's wacky instant handbrake drifts, i can sorta understand why they went with a slightly less agile approach. However, with every iteration of GRID, the CPU controlled cars seem more agressive and heavy. While i understand driving people off the track to gain the lead has always been a bit of a problem in racing games, CPU Opponents shoulden't be able to effortlessly get me into a wreck just because they don't agree with my driving line.From a technical standpoint, there's a few graphical glitches when using AMD's CrossfireX, sometimes the grass flickers, but seeing how other games just completely fall flat in this regard i can look past it, since the performance scaling is all right. It doesn't change a whole lot, since even at 1440p, maxing out the settings leaves more than enough headroom to comfortable run this maxed out ( safe from some intel only settings, thanks). While the shaders and effects stepped up quite a bit from GRID2, the environments and roads seem left behind on most tracks, leaving you with an uninspired and uninteresting landscape at times. I have yet to see some of the tracks for other disciplines ( i have mostly seen the circuit-esque tracks at the point of writing), so take this with a grain of salt.

												Maybe my problem is that I was expecting more of a racing sim and not a flashy arcade style game. It has racing sim elements with the difficulty settings, similar to Forza. The vehicle customization is terrible and annoying since it's based on sponser difficulty level. They spent too much time making the game look nice instead of having actual content and a race system that actually works. You are berrated when you finish a season in 1st place but told you did an excelent job when you don't. They made this game with funding from being coporate shills to get all the sponsers and go figure..they are mostly computer and tech based companies. Drifting is completely unrealisticendurance races are time/distance basedeverything else is just mundane and basicno/little vehicle customizationwhy is there even an upgrades UI? why did they even bother if you can't buy more parts for your caryou can't choose what to drive, its all based on the sponsor you chooseIf you are looking for a racing sim look elsewhere

content:
Posted: September 1, 2014
												Welcome to the autosport, motherfuker.Quick sidenote: I pre-ordered quite a while ago and when it came out I generally forgot about it, so got to play it for the first time like three weeks ago, or so.I haven't played previous GRID's, so, yeah, that kinda sucks.Anyway, from the very beginning we see an awesomely made trailer, the graphics appeared to be so good that I haven't figured out at first whether it was real footage or animation. The graphics throughout the whole game is really high, and, as appeared, not too demanding: with not the toppest graphics card (AMD Radeon 7800), it easily pulled the ultra settings. The crashing cars, the dust, the rain, everything looks just so good.I didn't really care for the soundtrack, the ambient music was so-so, but I usually would play something else, apart from the game, the car sounds and stuff...I guess they're realistic? I've never been to any race in real life to say for sure but it sounded quite decent at least for me. The lady voice that goes with you through all the menu might irritate you after several tens of hours, but you anyway will be able to talk to your...team dude who tells you stuff about whether your car broke or not, your rival position and so on, I don't honestly know how he is called.I liked the control system, it was a bit difficult at first to keep in mind everything but I just got used to itThe whole game is kinda cool, ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥a seasons in with difference types of racing, which looks quite professional too. I haven't really played multiplayer, so I can't judge itOverall, yeah, I enjoyed this game, the time for this was take (4 years) and in the end we get a really neat product which you can play for quite a long while.8.9/10

number of helpful: 4 of 9 people (44%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 23, 2016
												I will have to make a disclaimer upfront that I love race simulators (as at time of review, I have clocked 188 hours in Assetto Corsa), so my review of this might be biased since I would prefer realism and physics as high enjoyment factors, which of course GRID Autosport would be a huge disappointment. Says the dev before the release of this game: "GRID Autosport would be more sim than arcade". I am sorry, sim my♥♥♥♥♥ All the cars turn with rubber band effect; it turns and just when you thought you turned enough and starts to return the steering to neutral, the car has that tendency to swing back about 20-30% of the turning you attempted as if you are turning against a rubber band. Like seriously? No cars behave like this.Let me qualify myself. I race racing karts, played enough simulators and drove enough cars to know that cars don't behave like this. At this rate, even Initial D and Wangan Midnight would be a better game than GRID Autosport. Luckily for me, I bought this from the 2nd tier of Humble Bundle; was considering the 3rd tier that includes the season pass, all GRID 2 DLCs, and Dirt 3 Complete edition, but seeing how horrible the physics is (it is actually worse than and more unpredictable than Initial D or Wangan Midnight), I have decided against upgrading my Humble Bundle package. Now, if only Humble Bundle accepts refunds.(TL;DR) In conclusion, if you are someone like me who only enjoys realistic physics and played Assetto Corsa, then don't even touch this with a 20-foot long pole. You might consider this if you haven't touched Assetto Corsa (not sure about other sims because imho, AC seems to be the best out there and I have tried almost every other sims) before. On the other hand, if you like arcadey racing games that makes you feel like "fast and furious", you might want to consider this only when there is a steep discount. Otherwise, may I direct you to Initial D or Wangan Midnight games?EDIT: I should also mention that I turned off all assists in this game, so that should be as raw as how a real car should behave. Perhaps it might have been better with assists but assists should be unnecessary with decent driving skills. I also play with no assists in Assetto Corsa but cars in Assetto Corsa have more "grip" and predictability, just like how you would have expected if you actually race in real life, which of course this game is completely devoid of. Complete failure even as an arcade game, made worse with claims of "more sim than arcade"; bullcrap, this is below arcade racing game category with that rubber-band turning effect.

number of helpful: 3 of 7 people (43%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 7, 2016
												It’s all about the teams, the rivals and the race in an intense new world of professional motorsport. Racing alongside a teammate, you must overcome key rivals and satisfy team sponsors in ferocious races where every pass and position counts. In a huge career, specialise in your favourite racing discipline or conquer them all feel the aggression of the pack in Touring Cars, manage tyre wear and race into the night in Endurance events, race Open-Wheel cars with precision, show car control in Tuner events and react on the fly in Street races. Each unique category features series dedicated to different classes, including Touring Cars, Hypercars, Endurance GT Cars, Prototypes, Single-Seaters, Super Modified vehicles, Drift cars and many more. Bursting with content, GRID Autosport features over 100 routes across 22 incredible locations and the world’s most exciting contemporary and classic high-performance racing cars to collect, tune and upgrade. Development has been driven by Community feedback to include the return of in-car view, authentic handling and multiplayer racing powered by RaceNet to deliver new challenges every week, plus all-new Racing Clubs for online team competition. Party modes, Demolition Derby and competitive split-screen modes complement the game’s extensive career mode and expansive core online game

number of helpful: 3 of 7 people (43%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 30, 2015
												Nothing's really changed since Grid 2. The same tracks, the same cars, the same computer-generated engine sounds and the same bad texture work and graphics masked by a lot of FX.Everything is as unrealistic as ever - (1) the aligning of wheels has to go out of place in order for everything else to break, and it's always the front left side, no matter where you hit the car, (2) AI controlled drivers and their vehicles are basically unaffected by the laws of physics - they regain speed faster once they exit turns, cannot be spinned out, yet they can spin out you, as if their cars weigh a lot more than yours yet can retain a speed impossible for such an object, and generally move faster even at max speeds.They've taken a lot of what made Grid 2 any good like ability to use the car of players choosing and replaced it with less relevant content like teammates and some sort of inferior career mode.And you, for some reason, have to drive cars with their steering wheels on the rights side (even BMWs). At least there's a  cockpit view now.Can't recommend in the light of a lot more superior games.

number of helpful: 2 of 5 people (40%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 7, 2014
												Let's be clear : I'm a fan of Codies, I think they are doing a great job usually. When Grid came out, it was, and still is, the game to have ; The career solo was great, handling was correct and the game was really fun to play in multi.Last year, they realeased probably the worst handling car game they've ever made. It was like driving on butter all the way. The multi was so terrible that I'm still wondering "Why did they put a derby mode later on, because there's already that everywhere...?".This year, it's the turn to Grid Autosport. I was really confused ; Already ? One year only ?But they said they have listened to us, and it will be THE game that we want.Well, the handling is great ; Not quite as good as Grid, it's more like between Grid 1 & 2. But yeah, that's more pleasing to drive.Lot of routes and destinations, this is quite enjoyable, even if all the tracks from Grid 2 are there and for several races I can see downgraded graphics there and there. But ok, it's not a next gen (current gen now) game, so I guess it's not a problem.Modeling of interior cam is back ! AND blury as hell. Like if you're driving completly wasted, you'll probably see the car like that.... A HUGE disappoitment on that, Grid 1 had those, and that was really cool !Multi is hell on earth, again... Between cheaters, stock cars and players who deliberatly run into you... because they're driving the wrong way to annoy you.... Well, this is really awfull.Please Codies, fix that ; I shouldn't be bothered by cheaters when I'm playing a game in multi on Steam....And finaly, my biggest disappoitment : Career solo.Multi is terrible, ok, so let's take my career and drive for me : Well, nuh hu.The career is, in big sum up : You are a driver, sponsors will hire you to drive a certain amount of races, which rewards you with XP.That's it.Come on Codies, where is the real career mode ? I want to have my garage, pay for my cars, CHOOSE MY CAR FOR A CERTAIN RACE ; Here, we have 2 choices from 2 sponsors. And you're stuck with 1 to 4 cars, and the choice is not really yours.The partner is a real joke, the comments are not really usefull, and despite all the energy put on this, it's really an annoying career mode. You drive for one sponsor, you're done, next.There's no challenge whith points or money earned, no big final like "Le mans" in Grid, no car customisation in solo, nothing.So my review is simple :If you want multi and you're willing to taste hell on the roads : this game is for you.If you want a solid solo career, I'd pass...If you want some fun, i'd wait for a discounted price.Let's prey the 4 will be THE ONE (even if it'll surely not be....)

number of helpful: 2 of 5 people (40%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 30, 2014
												This game is great; they have improved on almost every aspect of Grid 2 and gone back to the games roots. I played Race driver Grid for about 200 hours when it first came out, I loved every moment of it! I found that Grid 2, while I still really liked the game it still fell short of my expectations.Well, Grid Autosport is everything I could have expected and more from a racing game! The cars feel realistic, the sound is amazing and the graphics are stunning! As for the gameplay; I would not go as far as to say this game is a racing simulator but I am not sure that is the point of Grid. Grid 2 had a very arcady feel to it; sliding around corners, bashing into people, etc; Autosport however will punish you severely for doing those kinds of things, the damage system is relentless and if you do not take the racing line or brake properly you will lose valuable seconds off your laptime through spin outs or driving off the track!The multiplayer is really entertaining; in fact I prefer it to the single player mode. You have access to every car from the get go, however they are "Loan" cars, so you cannot upgrade them and they typically do not perform quite as well as Brand new cars (due to their condition rating). This adds a realistic feel to the game and also inspires you to buy your own cars and tune them properly! Tuning is another important feature of this game, once you have purchased your first car and begin to race with it you will begin to unlock upgrades and tuning options to make the car perform exactly how you want it to! I found this really helps me set my cars up based on my driving style.Earning money can be tough in Grid Autosport multiplayer, however that is the point! If you crash your car or the loan car you will need to pay for repairs, this encourages you to drive sensibly, take the racing line and brake properly ( No more e-brake!) the cleaner you race, the more money you get and the closer you will get to owning your own beautiful motor car!If you liked Race driver Grid then you will love Autosport!Pros-Beautiful Graphics-Fun and Realistic gameplay-Amazing sound-Endless car tuning possibilitiesCons- Voice chat and some connection issues online- Long loading timesOverall 4.5/5

content:
Posted: June 27, 2014
												Got the game after a lengthy hiatus from any sort of serious racing game since my wheel and pedal setup playing GT on PS & PS2. I'd played some pretty arcady racers on various sources including PC but honestly wanted that legit racing feel without the tediousness of some of the more intense sim racers.One thing to point out, if you're used to arcade racing games, get ready to spin out over and over. However, you should have faith. I'm playing on a 360 controller for Windows on 8.1 and setting the difficulty to the base "Easy" setting is giant help. It gives you the full racing line by default which shows you not only the best line on the track but also, via color changing as indication, shows you relatively how fast you need to be going for certain portions of the track. This really comes in handy when getting used to the braking in turns. This game is not a game you can simply swing your back end around the corners in. Once you begin to get the hang of it though, the whole thing becomes satisfying and rewarding. I like the way the different racing specialties are set up in the career mode. It allows you to choose from all but the GRID Autosport Series which is apparently reserved for when you've mastered all the others. As of right now, I've played through a season in both the Touring and Street series'. The Street series seems like a great place to start because the speeds don't get too much above 100mph and the cars handle well. I have yet to play any multiplayer so I will refrain from commenting on it until I get the chance to join in.VERDICT: Great game so far.

number of helpful: 2 of 5 people (40%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 2, 2014
												GRID Autosport feels like what GRID 2 was supposed to be. It's sort of a split between 1 and 2.For starters, you're back to the fairly open method of choosing races that was in GRID 1. You get a little board of different types of disciplines (Touring, Endurance, Open Wheel, Tuner, Street) and you can choose any of them right off the bat to dig into. They each come with different events you can sign up for, and each race has a few different sponsors you can race for, for differing amounts of XP based on how well you follow their requests. Generally, what you see is what you get in regards to what types of races you do. Touring is usually just touring car races, fast paced pack racing with you and 15 other racers. Endurance is powerful supercars that you race for 8 minutes or so. You have to watch your tire wear in this discipline, so lighter braking and safer turning. I haven't had any issue with my tires exploding on me yet (I play on the Medium difficulty) but they do tend to get close. Open Wheel is small cars that are, as you'd expect, open wheeled. So far it's been mostly Formula 3, but I haven't progressed too far in that discipline to say for sure if it'll become more. This discipline is also incredibly fun, which is a nice change from the stressful races that Open Wheel brought along in GRID 1. Tuner is light weight and small race cars and American muscle cars, which seem to be usually time attack (post the best time) races. Street is more along the lines of what you got in GRID 2 in the early tiers. There's a lot of hatchbacks and muscle cars in pack races. In addition to the above, there's a "GRID Championship" that unlocks after you get level 3, 6 and 9 in each of the disciplines. The GRID Championship is just all the other disciplines crammed in one event series, and gives you more experience to level the disciplines. There are also small "cup" events in some of the disciplines that'll pop up and break up the rest of your racing. They're small events of a few races, and the best is definitely Drift. The AI is fairly typical of a racing game. They'll still follow their line regardless of how much you're in the way. It becomes especially upsetting when they hit you, and you go spinning off the road, while their car seems to be made of dark matter. Thankfully, they don't seem to be broken when they work for Ravenwest anymore. Gone are the days of watching those black and grey cars that you know you outpower speed off and leave you in the dust.Speaking of, you don't seem to be able to have your own team anymore. You work exclusively for the highest bidder, and your codriver is whoever the team wants to stick with you. Most of the time, they're useless. You do have the ability to tell your codriver what to do, to an extent. You can tell them to defend/hold/drive normally/push/attack. Attack seems to be the only way to see them gain any positions, though, and I so rarely have them in a good place that I ask them to hold or defend, though the few times I have they lost their good position and I had to tell them to attack anyway.The handling feels a whole lot better than it did in 2. The cars have some weight to them, and the tires don't want to squeel across the road with every turn (with basic assists left on). Not being able to drift around every turn and win by massive amounts of time anymore took some getting used to, but it's wonderful. I plan on turning off all the rest of the driver assists soon to see how it feels without them.The feeling of speed seems a bit inconsistent, at least to me. Cars in Tuner and Muscle classes feel like they move really slow, despite the HUD telling me I'm going at 100mph. Then I jump in a Touring car and feel like I'm blasting along, but only doing 80. It might just be the way they handle, but it feels fairly odd. It looks good, for the most part. The tracks and the cars are well rendered. The cars have a good shine to them, the liveries look good. The damage model on them is pretty weak, though it is a step above a lot of other racers. Cars still split apart by the seams like in GRID 2, so you'll get that weird piece of body flapping like a bit of loose skin. If you tap a car in front of you going into a turn, you will get scrapes all up and down the hood, regardless of how hard you hit. Does the same on the sides of your car, and presumably on your rear. It's not really a big issue, and I understand why it was done, but it bothers me a little. The backgrounds are, as is typical of racing games, weak. Low res, 2D trees that sparcely populate ugly, jagged hills. People in the stands are straight out of an RPG on the PS2. Perhaps the biggest issue as far as visuals, is the car interiors. Maybe I looked at it wrong, but it seemed like the reintroduction of cockpit view was a big deal for this game, and they are absolutely ugly. You don't get any movement on anything but the wheel, which becomes especially noticable when you're driving stuff like the open wheel vehicles and see the speedo screen make no effort to do anything. And considering this was stuff that was in DiRT 3, it's fairly shocking.I like the game. It's got a good simcade feel that leans a bit more on the sim than the arcade, it looks good, and it plays fun. But it still feels like a step back from GRID 1. It's a step forward from 2, for sure, but there's still that gap.

content:
Posted: June 27, 2014
												7.5/10 Fair perspective. 9.5/10 Personally.It's an arcade/sim which does lean much more toward sim than arcade and is the most realistic grid game to date, the only negatives to this game are the racenet website, which you have to use to join, modify or create clubs and the cockpit view while gets the job done and still gives you that immersive feeling, really could have done with a bit more attention.The online experience is great, smooth gameplay even with players from all around the globe racing together. Great voice chat and mostly grown up drivers. There is a system that punishes players for the amount of impacts they have been in or caused which is proving to help players race more clean.As for the sim elements of the game, the cars do all have a unique weight and balance feel to them and behave differently under varying circumstances. You have to use your brakes to be competitive in this game and to set the fastest pace. Accelerating at the wrong times or under heavy cornering will produce understeer or oversteer depending on traction, this will throw you off of the racing line or apex which causes you to have to overcorrect the next corner thus, slowing you down and pushing the car to it's physical limitations to stay on the track.Underrated game in my opinion, it's a shame it's reputation was tarnished from Grid 2 and people aren't giving it a go, or it could have been one of the biggest racers to hit consoles and PC. I hope it eventually gets the credit it deserves. Well done Codemasters, I was skeptical but it has been money well spent.

number of helpful: 2 of 5 people (40%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: October 1, 2014
												If you want a proper racing simulator buy Gran Turismo 2 for PS1 and enjoy and don't touch this crap even with a mile long stick.Gran Turismo will have more vehicles, REAL endurance races (instead of drive around 4 minutes), a way better customization and tuning abilities (more later) probably more tracks, better soundtrack, better voice acting (i.e. silence which is better than a phone-sex-line-granny-trying-to-be-sexy "Welcome back John" every time you open the game), better driving mechanics (more later), pit stops etc. etc.Once again Codemasters make it look like a nice game but after a while you'd give away your aunt if you could just remove it from existence.Gameplay:Mechanics are something inbetween Grid 1 and 2, meaning you won't be powersliding (i.e. slowing down) all the time but anyway you'll be doing that quite a bit. I can somehow deal with it when driving a street or touring cars but FFS I DID NOT START A FORMULA SEASON JUST TO DRIFT AROUND. The open wheel cars have just the same amount of grip with a little bit lower centre of weight and more power so they'll slide just as much as your Ford Mustang or Nissan Silvia but they may be recovered from it a bit more easily. Fun for a while or for arcade racers but not a part of a "simulator".If using a keyboard to drive you need to have traction control on and thus (I suspect it's due to it) all other drivers are faster than you in the start.If you try to ram the opponents you end up eating mud yourself every time because they're like moving brick walls on rails. They don't give a SH** about you and your pushes if you are not in with a total kamikaze, also you have a great chance to end up spinning out every time you hit someone.The penalty system for cutting corners is complete utter bullcrap. In a same circuit you could drive 100 meters on grass and it doesn't do anything but in the next corner when you hit the kerb a bit too hard and touch the grass you'll be slowed down for something like 7 FÜGing seconds. The AI doesn't get penaltied and happily push you out of the track if you're too close so enjoy!Tuning:No.Depending on how far have you played in the career you'll have zero to a little possibilities to fine tune your vehicle. The changes are the exact same as in Dirt 3 but in Grid you may only have two options for each, 0 or 100%, depending on your team. This pretty much renders the tuning useless because unless you're looking for more sliding you aren't doing a thing with a possibility to set 100% of your braking power to rear or front tires.I also noticed that either something is terribly wrong with the open wheel cars or the game has differential lock tuning inverted, locked diff should make you slide even more but in the game open diff causes it.If you can still remember the fine tuning in GT2, I can tell you it was real high-tech. Don't even dream about something like that.Vehicles:All same group (or class) vehicles are basically the same to make them even. When you have two team offers the XP is the only thing you need to check, your team mate will always suck and the car is just a moving image with exactly the same abilities as the other one.There are something like 5 different cars in each class (except the formulas which have 1 or something) so basically you have a few to choose from but it's nothing like the hundred cars in Gran Turismos.Gamemodes:Along the basic races there are some other modes such as time attack (or something) where you have X laps to score the fastest laptime (so it's basically a qualifying but called race) endurance and drifting.Drifting was surprisingly pleasant and pretty cool but the same mechanics (meaning same controls but -100% grip) were seen in Need For Speed something like 10 years ago. It's also ridiculously easy, within a lap you can score 1,5 million points and AI scores 500-800k.Endurance races are about driving the circuit for X minutes and your tires will wear out. In addition to the "normal sliding" which is rather heavy you cannot brake or turn softly with a keyboard so you'll eat up your tires pretty quickly but it's fun enough. No pitstops though, would have been cool.Multiplayer is... well, online multiplayer. The lobby is plagued with an automatic voice chat which you have to switch off every time if you don't want to use it.Codemasters have a ghost car mechanic which makes everyone ghost cars when in a corner to avoid collisions and pushing but it's not working very well as it makes you visible when you're not braking heavily and thus you're again open for hits which means there will be hits just like there wasn't any ghost thing at all.Overall:I have really mixed feelings about this. I enjoy arcade racing but this isn't it. I also enjoy simulators but this isn't it either. It's not completely bad and I've had fun moments but it's not anywhere near the addictiveness and fun I had with Gran Turismo 2 when I was a kid. It isn't a best comparison but it's the last good racing simulator I've played.4/10 If you enjoy semi realistic racing and can swallow the crap they'll send you with it, you'll like this. If you're in for a good simulator or action full arcade racing, you won't find either in this one.

												This has the same problems as Race Driver: Grid, at higher difficulties, the AI just cheat.I'm not talking about crazy rubber banding, but they seem to go around high-speed corners and down straights ludicrously fast, even if you're in the same car.The only hope you have of overtaking is to BTCC them in the slow corners, which doesn't feel right in supercars/open wheelers.Also don't even try to play with a wheel. Disappointing.Sure it's a graphical and technical leap from the previous games, but it still sucks where it counts.Stick to modding Race Driver: Grid, at least you don't have to rebind the controls every time...

												First of all I am fun of simulators. Recomend for Arcade funs, not recomended for SIMULATORS FUNS.In many reviews I was reading that TOCA Race Driver 3 (2006) is coming back (TOCA 2 and Race Driver3 2006 where the best sim games what codemasters made - driving phisics. In TOCA RC3 you need to switch on "gravel traps" and other stuff there to get realy good driving modeling, without this is DAMMED ARCADE). In gird I thought that if I will switch off all assists game will be demanding and will have good driving model. IT IS NOT. It is realy arcade, but only ine connection with old TOCARC3 what I can see is big range of car, races eetc.I will bet if dirt rally programmers team would do GIRD Autosport, then it would be much better, because Dirt Rally is quite good not easy game. Where you can feel that you are driving 1,5 ton car not the paper box.AI and race driving tactics are focused not on tactical overtaking and knowledge but on quite brutal driving style, what can confirm for example setups for second team driver (defend-he will push cars from track when somebody will try to overtake, Attack-better not to tell...hell). So game AI are not so smart in smooth nice tactical driving like it was in RC3 or TOCA2, its always better to push somebody out of the track. In old good RC3 you and AI were getting penalities and warnings for cuting the track and agresive drivingClimat:In my opinion from codemasters the best climat was in TOCA 2 and RC3, because to make good lap time you needed to drive 500laps on one trackto learn everything, so during the race time where opponents were siting on your tail you could feel higher blood pressure because you knew that one....only onle mistake will cost of loosing all points. And more over driving model was not easy and on hard mode every cars were siting on bumpers so close to each other, it was very stresful - but this is the climat of closed track racing....I have hope that finaly Codemaster will make good game on Turning Cars Topic and GTRs with good driving morel. I think that after of big succes of Dirt Rally Codemasters has understood that the game can not be easy, more difficult game gives you more satisfaction when you will pass/win something. This is Dirt Rally....now waiting for asphalt racing....because autosport is not for me.

content:
Posted: October 27, 2015
												This is without doubt one of the worst racing games I've played in past few years. It sells itself as a fairly serious racer, but 30 seconds is enough to demonstrate the absolutely terrible floating physics - quite what they are attempting to simulate I don't know - if it's hovercraft then they've got it spot on.I had the XBox version and played it for a few hours, and actually managed to get a small amount of enjoyment out of it until about race 3 or 4 when the moronic AI finally become too much. Restarting a race 20 or 30 time just to try and avoid getting punted off by the oblivious AI as they batter their way around the track finally became too much and instead of smashing my Xbox pad I took out my rage on the disc and snapped it in half. That was a few months ago and even seeing the box on the shelf still makes me angry.Anyway, after some time away from it I thought perhaps I'd give the PC version a go for 2 reasons - 1. I can use a proper wheel and 2. I can get a refund when it inevitably turns out to be terrible. First impressions were not good as it refused to recognize a Driving Force Pro wheel pedals in the default combined layout, and I had to quit and reload 3 times to try and figure out what was up. Setting them to seperate finally got it going.Rather unsuprisingly 14 minutes from first loading the game I requested a refund. 2 laps of the first career mode race were enough to know that the physics are unbearably terrible - the car seems to rotate around a central pivot, which means from bonnet or nose cam the whole world seems to revolve around a point behind you, leading to a really weird feeling of having to steer too early and then let the slidey car sort of catch up. I thought they'd got over all this central-pivot rubbish that seemed to become apparent in the games after Colin McRae Rally 2.0, but apparently not, their physics system is just as hopeless as ever.  Also, for some reason it kept switching from bumper cam back to bonnet cam during gameplay, a bug that I also found happened on the XBox, and of course it always happens right at the worst moments. I assume even QA couldn't bear to play it for more than 2 minutes in one go to spot this obvious howler.I bought DIRT Rally a while back too after reading about just how good a sim it is, and again it soon became clear that while sliding around on dirt hides their terrible physics system to certain degree, once you get on tarmac it's just as bad as it is in this game.I skipped F1 2015 as I was frankly sick of buying the exact same game every year, and I think this is the last straw - any future Codemasters game will not be purchased as every single time I am disappointed.Despite the positive reviews in certain places, this game is completely destroyed by almost all of its competition and IMHO is not deserving of a 5/10 , let along a 9/10 as it appears to have been awarded by some reviewers.

number of helpful: 1 of 3 people (33%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 20, 2015
												I was some what positive of Grid 2 however the driving of the car and the need to drift around corners felt a little strange. Well in this version Grid Autosport that is all changed. The cars now feel like they  have some weight and you need to enter corners in a somewhat controlled manner no longer are you just required to brake and drift magically around a corner. It does require some finess. I have set it to easy and this feels about right for me. No more story line this is all about xp and racing. You do have a slightly dumb team driver and he is terrible and often gets in 13 to 16 place. He was at the second spot and went all the way back to 13 once the race was over. You can give him orders to be more agressive but it seems to make little difference. The track and cars look super detailed. Not sure how accurate they are because I have never driven on them in real life. The difficulties range from super easy to easy. I will be honest I found easy to be normal I cannot imagine what normal or medium would be like. One other reviewer pointed out the fact that the AI gets a boost and that seems to be true. I still feel even with this negative the game is still good. Also be aware the AI gets a little aggressive and can sometimes spin you off the track and that is annoying. Lucky the game has a flashback system in place. So the negatives besides the ones I mentioned. The camera shake started making me ill and I had to tone it way down. Other then that it seems to be a very good driving game.Just a few more details. The endurance races are in my opinion the least fun to drive in. Its just a pain. Its at night and the tires wear down and there is no way to change said tires. Its annoying. Drifting is a pain however you can tune your car to make it able to drift around the track. So thats a plus. Gear dif. set to long and make it grip the corners and it makes it a lot easier to drift.
