Posted: November 24, 2015
												In terms of gameplay, Grid Autosport is fun as it can be. It brings Grid, at least for me, back to the very first game. Which if you didn't know was the best of the three, as well as being my suggestion as a starting point for a new comer. The car physics, accidents, are some of the best i have ever seen in a racing video game. Also, the selection of cars is not that great, however; they are all very different from one another and all cars have something special about them while always being great looking. This game doesn't leave without its bugs though, and there is one masive bug that doesn't sound like its going to be fixed soon. THIS GAME CAN NOT BE PLAYED FULL SCREEN. Yep you read that correctly, this game, for some odd reason, does not want to be played in full screen mode. I have no idea why. The so called "fixes" didn't work for me. I have learned to play windowed mode and since have been having a fair amount of fun in it.Sadly Steam does not let me put a review that goes in between bad and good, so becuase of the no full screen option that sounds like it would be an easy fix for Codemasters, much like Dirt 3 runs perfectly on the same rig of mine, then i can not in my right mind give this game a thumbs up leaving me with this sour taste in my mouth only a few hours after purchasing it.

												The turning mechanics are literally ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥. I don't understand how race cars can turn worse than regular cars, but these folks have managed to simulate that. Luckily, this was just a game that came with humble bundle. Graphics are great, the menu is garbage, I just want to get into a race without having to also plan out a career, but throw that plan out the window because this is more like a racing manager game as well as a meh at best racing game. I've played way better games with actually functional mechanics, and I'm also an automotive mechanic and this is not how vehicles drive. That's fine, this game basically only cost me a dollar for it and all the DLC, otherwise, I would never recommend this game. I'm more let down by the fact that the reviews on top didn't really explain any of this, but like I said, this game was practically free and completely disappointing. I'll give it a try again in the future, but for now it's a definite no recommendation from me.

number of helpful: 1 of 3 people (33%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 25, 2014
												Yes and no.  I would and would not recommend this game.For some reason my hours have not been updated on the time I played this game, and I have played over 10hours of this game so far, so I am confused by eh ho!Lets start simple and then get some detail.Graphics are nice and clean polished out.Audio is car noises, really it is nothing special or amazing it's a car game...Controls are the same as other racers, keyboard and mouse or controller and I chose the controller as it handled better and easier to play.Now the game.  If you like to drive on the inside view like me, then you now can in Grid BUT and it's a big BUT.  There is no detail, literally a blank crappy steering wheel with a literally shape style dash board, there is NO speedo or gauges (How ever it is spelt) or anything just a black shaped canvass to mimic the dashboard.  FAIL!Car control: The cars feel weird like driving into a control at 100Mph and it looks like 30Mph but the engine is screaming.... you turn in at 60 and it slide a little bit but responds soooo quickly unlike any other game.  Literally brake? No! All you do is role around corners literally role because you do not need a break.  I been winning races with no HUD at all and I mean nothing on, never touching the break and roling around the corners which is annoying.Literally the cars handle like ice, sliding around things quickly.There is a nice feature which is the second monitor feature which allows you to see a scoreboard and different viewing angles when driving, but when I turned this on the game played terrible and was super laggy, but I am unsure if this is because I have the main monitor at ultra 144Hz so I do not know.  Just still unplayable with that on and a nice feature at the end of the day.If you like racing games then maybe this might suite you.  I love and enjoy racing games but I found playing this the same as others and offering nothing new.  Literally nothing new, and it feels like I've played this before (Grid 2) and I am bored of playing it after 2hours but thought to soldier on and play more and more.The mutliplayer is where the fun is if you get a lobby where people race correctly and do not ram the hell out of you.  Ghost mode ACTIVATED! Drive through me now!Really the game has tons and tons of these and no one really drives like a correct race is supposed to and that bores me, specially having to create a ghost lobby to stop the rammers makes it unrealistic but then seeing the car control it makes it okay.It literally feels like a DLC from Grid 2.  Really it's nothing special or new and that bores me and lets the game down!Would I recommend this game? Yes and no but sadly I cannot choose these two options.  If you like a 5minute drive around a track then avoid this, but if you are a die hard racer who loves ALL racing games then play this.  I like it do not get me wrong but playing this expecting something new is the wrong way to see it and for that I cannot play anymore but I will really try.

content:
Posted: January 26, 2015
												Major game breaker: unshakable AI despite having the 'faster' car - they always outrun you on straights.Pros:- Nice graphics, but of course, i'm running on a GTX780Ti with a 1440p screen, so maxed out everything without issues.Cons (other than the ♥♥♥♥ed up AI):- Controls doesn't save. Using an adapter with my old Dualshock 2 controller, when i set to the Direct Input Device preset, the buttons doesn't work for the menu, and i do not know what the keyboard shortcut is. When i switch back to a keyboard preset and map the keys to my controller, everything is fine until i quit and start the game, then i have to remap everything again.- Understeers like a cow, oversteers like a dog on ice. You make settings which you think should counter those problems - but no, the game thinks otherwise and you end up making the car worse.- Another AI problem♥♥♥♥♥physics. You car weighs as a car should. The other cars weighs like a ♥♥♥♥ing 100ton tank each. You push them hard and they refuse to budge, them tapping you slightly and you go sliding off the road, which brings me to my next point...- Penalties. So, it has become my fault that the ♥♥♥♥ed up AI pushes me out despite me having the line, and i get a ♥♥♥♥ing penalty for that?- AI related issue again. No matter how hard you try, the AI will always out-accelerate you at a stop-start.- Physics♥♥♥♥♥AI. Me, car. Them car. I ram them I damage, they ram me, I damage. Them ♥♥♥♥ing driving a tank?Fortunately, i bought this while it was on a discount.But damn Codemasters, what the ♥♥♥♥ are you doing? Race Driver: GRID was a damn nice game. GRID 2 was a little disappointing, and now this? sheesh, you becoming the 2nd Ubisoft where you gonna just churn out games hoping people will buy them?

number of helpful: 1 of 3 people (33%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 28, 2014
												This is a racing game made for racers.  People who genuinely love motorsports.  People who have actually DONE motorsports before.  People who know what racing really is like in real life. This review is written having only played the game with a G27 racing wheel and only manual sear shifting with all HUD's disabled for the most racing like experience.I've done my fair share of track days and i can tell you, think is the most realistic car racing game i have played.  There's plenty of people complaining the game feels too slow, the cars don't grip in corners blah blah.  Well guess what, those people have never driven on a track in their life.  When on a racing track, unless you're in a ultra fast ferarri or koensigg or something, guess what, you feel SLOW.  That's how it is.  Your car is slow.  People are so used to ♥♥♥♥♥♥ car sims that put so much emphasis on feeling like you're flying along or arcade racing games that let you go around corners at 400kph that they have no idea what it's actually like to race a car. So more on the good parts.  The handling of the cars:Fantastic.  Cars handle how they should. FWD understeers coming too hot into a corner, or if you put power down coming into a corner and you can even get the♥♥♥♥♥out with lift off oversteer when driving really agressive.  All of that is true in a FWD cars handling characteristics and they are all spot on in the game.  RWD cars oversteer if you power on too much mid corner, or over a crest.  You can really feel the suspension working.  Coming super hot down a hill into a banked corner?  Your suspension will start to wallow like a real car trying to deal with sideways g-forces, and if not careful in a RWD car, will cause oversteer.  Graphics: AMAZING.  Holy♥♥♥♥♥♥  The attention to detail is amazing.  From the different exhaust outputs of the cars (some will be obviously running rich, some not, etc) to the in car view of the dash being out of focus (because you're looking at the track, not the car) but obviously having some type of MOTEC carbon fiber HUD in place of the standard cars one, to the general cars decals and body panels.  The world around looks so gorgeous, beautiful lighting, amazing scenery, and really perfect track textures. Racing modes:The only thing the game is missing in terms of racing modes is drag racing and rally.  Which is not a downside to me.  Drag is always a short lived interest in racing games and rally is much a massive part of racing it really does require its own game.One massive thing to note is the different racing game modes all have different racing styles.  Touring cars are mega aggressive, open wheelers really require you to be careful with damage on and time attack is like how time attack is with sporadic cars you have to deal with.  Sounds:I love the fact you can hear the tyres gripping, the straight cut gears int he gear box and the pop from fuel injectors still being on when your changing gears, because screw fuel efficiency.Its the little things:To me what really makes this game great is the little things.  Like picking a perfect line through a series of corners then coming out and realising you just shaved a second or 2 off your lap time.  The spectators not being 2d, the clouds and lighting are so gorgeous and the cars look amazing. Even the simple and elegant UI still keeping perfect functionality.  The fact you log in, and the game says with voice "Welcome back (name here), there's some new events in the touring car championship, go check them out!".  You can really tell Codemasters have really put their heart and soul into this game.Summary:If you're a grown adult that loves racing, and has done it before, this is the game for you.  If your some pimply teenager that thinks GTA and Need for Speed are racing simulators, this isn't for you.

content:
Posted: December 25, 2014
												I am VERY pleased to say that I found this game to be exactly what I expected from GRID 2 - GRID 1 with improved physics and graphics. Pros- Beautiful graphics- Much better physics, especially considering this is an arcadey racer- Added features (e.g getting your engineer to give updates about things like car damage, teammat position etc.)- Qualifying (optional) is a nice featureCons- You no longer have your own team (boo!)- Although they have been improved, AI are still too easy to make them back down from a corner by moving close to them.Overall, A great game (10,000x better than GRID 2) and a great redemption for one of my personal favorite arcade racers.

number of helpful: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: August 1, 2015
												TL;DR = Arcade-like experience that offers short lived entertainment that which is NOT worth at its current listing.I received this game as a free download with the purchase of new computer hardware.  With that said, it is an adequate racing game with many of the bells and whistles that one might come to expect.  However, playing it many a time in solo career mode as well as the split screen co-op mode, both my co-op partner and I had to point out multiple times that the game leaves something to be desired.[[[LOTS OF CARS!]]] Kind of.  They all behave the same way in my eyes.  Don't get me started on these "drift-tuned cars", I can't figure that nonsense out for the life of me.*  But of course, having the trademark performance cars and Indycars and the like are all fine fun.  Then we have Supercars and Hypercars.  More on that later.          *=Probably just terribad.  Co-op partner always flipped me over and f*cked me sideways when she consistently beat me at the "drift" races.[[[PHYSICS!]]]I don't know about this one.  Maybe it's because my ~80 hours logged is primarily devoted to the co-op mode, I likely don't have a reliable opinion.  But there were times when my partner's car slid, literally from left to right, as if being yanked by a piston on a conveyor belt.  Of course, when that didn't happen, our reckless driving often jettisoned our very expensive Hypercars hilariously into the air.  Otherwise, we would be skidding across the track at hairpin turns.  TO BE CLEAR, this is not the fault of the game or the engine; this is user experience in the CO-OP mode.Beyond those elements, I have little to offer for review.  Other reviews would more adequately describe the AI and the Career mode.  As I said, most of my experience is in split screen co op, and so my opinion may be wholly unreliable.  And again, I received this game for free.  Would I recommend buying this game for $39.99?  No; maybe if it was under $10.  Only under the circumstance in which the user could come upon this game at a low price point, or for free, do I recommend it.

content:
Posted: December 29, 2014
												I've played Grid and Grid 2. This game is not as bad as some people say. Sure you can't buy your own cars, but that can be seen as a positive. You get to drive different cars and experience a range of different racing styles. In-car view is my favorite. First 2 games of the series I tried to race with the outside views only and in events like drifitng that was really bad, because I would always either under or over estimate car's speed and porximity to the corner. That would result in epic frustration and poor drift scores. In this game I was able to do cool drifts right in my first drifting event. Very positive emotions so far. Also the AI is not as homicidal as it was in Grid 2, so I can't complain. Overall I like this game and would recommend getting it on a sale.

content:
Posted: June 28, 2015
												Codemasters really disappointed me on this one. The first thing that caught my attention were the terrible graphics in the cockpit. It's like 140p on the inside, you can't see the gear, the reflections off the mirror are so low res that they are practically useless because you can't actually see who's behind you. Cockpit view is also unplayable because you can barely hear the sound of your engine to know what gear you're in / when to change. The AI can be really aggressive at times and there doesn't appear to be a noticable difference in graphics from Grid 2. However the game is fun to play, the racing physics are realistic, and the graphics look good overall.

content:
Posted: September 3, 2015
												This game is great. From a simulation stand point, it is realistic but not so much so that the game is no longer entertaining. It requires a basic knowledge of racing, but still preserves a lot of the fun in many other arcade games. And if the right difficulty is chosen, being in the pack is not frustrating at all but rather challenging and entertaining.There is one major concern I find though, that that is that the game crashes after a short while (15 minutes around), so until that is fixed it might be worthwhile holding off on a full price purchase.Overall, good game, definitely worth playing, just careful of the bugs.

content:
Posted: September 3, 2015
												I play alot of racing simulators but i actually enjoy the "arcade" aspect to this game every now and then.Graphics and sound are good and theres enough content to keep you occupied.The game has 2 major flaws though....1: The force feedback gets stuck sometimes and can vibrate without reason for up to a minute.2: The AI drivers are incredibly bad. Normally, in almost any racing game since the late 90`s, if you overtake on the inside of a corner, the AI driver usually brakes or atleast try to avoid a collision but in this game they follow the racing line like a train follows the rails. They just slams into you..... I play the game on the hardest difficulty without any driving assists so i really have to push it to come out in 1:st place in many of the races and since the AI drivers makes every overtake a dangerous one it just takes alot of the fun out of the game. I like the fact that an overtake isnt easy but if you follow the rules and dont "cut" people of and such, they shouldent just slam into you.I still recommend the game though!

content:
Posted: April 13, 2015
												This game presents itself as a realistic racer with nice graphics, real world racing teams, and vehicle tuning. The problem is that the physics engine is still the super arcade engine from previous GRID games. The arcade style physics feel really out of place in F1 cars especially. The game also gets extremely repetitive very quickly. The career mode is nothing but circuit racing, with the occasional drift tournament in Tuner, in various cars. Alternate styles of race, such as Drag and Sprint, are DLC. You also have almost no options when it comes to vehicle choice for races. You are given the option between two sponsors with 1 or 2 cars each. A lot of the teams have no tuning options whatsoever.I did purchase the Drag DLC in order to see what the fuss was about. The DLC is highly disappointing. There are nine additional tournaments but they have no impact on your Career OR Online progress in any way. Vehicle options are also extremely limited.If you are looking for a realistic racer, or any kind of variety, look elsewhere.

content:
Posted: August 18, 2014
												After waiting many weeks after the release of this game i decided to break down an throw more money into the Codemaster's pool of racing games. As many do now a days, i searched the web of pre-access user videos and reviewers to see how the in-game play would be. So before even purchasing i could tell there would be a lot of things i wouldn't like about the game, and somethings i would.  Overall this game is not worth the price it is going for, there are so many things that are off about this game or just not worth the value. If you still need a reason why you shouldn't buy it, keep reading.I own and play many codemaster games( F1 2010-13 , Grid, Dirt 2,3) so i have a good idea of how Codemasters work SHOULD be, but it seems they decided to cut every corner possible in this game. The AI, the physics, the track design/layout, have all been half arsed in comparison to the other games they have made, specifically F1 2013 which is by far the best version to date. It's strange to even think that this game is even made by the same people unless you look real close at some of the details in this game. My biggest gripe with this game, is the horrible attempt of the interior design of the vehicles, it's unbelievable how little f*cKs were given when they put these vehicles together. Considering games like Shift 2, forza 3-4 , which were made years ago, have superb interior and exterior design and a lot more cars! So there really isn't any reason for the excuse the designers may have.Some may still have an issue with the driving physics including myself, but i will say it can be pretty fun (like 20 minutes fun) when sliding about and buzzing of into the distance. Plus it's not like its uncontrollable, so i'm not going to knock on that door to much. Yes the problem is that tje they drifted towards....drifting physics, allowing the car to get extremely tail happy and overly dramatic body roll (tilt and lean) is apart of normal turning style, but in some cases it's a bit much considering that even the extreme formula cars suffer from snap oversteer and understeer if you don't get it just right.One thing that is decent about the game, is the basic tuning parameters. Even if you're a noob when it comes to vehicle tuning( unlike Forza where you have to be just shy of a mechanical engineer), you can get a sense of (hot or cold) when it comes to picking the right settings, and even if you are cold when it comes to choosing the right balance, you aren't severly punished on track, yes your times will be off but you now know why and can easily change it accordingly.But my last issue comes down to the detail in resolution. Its simply not there, there are still many areas through out the game that are simply too pixelated or not optimized. This may be a gripe with people who have spent a lot of money on their gaming rigs and want the best, of the best of the best, and for us this is not. It seems to me this game was probably meant to work well for people who have basic or mid range computers, so I can see where over a wider audience why it has been optimized at this level. Even maxed out on all settings my computer doesn't even break a sweat, which means there is a lot of graphical computing that is still bottled away to keep from killing users computer's. Though i've yet come across glitching issues, which some people like, to me it means not to many areas have been pushed to its maximum potential. A good example of this is Ubisoft games, they crash like hell and glitch like no other, but for the 15 minutes it plays, the quality is superb!

content:
Posted: July 10, 2014
												Grid Autosport succeeds where Grid 2 failed and is nearly an even match for the original Grid. AI is excellent though often ruthless, car control is accurate but exaggerated, tracks have all been seen before but boast many new layouts, pavement has nuance, and damage has consequences. I’m struck by how consistently the AI races. Once the difficulty is dialed in, every mistake you make pushes your rivals ahead and every perfect line reels them in. Passing a racer is always the slowest line around a corner and I can see the affect it has on me in relation to the cars ahead and behind. It’s brilliant. The race menus are all new for Grid Autosport. Events are organized into seasons that encompass one discipline at a time and must be completed before switching to another. You freelance yourself out to racing teams like in the old contracts system in Grid 1. Each season could be as few as 2 races or as many as 8-10, and can include a wide variety of vehicles. Season offerings are numerous and allow you to lean on disciplines you enjoy and do the minimum in disciplines you don’t. Different race teams set different goals and award more or less points accordingly but, more importantly, different teams offer different cars to align with your preferences in the same races. The points increase your level in each separate discipline and progress you into faster and faster cars. Seasons are competitive enough that you can afford to have numerous non-first finishes and still win so long as you’re near the top. Individual races typically have a 10 minute practice session, a 3 lap qualifying, neither of which can be restarted, and a race which can be restarted. Practice and qualifying can get a bit tedious but are optional. Short comings are few. I wish I could command my own race team and create my own liveries but you could argue that that’s what multiplayer allows you to do. And though there are many new track layouts, you’ve seen all of these locales before in Grid and Grid 2. New facades would have been welcome. I’d say the game is most enjoyable with an xbox360 controller but delicacy on the triggers tires my knuckles which makes the G27 a more comfortable, if not leisurely, choice. Highly recommend. Best fender on fender racing I’ve seen since Grid 1.

												First of all, this isn't gonna be a lenghy review. I went ahead with my gut feeling, hoping that this would bring back the old GRID which I love and adore.Fortunately I was not disappointed, not the least.With a G27 hooked up and configured this game is a pure blast. It's a major gripe on the forums. Save your money for Grid 3... maybe.

												IMO, it feels like someone got really lazy when they got to the "resolution setting" part of making a PC game... content:
Posted: September 5, 2014
												I've gone through what seems to be an endless list of patches till this day of posting and still the game is still able to astound me with the constant bugs. Critical: 5 BSOD events during playing the game itself. Playing the older Grid 2 yields hours of interrupted gameplay, or anything else for that matter. Then lose all your progress from starting the game before the crash. Cons: 1. AI: Can concur with most that the AI is behaving in an unruly manner, especially ones by Ravensport. What's more as easily they can spin you out, you can't retaliate effectively by PIT because they seem to be immune from pushing? 2. Downforce + Grip: I can expect the Touring cars to be slidy, but a F312 Dallara acts like its driving on ice. Or things one would expect to have more default downforce. Also AI seems to be able to slide at speed, while player cannot. 3. Tuning: Inital mid level tuning is too coarse for some courses. It should be full tuning at all times or never at all. Tuning isalso a cure for the poor grip/downforce on the F312 for example. 4. The nag everytime a season ends. If I wanted it to be harder, I would be playing Asseto Corsa with a phone keypad. Or drive a real car. Just saying.5. Endurance: At the shortest length, the tyre wear is overly much. If it happened in real life, you would sue the tyre company. Also losing grip means driftiness, but the controls won't allow finessed drifting, thus crashes occur. Pros: 1. First time I had an opportunity to drive Aussie V8 supercars. I now understand why the country is divided into before races. 2. Discipline variety: Keep alternating to relive the tedium of driving on the same tracks in every possible direction. Like the old days of NFS underground. Surprisingly apart from the speed, one can drive the same way  between all categories. Since I would not be able to finish the game without crashes every other race, this game is a reminder of my own folly of buying a pre-order sim from CM ever.

content:
Posted: September 7, 2014
												SE16 Review #1 | GRID Autosport (PC)When the first GRID game came out, it was a step foward for racing games. The new feature of being able to rewind and replay at an exact point, was followed by games such as Forza. GRID 2 was a litte bit of a let down, however, GRID Autosport has re-gained that pure racing magic that the original game had. It is based of 5 categories, Touring (BTCC, DTM), Open Wheel (F3, Indycar), Endurance (Prototype, Classic), Tuner (Drift, JDM) and Street (Hypercars, Super Cars). It is a very well layed out and beautiful game with perfect compatibility to most sterring wheels, including my one, the Logitech G27. The DLC packs are alos great, being cheap and mostly on sale for half price, and also featuring great content such as new tracks and vehicles. GRID Autosport brings back the true feel for racing games, definantly worth the money.Overall Rating: 8/10Reviewed By: Slenderenderon16 (SE16)

content:
Posted: September 15, 2014
												Another in a string of dissapointments from Codemasters. They used to be one of the top racing game makers. Now, it seems like every year things get worse. The original GRiD was actually quite good except for two flaws: the inexplicable stacks of tires along the walls and the flashback feature. You couldn't see the tire stacks so you would drive a normal racing line, going near the walls, and then BAM you're wrecked. The flashback was a nice concept, but it ultimately failed because it never went back far enough.The 2004/2005 rally game was the last good one they made. The F1 games were disappointing, GRiD 2 was horrible, and the DiRT series tried but ultimately failed, especially DiRT 3. It was great that 3 brought back more rallying, but Gymhkana 'hoonigan' events, seriously? Games are supposed to be fun, and that's not fun, it's just stupid.GRiD Autosport seems to be an attempt to recapture some of the first GRiD game's fun factors. It doesn't do that. The controls are snappy, unnatural, and unpredictable. With oriignal GRiD, it was start up and play, Not with Autosport. It suffers, as many current driving games do, from 'current-gen overdone graphics lag,' which is my way of thinking about how developers feel compelled these days to ignore physics and animate each little frame when moving from one position to another at the expense of response time and realism. When it takes half a second for the game to respond to me pressing the button for reverse view, that's a big warning flag. What ends up happening is that the steering responds slowly and then more quickly, not in a linear fashion. This causes you to stop steering (or countersteering) when you see the right time to do it, but by the time you see it, it's already too late and you've overdone it. Then you try to counter (or counter-counter) that which only makes it worse. Thinking it was because I was using a gamepad controller, I tried my Logitech G27 wheel. Same thing. It's an unfortunate side effect of the capabilities of graphics display and engines and such being well beyond the capabilities of developers and the physica processing. Older games don't do that, but every game equating to PS3 and Xbox360 does, along with their PC equivalents. Yet we keep buying what Codemasters makes so I guess they accomplished their goals. For me, this is the last Codemasters game I will ever buy. Sad ending to a relationship going back to the first CMR game. Fortunately I still have CMR 2005 and play it regularly, TOCA 2 is still a lot of fun, and even DiRT 2 is at least enjoyable, if unrealistic and lacking in relevant driving modes. But having fun is what a game is all about, and those games deliver.

content:
Posted: June 28, 2014
												Let me start by pointing out that I do not own Grid 2 and only ever played it for less than 5 minutes, so I can't make any comparison between these two. Grid Autosport is a good racing game, and when I say that, I mean that it's a fun game, in which the racing feels fast, fierce, fun, challenging, and rewarding. It does not feel like reality, but it isn't one of those over the top arcade racers either. Overall, the racing is fun and satisfying. The AI is tough, sometimes even a bit over the top, especially in the touring car races. However, I'd much rather have overall tough competition and feel like I've fought and raced hard for every point, than go through a grid full of cars going on rails, not bold enough to challenge the human player. The only problem I have with the AI is that your team mate seems to be pretty much rubbish every single race, which leaves you fighting for the team championship alone. I've only done the first few seasons, so perhaps this will change later on. Nevertheless, I would very much like my team mate to be the biggest challenge in any race, which is not the case at least at the moment. The graphics are nice enough, I doubt anyone has much complaints about them. The cockpit view, as stated a gazillion times everywhere, is not as good as it should be, but it's there nevertheless. I don't mind the blur or the bad textures inside the car, however I do find it annoying that looking around will flip the view straight to sideview, instead of smoothly "turning your head". You can remove the blur by the way, with some tweaks to the game files (google). The textures won't get any better though, neither will the displays start functioning. Like I said, to me it's just not important. I do understand that some people feel otherwise. For me, it does the job.The handling is probably not quite perfect, but as soon as you get used to it, it is actually very much fun and satisfactory. I would like it to be slightly less airy, but I've already got used to it and have no complaints. In the worst case, it's going to make you feel a bit strange for the first few races, while getting to grips with it. It's not sim, but it clearly has some elements of more sim-like handling. I've played all assists off, with a gamepad, and it's good fun and extremely challenging at times. I can clearly feel that a steering wheel and pedals would much better suit this game. Even with the gamepad though, I really enjoy the challenge the handling gives me, trying not to break traction, not to lose the rear end while cornering, not over-correcting, etc. The sense of speed is brilliant. At some of the street circuits, or the fast road circuits, you really feel the rush, trying to stay on the throttle as long as you can, braking late, feeling like you're surely going way too fast! Just so you know, I'm playing with very hard AI, no assist, and manual gears, with a ps3 gamepad. There are a lot of smaller things I like about the game, things like being able to change the duration of a race, being able to command your team mate and so forth. The team mate commanding could be better, but it's a nice addition. As an example, I was in a race fighting my way through the pack since the starting order had been reversed, while my usually very slow team mate was at the front, thanks to the high starting position. I found myself third when the final lap started, with my team mate in front of me at second. I'd told him to be aggressive, and thought to myself that perhaps I should tell him to slow down a bit, seeing that he was a bit all over the place going for the first position, and we needed the points to complete the team objectives. I then thought "nah, let's go for the 1-2", and a few corners later he spun trying to overtake and dropped to the back of the pack. So the team orders definitely added something there, as I felt like an idiot afterwards :D Not a huge thing, but nice small detail. Multiplayer seems to be great. I was doubtful about the "gaining xp" and "buying cars" business, but I have to admit that it adds more depth to the game mode. There are loads of options, from cups, single races, and time attacks (with everyone on track at once), to something called destruction derby, which I have not yet tried as I have little interest in that sort of racing, but it shows some variety nevertheless. Being able to have your own club with friends or others is a great addition, from creating liveries to trying to finish well to gain reputation. There are quite a few maldonados out there, so sometimes patience is tested.... very much. I guess you could find a group or a league, but most my experiences have been fine, and the racing is surprisingly good, especially as the damage tends to take the crash heads out quite soon after the start. Damage is nice by the way. Nothing spectacular, but done very well still.So, like said in the beginning of this review, the game is good. To me it felt like a good deal as well, as it was £29 on release, as opposed to the usual £39-£59 most new games seem to be. I'm sure people who bought Grid2 might feel differently, given that the game is less than a year old, but myself not being one of those people, it felt like great value. It's a solid racing game, and I'm going to spend a lot of time with it I'm sure. Hope this review is helpful to someone!

number of helpful: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 28, 2014
												Not a Masterpiece, but GRID Autosport is a solid improvement over GRID 2, finally bringing the experience closer to the popular first GRID title.The same mix of sim and arcade elements combined with an aggressive AI, but with today's graphics.Although I'd have preferred a full dashboard, the out of focus one you get is IMHO still passable and effective.Handling is fun, (luckily) with a little less emphasis on drifting than GRID 2, and together with an aggressive AI you get the style of close simcade racing that the original GRID was known for. Note if you are looking for a full racing sim, you are better off buying something like AC, rFactor2, GSC or R3E, but if like the occasional lighter sim GRID Autosport is pretty much a home run.Now it may be irrational and I have to do more comparing, but there are areas (besides the dashboard, team management and elements of the GUI) where I still think the original is better, however the same is true for GRID Autosport (handling is a mixed bag, FFB setup, graphics).So basically I like GRID Autosport, solid simcade, fun and aggressive racing 7.5 - 8/10I am racing on hard, no aids with a DFGT.System i7-920, 16gb, w7-64b and 780GTX - runs a solid 60fpsOk, couple observations..Like - close hard racing when you suddenly see a car in front fly in the air and rolling passed  you.Miss - the old GRID damage cam is still better. Overall replay is clunkier, just slight improvement over GRID 2AI - on hard the AI can basically keep up even after a rwd car hast lost one of its rear tires and is driving on the rim.Small things that can make or break your gaming experience,CM made a benchmark game with the original GRID and they are having difficulties mixing "innovation" with proven game elements. Perhaps it is my age, but I am starting to hate the excessive push to innovate games to the detriment of success formulas. Reviewers and even players give games a poor rating because they are not innovative enough. Me, if it works, copy it and just update the graphics and physics to match the next generation of technology - I'll buy it.Don't push yourself to reinvent the wheel, give us what works what we really like to play.GRID Autosports is just that.CM took a good look at the original GRID and tweaked their GRID 2 base game until it neared the original GRID.Next time I hope CM will remember and produce a GRID 3 that is basically GRID with updated physics and graphics.Better yet get a couple of licenses, something like V8SC would really be a perfect match for this engine.A full championships beats the many "analog" single events with just a couple of cars and tracks each.Get the right license and you'll have the next F1 "easy win".Did I mention V8 Supercars - dunno how they do it, but that's probably the most exciting TC racing on the planet, with a good mix of high tech, close competitive racing, challenging tracks and oozing with sheer character.You even already have the some of the cars in GRID Autosports.Did I mention V8 Supercars?...and the Utes :)

												Hoped this game would rekindle hope for the GRID series, but frankly its awful. Handling is only marginally better than the last game, awful menu system - cant even just grab a ccar from a menu and practice a track, have to go through setting up a competition, career mode is basic, AI stinks - far too aggressive in open-wheel cockpit racing - its like it is barely aware of your existance.Cockpit views are a joke, either right up to the window with no detail or a blurry non-functional cockpit from a behind the wheel position.Obvious from the start that this is going to be plagued by a lot of DLC but its a cash-cow thats not worth milking.I bought this hoping for a good GRID again and after hearing positive feedback on the internet but it was blatant BS. Uninstalled, only saving grace was I got it at a discounted price but I still feel let down. They need to work hard to make me bother to reinstall it.LOL patch appeared as I was typing this up - went into forums to check it out, no notes yet for that patch but there is a bit of feedback about the game corrupting save files, *slow clap* well done codemasters, epic fail (a post states they fixed corruptions but are waiting for that patch to go through QA - shame they didn't QA the rest of it before release).

content:
Posted: June 28, 2014
												While it's a pretty game to look at, the overall experience is lacking.The ABS should be an anogram for 'Always Locking Breaking System' as the breaking is terrible, even when using analogue controls.A.I. opponents are lack lustre. They will hold their driving line, even if it means smashing into your rear quarter panel, sending you off the track. Sorry, but if I have the inside line and carrying the speed into the corner (all whilst controlled), the AI should not be trying to send me into the wall because they want to keep their line. The cockpit view is horrendous and obviously only put in after the outcry from Grid 2's omition. The fact is, they could have and should have put a few more hours into it. It's a blurry mess.The Career mode is a simple set of menus and it feels like the available vehicles and tracks are limited, in comparison to previous installments. This isn't the case, however it gives that impression due to the menu's being so 'cut-off' from the player in comparison to Grid and even Grid2.There is no sense of continuation in your career either, apart from five vertical bars that increase with arbitrary numbers after each race. You don't have your own team, you don't manage your team-mate. You are simply a gun for hire for random teams. You don't even get to choose your livery, colour scheme, or even your vehicle number.In all honesty, everything in this game has been done before and done far better.Racedriver: Grid, is still the best in this series. Such a shame.

Posted: February 13, 2015
												"Oh God, not another race!" is the phrase I use the most when playing this game. The reason being that when I bought a racing game, I was hoping I'd be racing.I really enjoyed Grid and I think I'm in a minority because I also enjoyed Grid 2. Grid Autosport I want to like but it just feels like a chore, grinding out races so you can slowly unlock other races which you need to grind out to unlock more races...Of the 5 race types, Tuner is like driving a marshmellow around a track - no sense or urgency or speed. Drift is ridiculous - you hardly even need to brake, the car will drift as soon as you turn the wheel so there's little to no skill involved. I tried fishtailed left and right through a section whilst completely ignoring bends and still won. And Timetrials? Who cares - I want to R A C E!Endurance is pontless and in a game that already feels like hard work, why bother? Instead of looking at your lap counter and thinking 'Only 2 more laps', you look at the clock and think 'Bloody hell, 5 more minutes?'Other modes are good as you actually get to race but very frustrating in that you will bust a gut to get a win or a 3rd place against superior competition (actually, it's only 1st and 2nd that are superior, but it helps you to delude yourself that everyone in the field is) and your efforts are largely pointless because your teammate is still on the starting grid trying to find the ignition.To be honest, it pains me a little to not recommend this game because the racing can be great fun. But every time I pick it up to play, after about 10 minutes I'm just begging for the end of the event and having to drag myself through. Shouldn't it be more fun?

												Heard it was meh, Grid 2 was better, etc. Well that may be true, but it is still a great game.The only annoying thing is that you are dependant on AI partners during events. They are frequently♥♥♥♥♥♥which drags you down. This would be fine, but your main rivals throughout the game, Ravenwest, are both pretty much always in the top 3. Because of this it is very difficult to win since their team average will be higher than yours. To solve this I generally make one of them crash by pushing them into the wall or something. Not exactly in the spirit of the game, but neither is forcing you to have a ♥♥♥♥♥♥ AI partner that makes it so you can't win.

number of helpful: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 24, 2015
												Codemaster regains its composure in the grid series to produce a definite one foot forward offering. Clearly holding the F1 franchise is beginning to show dividends.The most noticable change is car handling,something far from the case in its predecessor Grid 2 and while not exactly pick up and play as Grid 1 is worth the effort to master. The single player story/campaign is hit n miss but again Grid never did hold an award for that part and car tweaking is minimalist to say the least. That aside all runs smooth,nice tracks, nice cars, much improved handling from 2 and more than reasonable AI dependant on setting.I still hanker for and lord the original as autosport comes across a little to clinical looking in presentation for my liking but this doesnt detract from it offering itself up as a really good driving gameGrid autosport with DLCs is the most complete grid package from cars,options,tracks to arcade amusement todate, its just a shame yet again to have to collect the DLCs to make it so.

												Very good racing game, a lot of race types, cars... good graphics. good driving feel. one of the best racing games that I played.I need to mention, the game is not Arcade, is more oriented to a Simulator. You will need few time to understand how to drive the car, but after that the driving feel is very good. Pay attention to difficulty settings, some driver addings need to be set On or Off based on your driving style.Also, Online content is very good. Racenet Challenges is a nice way to play vs friends/community. There are leaderboards for each type of race. Ghost Car is also nice, can virtually compete with a friend.

content:
Posted: December 27, 2014
												This is a fantastic racing game, far better than its predceding titles. Its graphical fidelity is on par with Grid 2, and its mechanics are a vast improvement over both Grid 1 and 2. The game feels quite a bit more realistic than the other Grid games, more of a simulator than an arcade game, though it still retains a sense of fun and forgiveness of mistakes, at least at the lower difficulty levels. Though I have not used the online multiplayer system, I would highly recommend this game to anyone looking for a PC based racing game based on the merits of the singleplayer campaign alone.

content:
Posted: March 14, 2016
												I was hoping Codies had learned from their Grid2 mistake but I just dont understand how you keep ruining an IP like GRID, when it was so good.  The handling is somewhat simple, the graphics are generally good but the interior of the cars are blurred out. GRID had interiors and even working dials.The replays are less interesting, the smoke and damage effects are poor and the sound is really dull.  The inside of a touring car sounds like its full of cotton wool.Its not terrible but is not as good as the original GRID, and it should be leaps and bounds ahead nowadays.The career is also very limiting and is simply a succession of single races.I do like the addition of practice, qualifying and reverse ordering of cars in round 2.  Also, the time penalties and ability to multiply the number of laps.  But good rules like this on a poorly driving car with no personal team is worthless.Lets hope that the next GRID is the best of all the games in the franchise.

number of helpful: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 18, 2016
												Where would I start, hmmm ok the AI has a huge advantage and its not just the fact that they are faster than you for no apparent reason but also they seem to all be playing against you and you only. Its like one big team vs you, then you always have the cars they want you to drive and career mode is the most linear game I have ever seen in a race game before even more than the old Hot Pursuit. Not knowing that you cannot select cars I purchased DLC yeah noooooot. DLC I guess is just for my online cars collection but you cannot play online so they are basically just really pretty model textures to look at. All in all I say after 2 years of being on the market no game should be this dead online and that limited in scope to its offline play. Hey its a racing game these are usually not MMO buddyu so yeah way to make a flop. Not only that but why is Valve not doing anything to safegaurd its customers and loyal fans. I say that either these games need to be taken down or when the rating drops below mixed to negative the price has to be significantly dropped to reflect poor quality and development. If the old saying is you get what you pay for then what is valve and every other gaming company trying to tell us.

number of helpful: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 5, 2014
												Best Codemasters game since Dirt 3.When I played Grid 2 I thought "great cars and tracks, too bad the engine is garbage, and where are the Grid 1 cars and tracks?"  Grid Autosport put a simle on my face.  The "Street" discipline has a mix of the Grid 1 & 2 cars and tracks (not sure if everything's there yet) and a great physics engine.  The suspension dynamics feels right for the first time since Dirt 3.  Really, fun to drive, and that's what makes a racing game.  (Excpet for the drift events - WTF guys?  Boss's nephew write that or something?)Single player has 5 disciplines, and frankly I found most of them too boring to play.  But the stuff I like is enough to make the game worth getting, and I can just ignore the rest.  And if you love memorizing brake points, or just need a cure for insomnia, there's some solid content in here for you.Some reviewers seemed to be expecting a simulator.  From a Grid title?  Get real.  It's simcade all the way, and more power to it!  If you want to set toen-in angles or somesuch, Dirt 1 is still around, but this game focuses on getting the feel of driving at the edge of traction right, and the rest can hang for all I care. (And, yes, the heavy cars wallow around like pigs - if you don't find that fun there's that whole open wheel brake-point-memorizing thing just for you.)There are 3 or 4 driving games in here, and one or more is likely to appeal to everyone.

content:
Posted: June 25, 2014
												If you go by the "community" discussions and reviews, this seems to be a very love-it or hate-it game. Personally, I am loving it. As a fan of many different forms of autosport, few games in recent memory have been able to capture my interest for long. This game, for me, hits a nice sweet spot between arcade racer and sim-light that really brings the joy of driving through. I don't need to dedicate my life to it to enjoy it, but it's also not so simple that it would become stale quickly. With five playable driving disciplines, a rewarding progression system, and online play--this is a game I would definitely recommend for the racing fan open to an experience that's more a celebration of speed and competition than a technically accurate simulation.

content:
Posted: June 26, 2014
												It's Forza on PC.Finally, the GRID sequel we have all been waiting for. The sequel that takes the simulation side of racing rather than the arcade style of GRID 2. YES! It has cockpit view. Using the Xbox 360 Controller for Windows, this game feels natural to play and the use of the D-Pad to get Radio Updates from your Engineer is genius. (Push left for Car Damage, Up for gap to driver infront, Down for Race Rival info and Right for Team-Mate info)Graphically: the game looks alright. Handling: Pretty good for a racer. If cut a corner you are limited to a low speed for a short time (Only kicks in on very big corner cuts)Gameplay: from what I've played so far it is really going back to the original GRID style (build your XP for a discipline - Touring Car, Endurance, Tuner, Open Wheel, Street - then take part in the international stage for that discipline)From what I've played so far, I would really say "If you like Forza, or the original GRID - buy this!"

number of helpful: 3 of 8 people (38%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 28, 2014
												Note: It'll be greatly appreciated if you comment why the review was helpful or not helpful, so please take your time to comment on what I could've done better in the review.GRID Autosport is a game that is not meant to garner a new fanbase like GRID 2 was(might've succeded, although at the cost of disappointing many, including me), but is meant for people who enjoyed the first game: Race Driver: GRID(aka GRID).________________________________________________________________Gone are the 'Oh you're turning into a corner? Drift mode activated for "fun"!' handling physics of GRID 2, the nonsense storyline, the annoying and useless engineer guy, and a linear career mode.On the other hand, making a welcome return is an emphasis on real-life circuits such as Spa, Jarama, Circuit of the Americas, Mont Tremblant; cockpit view; a career mode that is reminiscent of Race Driver: GRID with 5 separate disciplines(Touring, Endurance, Open Wheel, Tuned, and Street).________________________________________________________________Besides that, the gameplay has been tweaked to put a little more realism into the game. The physics, they're arcade that mimics a sim, but they're more believable than what GRID 2 and even Race Driver: GRID offered. As a result, races are no longer a drift fest or is drifting the best way to get around corners(quite the opposite), and something called understeer finally exists.Also, free practice sessions have been added to race weekends, giving players time to get used to the track and tweak their car's setups(yes, you've heard that correct, you can now setup your cars, although it's simplified compared to sims). Qualifying sessions are now available as well, finally making any grid position that isn't P10-12 possible. These two sessions are not compulsory and can be bypassed, but that's only recommended for casual racers with AI difficulty set to easy.Adding to that, race lengths are now extendable with the choice of 2, 3, and 5 times the original length. Don't like 3 lap touring car races? Why not have 6, 9, or 15 laps! It's possible now and I have to say it makes the career mode much more enjoyable.Speaking of race weekends, the race engineer is also a lot less intrusive and gives helpful advice instead of saying 'good job' every minute. Players now can also ask their engineers to get an update on the car's status, teammate or rival's track position, or the gap to the driver ahead. Another thing, the engineer is now British.________________________________________________________________Then, what are the downsides? Plusses outweigh the minuses(of course, my opinion), but there are some to note.First off, it's not a revolution, but an evolution. You won't find anything that'll catch your eyes for being so brand new. In fact, there are quite a few recycled contents. The track selection has some new additions like the beautiful Mont Tremblant or Sepang and CoTA, but other tracks are ones that were featured in either Race Driver: GRID or GRID 2(no new city circuits).It's a similar case with the car lists too. Although we see some new cars(all of them are great) like the Ford GT40, A1GP open-wheeler, Caparo T1, Classic Mini, Lancia Delta, and McLaren P1, many others are ones that previous games had as well. In-game soundtracks are also the case where you see recycled contents, with the soundtracks being remixed versions of GRID 2 soundtracks. They're better than GRID 2's, but still, remixed musics are remixed musics.Adding to the list, there's the cockpit view. Oh people are going absolutely mad over this. Yes, the game doesn't have a 3D interior modeling and uses the exterior mesh for cockpit views, making them low-res and undetailed. I personally have no issues with this and I like that Codemasters have added an alternative cockpit view that zooms in to the front windshield alongside the standard one(many games go for this, but I find them distracting because of car's interior taking up too much space on screen), but yeah, having a detailed interior with working dashboards like in other Codemasters titles would've been better.________________________________________________________________I haven't had the opportunity to drive around every track or drive all the cars in the game. However, after 2 days of playing, I'm already liking the game more than the previous two games. Had GRID 2 been like this game, I would've fallen in love with it. It took a huge disappointment and more waiting, but I'm glad that Codemasters have listened to fans' outcry and worked to fix it. GRID Autosport is not a groundbraking game, but a delightful fan service for those who waited for a sequel to Race Driver: GRID. If you were one of those people, I'd recommend that you give this game a chance. Verdict: Recommended, 4/5

number of helpful: 3 of 8 people (38%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 3, 2014
												This game was Codemasters' last chance to make things right. They blew it completely. Here is why: 1. Cockpit views - a bloody shame when compared to the lovely one that the original GRID came with. 2. Handling - worse than GRID 2 and incredibly bad compared to the original GRID; trying to manage oversteer with keyboard is a chore to put it lightly. 3. Car tuning - a total joke, even NFS Underground 2 was better; you might think that Codemasters could at least copy things right, but that would be smart4. Career - the whole team experience package from the original GRID is missing; no comment5. Endurance races - Codemasters managed to screw them up really hard; Le Mans is gone, as well as the day-night cycles during the race - instead you have to fight tire wear and AI that seems not really affected by that6. Blur - once you deactivate that, your eyes suddenly feel like they don't need glasses (yes, it's that bad), but you will instantly see how shoddy the textures were made; the rest of the game is similarly crafted ...Given this trainwreck, Codemasters claim that they listened to the community was a blatant lie. Unless acting upon the feedback was optional (in their opinion). You get the picture, I hope. In my not so humble opinion, this game and its developer by extension have managed to insult the first (legendary) GRID again, which to this day remains the undisputed champion. Those many awards back then were well deserved, but Codemasters as it is today does not deserve your money for this game right now. Do yourself and your wallet a favor, enjoy the first GRID (the game that does it right) and ignore the 'pretenders' that followed afterwards. Cheers.

												Probably the highest on my list of games I should have never of purchased. I know it’s not a "sim" in the standard sense but the AI is ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ (no matter the difficultly or series). At times they're like a real-life ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ you pass on the road when they’re driving too slow because when you do pass them they're right on your♥♥♥♥♥flashing their brights. WTF!? The AI for Ravenwest...wow. Sure they're great drivers but at times I'm purely out matched (again no matter the difficulty) because the way they pull away from the rest of the pack or even if I'm at max speed they'll leave every one of us in the dust. It’s like they have a twin-turbo’d supercharger with NOS. Sure that’s worth a laugh on itself but that’s the way it feels. Another thing about the game design is if you get a lil rough with the NPC cars chances are you'll crash, why I don’t know. It's like they're a tank and I'm a Ford Fiesta. I touch them, I'll either crash or my steering is F'd for all eternity (steering went orange at 20mph after the 1st turn at Bathurst). If they touch me, well I'm just F'd. What's funny is a bit ago, on Bathurst, I got side-swiped by a Rick Scott and my car damn near did a 90 degree angle into the wall on a straight away. The rubber banding I've always seen on Need for Speed games I am seeing in this game as well, it’s horrible. I'll have a 5 second lead oh wait, here comes one of the Kicker cars out of nowhere catching up, and for some reason I still got the fastest lap time. If you haven't gotten the game, don't buy it for anything more than $15 dollars cause exactly how it plays. This has game frustrated me more than being a fat kid in high school.

content:
Posted: July 8, 2014
												The good: The feel of the racing is great, not too arcadey or too simulation, just right for a casual racer like me. And the fact that AI now make mistakes is a very good feature. For ages I've wanted a game where the player isn't the only driver doing any overtaking or causing drama, because in real life every driver can make mistakes and Grid has finally managed to show that. The drivers actually pressure you in this game, where as in some games you feel like the AI dont challenge you enough. Lets be honest, there is not a lot of good touring car games out there, and this is probably the best of the touring car games.The bad: It's WAY to predictable. In Grid 1, the ravenwest team was exactly the same, dominating every race and winning everything, and when Grid Autosport was announced, codemasters was happy to announce that ravenwest was back. The only thing i was thinking when they announced the return of ravenwest is "Not good". What makes racing exciting (for instance the BTCC) is competition. Anyone in the BTCC, ranging from matt neal, jason plato, andrew jordan, giovanardi, colin turking, and a lot more have the chance of winning races and being a potential champion. Grid Autosport however... has completely got that all wrong. I am soley a touring car driver, so i dont know About the other events, but in the touring discipline, you can pretty much gaurentee Nathan Mckane and his ravenwest teammate will come in 1st and 2nd, with the team kicker guys coming in 3rd and 4th. EVERY SINGLE RACE, you can pretty much predict where everyone is going to finish. The occasional switiching of positions, but thats rare to say the least. You feel like theres no point there being any other team, since ravenwest will ALWAYS... and i mean ALWAYS win the races. This bad feature alone has made me dislike this game A LOT. If the game was less predictable and ravenwest wasn't the only team capable of winning a race, this game would be much MUCH MUCH better.I also don't like the career mode. I never have in Code master games. They have improved it since Grid 1 since now i can specialise in touring cars, but theres no true progression in the game. Each season the teams are exactly the same. In games such as FIFA, each season is different as players transfer to different teams, new younger players are introduced, and old players retire. Each season is different. But with Grid Autosport (and likewise for games such as F1), the teams are always the same every season, and if you change to a different team, the other driver that was in that team just randomly disappears.. you'd think if i took one of the ravenwest guys positions, because they are "So great" they'd change to a different team, but no...Sidenote: I also think they should of added team creation again. I wanted to be competing in the touring cars championship with my own team, and my own selected team mate, like in Grid 1.Despite not recommending this game yet, if they fix what I think is wrong with this game, I would recommend this game to ALL. I like that code masters have gone back to touring cars and by no means hate the disciplines in the game, just the predictablity.

number of helpful: 2 of 6 people (33%) found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
Posted: September 5, 2014
												The review is distributed into different headings and paragraphs, and they're really short so don't worry about it. I haven't written this review in detail because there already are many great LONG reviews to read but if you like to read some short one with not-so-much explanation about stuff, read mine.TL;DR It's a good game, I'll give it a 8.5/10. Comparing with GRID 2, it's not that great IMO.In-Car ViewThis feature was added in GRID Autosport, but believe me, it sucks! They've blurred it out so that you won't see the pixelated speedometers and stuff inside which is not even working. Even the steering looks unreal. Now you must be wondering how I saw this. Here you go, download this mod: http://www.racedepartment.com/downloads/cockpit-cam-no-blur.2553/Authentic HandlingYes, indeed handling got better than any previous GRID series. You will only notice a slight difference in driving, mainly huge difference in grip (if you're comparing it with GRID 2).Street Racing Discipline CategoryJust a regular discipline having all the street cars to drive. This is one of my favourite my discipline.Tuner Discipline CategoryThis discipline will test the player's throttle management skills during the drift events. The drift cars have rear wheel drive and steering lock and short gears. Players will have to have co-ordination in steer, throttle modulation, brakes and handbrake. Timing is important as a miss will send you into a spin.Open Wheel DisciplineIn open wheel discipline, layers will have to avoid contact with other cars as even the slightest touch will mean that they have to forget of making a podium finish. The prominence of slipstream is more in this category. Players can make use of this tool to progress. Also, slipstream might be used by other drivers so players in the front must be very careful.Cars found under this category are known for their raw acceleration and agility, since they are lightweight cars. This category will have two kinds of cars – ones that are "nippy, rear-engined" and that which can oversteer through corners and mid-engine Formula cars that have thick tyres and lots of downforce giving players grip and confidence to attack.- Large grid sizes- The A.I. opt for clean racing lines- Cars of similar or pre-defined specification, usually single car class- Sports-tuned vehicles with lots of grip- Practice, Qualifying and Race format- Day time racesTouring Discipline The cars here will be "grippy and lightweight" and are designed for bumper-to-bumper racing. - Large grid sizes (up 16 cars offline, 12 players online)- Angry AI that won't be afraid to attack or protect the racing line- Cars of similar or pre-defined specification- Multiple round races- Practice and Qualifying- Day time races- Loads of trading paintStatisticsYou will be able to track all stats which includes discipline XP, number of championships won/lost, races joined, etc. You can also compare it with the community through RaceNet or your friends.RaceNet ChallengeEvery week players will have six challenges to compete and it will be based on every disciple and one wildcard. Players will be able to earn rewards like experience and money based on the final finishing position.RaceNet GroupsOnline groups can be formed allowing players to compare their progress, compete and battle for supremacy with other groups.Players will be given group experience based on their performance and are given the opportunity to design their own livery and racing.Group HQ is the right place to gain access to group's drivers and check up on various stats. It will also be hosting the group garage, that will have all the best cars of the club members, their stats and players can compare it with theirs. This area will also have group admins drop in to manage the group, promote players, change the group logo or edit the recruitment status.Game Modes- RaceNet Challenge- Online Custom Cup – It is a game mode that allows players to configure and Event the way they want it by choosing different options like discipline, vehicles class, race type, number of events, AI, tracks, upgrades, tuning and assists, manual only, cockpit cam only, pre and post-race timers, collisions, grid order, damage and flashback- Party Mode – This is a mode that is found in Custom Cup and has fun Race Types which do not fit in the five main Disciplines. It includes Demolition Derby, Checkpoint and Eliminator.Cars included in the gameThe cars in the game will be divided into five main groups – Touring, Open Wheel, Street, Tuner and Endurance. The game will be featuring Touring Cars, GT, Single-Seaters, Muscle Cars, Drift, Supercars, Hypercars, Time Attack, Destruction Derby, Prototypesand others.Touring Cars:- Honda Civic Touring Car- Ford 												Like most people, i was very sceptical about this game, i really didnt believe that codemasters would listen to the feedback from Grid 2 and improve on it greatly.... But i was wrong! This game is NOTHING like Grid 2, the graphics are better, the handling has been improved dramatically and the entire feel of the game is just amazing. number of helpful: 2 of 6 people (33%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 28, 2014
												In terms of driving games I am quite experienced. I know what I like and I know what is good and GRID Autosport fits into both categories. The original GRID was an awe inspiring addition to (at the time) a flooded market of extremely good driving games, both simulator and arcade. Its greatest achievement was its introduction to road physics. Everybody lapped up (excuse the pun) the way you could feel the drive and know/react to the changing road surface. In GRID 2 the ball was dropped a bit. It was alright, but it did not live up to the original. In GRID Autosport 'everything is awesome!!'. Each of the driving disciplines has been perfected beautifully. Driving is fun and the simulation options are vast, yet it still has a fun arcade feel?! It expands in every department compared to the original. The framerate is damn fast even at ultra settings with the high definition pack. I have encountered zero bugs and the multiplayer is quality. I am so happy with my purchase and cannot fault it. It is certainly worth giving a go. Join in multiplayer and lets race!

content:
Posted: June 26, 2014
												Grid Autosport is a beautiful game and the free HD texture pack adds a lot to the car models. The driving itself is very different from Grid 2, so if you're expecting the slide around every corner at top speed driving then you might want to look elsewhere. Grid Autosport's driving style is very sim like and more realistic then Grid 2. I'm only a few hours in and there are a few things that I would have liked to see in this game that seems to be left out. First off if your going for a sim style game I believe it should hold true to other sim racing games and Grid Autosport lacks some of those features. You cannot purchase vehicles, the upgrading system is lacking and almost seems useless at this point because all upgrades that are available seem to be installed for you. But even with those few issues I can still confidently recommend Grid Autosport because it is a solid racing experience with great handling and outstanding graphics. When I get some more hours in I may edit my recommendation but for now this is how it stands.*Update 6/28/14After checking out the multiplayer i found out that is the mode in which you can purchase vehicles and have a garage to store them in. I still wish they had this in the career mode considering i don't play a whole lot of multiplayer.

content:
Posted: July 7, 2014
												I have sadly only played in the years I have been with the Master Race 1 of the Grid based Racing games. Grid 2. Everything About that game I loved its sense of speed the way the game felt and it wasn't just a Oh Hey i'm a Racer here on steam hoping you buy me.. It was something special that some Racing games dont have. Finally we have Grid Autosport. One of my friends shared this game in a Twitch LiveStream and the moment I saw it I wanted to play it. This Game has ALOT to do and will keep you busy for a while. There is tons of customizing of your car from normal upgrades to just including better front and back suspension on your car.. To adding a little better braking to your tires.. And thats not all.. This game offers something I felt was needed in Racing games again. AI's that while can be ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥s at times.. Are Ones that make you have to read the road a little quicker before making your move. Timing your turns about 2 seconds before you make it or you'll bail out and be executing barrel rolls of joy. (Which Yes Peppy Hare would be very proud of you lol)This game has some of the best graphics i've seen CodeMasters do ever. They are still a company by gamers and for gamers and I'm very glad they brought this literally one of a kind title to Steam & the PC. If you have been wanting a Racing game that will really kick your butt but have you coming back for more This is literally right up your alley. So Grab that Wheel Hit that Gas and get ready for a ride you'll never forget.

number of helpful: 1 of 4 people (25%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 26, 2014
												Not a bad spiritual successor to the original GRID nor the Race Driver games. Features a few different disciplines of racing from touring cars to open wheel and drift cars. While the graphics are clearly from last gen, the lighting is superb and the sound equally matches it. Unfortunately the immersion is completely lost though as each 'season', which consists of only a few races, doesn't really make me feel like I'm accomplishing anything nor developing a reputation with a team. Picking a team to sign on with is literally just about picking the team with the most XP and easiest sponsor goals. If it fleshed out the disciplines a little more with a greater variety and some longevity, and insentive to stick with smaller teams, I feel like it would help develop that element of competition we see so often in real racing. This would also help me commit to one discipline longer as racers don't typically jump from Formula cars to drifters and then back to hot hatch time trials, it all seems a little incoherent.On top of this, the car handling isn't the best. Cars feel very floaty and there's almost no difference in the way each car feels regardless of drive or engine placement. The interior view is also incredibly lackluster; nothing inside the car works and the textures are so incredibly low res that Codemasters has opted to blur it all out.While there are an incredible amount of faults to this game, it is still somehow fun. It has a few cool features as well, such as the 'second screen' mode, which for people with two monitors allows you to have the race standings and a TV-like broadcast of the race featured on your other monitor while you play the game on the primary monitor.It's not worth the initial price of $50, but I'd certainly check it out for $25 or less, especially if you're a fan of other Codie games and are familiar with their arcade quote 'semi-sim' style car games. 7 / 10

content:
Posted: July 1, 2014
												In a racing game in which automobiles are featured, one would expect them to handle like cars. In GRID 2, what you had were not cars, but rather some form of drift mobiles, dressed up to look like some of the world's greatest 4-wheeled racing machines. Codemasters had created the ultimate in arcade environments - sliding was faster than standard cornering. And those who wanted a true-blooded racing sim sequal to the original GRID spoke out. They were not happy.And so Codemasters made THIS game. GRID Autosport. Where cars feel like cars. Where endurance races can require endurance (depending on your option settings). Where winning a race is more than just swinging your car around corners casually whilst daydreaming about what your drifts must look like if not for terrible reply camera angles. This is what GRID 2 should have been.
