number of helpful: 1 of 4 people (25%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 16, 2014
												I want to first start out by saying I have loved a lot of Codemasters racing games. I liked Dirt3 despite it having little to do with actual rally racing. I liked Grid 1 and was unimpressed however by grid 2. The F1 games I adore. Now to Autosport. First the game looks pretty good and has a good balance between realistic and arcade handling. For instance in a Rear wheel drive car, if you apply to much power on a corner exit you are gonna find the back end wanting to overtake the front. Yet it so very easily controlable allowing more relaxed play.The it seems would then play very well, and it does, untill the game adds any number of A.I. cars.The AI in this game is utterly atrocious! When I was following and watching an AI for a number of laps I always noticed he broke at the 150 meter board and I could manage to brake at the 100 meter board. So when I go for the overtake in late braking he suddenly brakes at the 200 meter board and of course me being in his slipstream i crashed right in the back of him. The worse has to be though when the AI is following you. They make the same misjudged break distance but instead the other way. For going into a hairpin after a long straight I would often be barreled into by an AI who would hit the brakes at the 50 meter board and of course run me off the road. Once I return I'd be saddle'd with a pennalty thus ending any kind of a counter attack. All in all a good game simply ruined by AI. If they can fix that, this negative review will be a great one. As there are so many basics the game just had done well. Good tracks, good cars, very cool team systems. and four different disciplines of racing to enjoy... Assuming it was just you on the track.

number of helpful: 1 of 4 people (25%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 26, 2014
												Not a bad spiritual successor to the original GRID nor the Race Driver games. Features a few different disciplines of racing from touring cars to open wheel and drift cars. While the graphics are clearly from last gen, the lighting is superb and the sound equally matches it. Unfortunately the immersion is completely lost though as each 'season', which consists of only a few races, doesn't really make me feel like I'm accomplishing anything nor developing a reputation with a team. Picking a team to sign on with is literally just about picking the team with the most XP and easiest sponsor goals. If it fleshed out the disciplines a little more with a greater variety and some longevity, and insentive to stick with smaller teams, I feel like it would help develop that element of competition we see so often in real racing. This would also help me commit to one discipline longer as racers don't typically jump from Formula cars to drifters and then back to hot hatch time trials, it all seems a little incoherent.On top of this, the car handling isn't the best. Cars feel very floaty and there's almost no difference in the way each car feels regardless of drive or engine placement. The interior view is also incredibly lackluster; nothing inside the car works and the textures are so incredibly low res that Codemasters has opted to blur it all out.While there are an incredible amount of faults to this game, it is still somehow fun. It has a few cool features as well, such as the 'second screen' mode, which for people with two monitors allows you to have the race standings and a TV-like broadcast of the race featured on your other monitor while you play the game on the primary monitor.It's not worth the initial price of $50, but I'd certainly check it out for $25 or less, especially if you're a fan of other Codie games and are familiar with their arcade quote 'semi-sim' style car games. 7 / 10

content:

												Congratulations Codemasters and thank you too all the skilled people at your Team for creating a fun, realistic racing game.From the initial introduction and into the first push of the accelerator its a thrill.  Graphics are not hard on my machine and with the G27 Game wheel its a joy to entertain myself with.  Unlike so many otherracing types games all the cars look familiar, the teams recognised and the tracks brilliant to drive.  Grip and car roll/movement is just like my 12 year old Mitsi so its not like driving a jet around the screen or some 2 tonne monster over ice.  The music is toe tapping between races - the voices very seductive and the allure to loose hours at the tracks should not be understated.I am only season one into the game so fingers crossed it continues to get Tiimii's 2 Thumbs Up !!I look forward to the oncoming DLC'si7 3.4g 16ram SSD 780Evga Gtx 47%GPU load running 60f/s 30%CPU load on 2 cores

												In the pastmost of my racing games have been along the lines of Split Second; BLUR; or even recent NFS games. Not only are there a variation in the kind of competitions youll be in and the cars youll drive, but also the tracks all handle differently and you need to learn to adapt. It is quite a skill to not only go fast, but also to handle your corners correctly.Im so glad that Autoport still has the raceline option as well as the flashback. For begginers like me, these help you find the best way around the track as well as avoid crashes.

number of helpful: 1 of 4 people (25%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 11, 2016
												Sorry to say but after playing the Forza games on console you realise how terribly mediocre this game is.Deathly dull career mode, badly ill-conceived multiplayer system which requires you to laboriously level up each car before you can upgrade it to become competitive with other players.  Unintuitive menu and lobby systems.You can buy your own cars, but each time you buy one, you have to level it up which is tedious and time consuming, and even then, there is NO guarantee you will ever actually get to race it.  Because there are so many different categories of car, WITHIN say the street class.  So you go to a street class race, but you still cannot use YOUR street class car because it's not in the correct sub category which you CANNOT choose, you just get what you're given.  It's a dreadfully designed system. The track minimap doesn't show you anywhere near enough of the track, it is too zoomed in and cannot be changed.  Also the edges are faded which makes it even worse.  You get like half a second advance warning of where the next corner is.  It is almost useless.  By the time you can see the corner on the minimap you can see it in front of you on the road anyway.  Why not copy how other games do it, like Gran Turismo or Forza? Or NFS Shift, where the minimap automatically zooms outwards as you go faster?Overall a very lacklustre and unrewarding game.

content:
Posted: June 30, 2014
												Would be great, BUT... [UPDATED 7/1/2014: SEE BELOW]I'm new to the GRID franchise, however I have heard excellent things about it and decided to jump in here with Autosport. When I first launched the game, wow. I've been a Forza diehard for the past 4 years and this is certainly a change. If you just want to read why I don't recommend, skip to the bottom. Before I go too in depth, here's a list of the pros and cons:Pros- Engaging career mode- Beautiful graphics- Decent physicsCons- 1 BUGI'll begin with the pros. The career is broken into different classes, Tuner, Touring, Endurance, and others. In each class, there are seasons that help you progress along your career as a racer. You'll sign on with different teams, such as Oakley Racing, for the season, you'll get a teammate, rivals, etc. Normal race car driver stuff. Each event (usually, unless it's a special event) has practice (for tuning, if available), qualifying, and one to two races. I found this to be much more fun than the career of Forza, where the races were short, limited, and very boring. I have yet to try online but we'll get to why in a minute.The graphics are gorgeous. At full tilt, it looks pretty real. Just be careful about your computer's proccessing power. It'll give it a run for its money.Physics are ok. I have yet to get into the higher classes to see if grip really becomes a factor. Something does feel slightly off...BUG REPORT BELOW [FIXED - SEE UPDATE]"OK, so why didn't you try online?"Great question! There's a bug... And if it wasn't for this bug, I would highly recommend this game. There is a bug that causes a screen "freeze" where the car and audio freeze for about half a second at random on all graphics levels. "Why's that such a huge deal?" Glad you asked. Every second counts in a race. So, if you're going through a technical, winding, difficult turn and suddenly everything just glitches out, you're focus is broken. This bug will work itself out, but it starts the race again before the screen can catch up. So you'll hear the car move (and incidently go off the track or hit other cars) before you can see it. "So what does that have to do with online racing?" This glitch freezes your car. In a tight race, where it's bumper to bumper, turn for turn, close quarter racing, a sudden stop ruins it for everyone. I may not feel the effects besides the glitch, but I'll inadvertently make everyone else despise me.To sum it all up, great game that needs MAJOR bug fixing. The core of the game is great, however that one bug disastorously effects the gameplay, making it almost unplayable. If I was a potential buyer, I would wait until there has been a patch and one that has been reviewed as a proper fix.Computer Specs: Toshiba Satellite P50, Windows 8.1 64-bit, intel i7-47000MQ @2.4GHz, 16GB (8+8) RAM plus 2GB NVidia GeForce GTM 740M: driver version 340.43 (beta)[UPDATE] I tried uninstalling and then reinstalling the game and now it works fine. It must've been a glitch that occured during "pre-loading" when I preordered the game. Now I fully recommend the game!

content:
Posted: June 29, 2014
												At first I was quite disappointed that the vehicle interior view was not detailed like we have in Assetto Corsa and Project Cars even though I realise that this is sold as a game rather than a simulator.I regretted my pre-purchase as it seems like a lot of money but thought I'd give it a little time before throwing it away just in case I was missing the point.I've got all of the simulation titles and racing games on my PC, PS3 and XBox360 and now I have to say that this is the most fun and addictive of the lot.I'm giving it a 10/10 as it is just so immersive and so much fun racing against great AI with beutiful tracks and scenery and a great feel for those using a wheel.11 hours in two days is a huge amount of time for me to spend on a game but I just couldn't turn it off regardless of the consequences :-)I'm driving with a Fanatec CSR Elite Wheel and Pedals so I can't comment on game play with a controller but with my wheel, this is the best.Love it, love it, love it.One of my best purchases ever.

content:
Posted: June 30, 2014
												If you like pure arcade racers this is perhaps one to avoid. I don't mind an element of sim-like controls and can just about cope with the physics - but it's more a learning experience than pure unbridled pleasure. But the graphics are great, the multiplayer hangs together very well and there's a real feeling of accomplishment if you manage to podium. There's also an awful lot to do with 5 main disciplines and several levels of racing within each. 7/10

number of helpful: 0 of 2 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 30, 2014
												I'm not exactly what you would call a racing game fan. Don't get me wrong I've played my fair share of racers back in the day (oh wow that sentence made me feel oooooold). NFS (3-till Most Wanted), Burnout and even Codemasters very own TOCA and Colin Mcrae series. Despite this the only racing games that got my attention for more than a week or two were NFS: Porsche Unleashed and Project Gotham Racing 3 (god-tier games). Well you can safely add GRID: Autosport to that list. Even though I've just started the game I can already tell that I will love the hell out of it. As is with all Codemasters racers, G:A has a handling model that struts the line between simulation and arcade styles. It has great A.I. that, you know, actually races instead of just acting as barely animate objects for you to pass. Heck this is the first time I've felt an actual desire to beat a particular team of rival racers (damn you Ravenwest, you smug a-holes!). Oh and the menu is sliiiiiick. Can't really tell how online is gonna pan out but I can already tell I will get my money's worth just from the career mode alone. In conclusion: I would recommend GRID: Autosport to anyone looking for a straight forward, no nonsense racer.

content:
Posted: June 30, 2014
												I played a lot of Dirt 3 on xbox. I've played even more on PC after buying a wheel set. This game very much reminds me of the road equivalent to the Dirt series. It's not *so* realistic on it's easier settings that I struggle to play it, so dialing down the settings toward a harder difficulty makes it feel like I'm working and actually accomplishing something.The game has a "team" dynamic to it, where every season (collection of races) you choose a sponsor and race with team mates. The objectives are great because there are a bunch of them each race, and some for the season.In most racing games I'm left restarting a race to beat it every single time I barely come in second or crash in the first corner. Grid makes me feel like I'm "accomplishing" something even if I place 6th in a race or 4th overall, like it's part of my career.It's not a replacement for Forza or GT in the sense that you don't acquire a garage full of cars that you individually tune and buy parts for. Each race you have a practice period on the track if you choose to use it, as well as a qualifying portion if you choose. Or you can just jump straight into the race.So far I am really enjoying the game, probably because the physics remind me so much of Dirt. One con for sure is that the driving lines are absolutely terrible. I wouldn't hesitate to recommend this to anyone for full price - maybe because I've purchased WAY worse games for $60, let alone $50. Overall I'm satisfied.

content:
Posted: June 24, 2014
												First impressions: This is the game we should have gotten instead of GRiD 2.  Includes the fun, eye candy, and variety we expect from "Codies" but is much less an arcade racer.  Instead of magic-skidding around corners a la GRiD 2, you'll have to pay attention to tire wear.  Overall, this is game more interesting and difficult version of the original GRiD.  They borrowed some elements from their F1 games as well; Practice, qualifying, and tuning are things you can skip, but doing them well will help you in the race.I have only played GRiD Autosport for a little bit, but I am already very impressed.  Little things like the high detail texture add-on DLC (free), lots of control of graphics options, and even the choice of seeing (or removing) the in-game wheel shows me how much they are listening to the fans on this one.  Also, the difficulty is highly customizable with rewards for turning off assists.  Finally, for GRiD 1 fans, I have not yet observed homicidal AI [Edit: It was hiding] nor any "rubber-banding."

number of helpful: 3 of 9 people (33%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 25, 2014
												Grid Autosport is Codemaster's latest attempt to bring the Grid series back to its roots and right the wrongs done by Grid 2. In my opinion, Grid Autosport has left the past two iterations of the series in the dust and has instead, pointed the series in a bold new direction. The game feels more mature, with a slick menu system, a host of official real world tracks and above all, a heavy focus on the competitive world of motorsports. Even more enjoyable is the re-tuned driving system and the sim-cade like handing of the many cars in the game. Autosport finally ditches the drift style turning of the first two games. Cars stick to the tarmac and grip is easy to find. This is especially evident in the open-wheeled dicipline, my favorite in the game. The cockpit view returns to Grid, and although it may lack detail, it is a welcome edition to the game. Content-wise, there is a lot of racing to be done. Most races can be completed in less than five minutes, with the exception of endurance races which test your patience and your ability to maintain a quickly wearing set of tires. All five of the diciplines feel unique and even more impressive is the fact that the AI behaves differently in each. Qualifying is back in the game, along with a practce mode for tracks that you may not be familiar with. Expect to take part in drift events and time attacks as well. Do not hesitate to pick this one up. It is a great find in a genre that is heavily ignored on Steam. Codemaster's clearly made this game for the fans who felt that Grid 2 didn't stand up to the legacy of quality the developer is known for. Grid Autosport is the Forza or Gran Turismo of the PC, I like it that much.

content:
Posted: November 7, 2015
GRID Autosport, another racing game by CodeMasters, is aesthetically pleasing, and feels genuine. GAMEPLAY:Like I've said, this game is very difficult; partners, they're more than useless, so be prepared to carry your 'mate, as I know I had to. The physics in this game are nice, you have to slow down/stop at the right point (something that can't really be said about the NfS series). Drifting is not non-existant, however, it's just not used much, due to the maps. Some of the vehicles (mainly trucks) are a real pain to play with, as the bars get in your way, due to this, you can't see much.STORY:You, the driver, are paired with a sponsor; sponsors work like you'd think. Each sponsor gives different benefits, you pick the one that you think would benefit you the most. Once you've picked your main sponsor, you're thrown into the amazing world of GRID. Race until you've gotten to 'Level 5' of your sponsor, do this until you've done so with the other sponsors (Level 3 is needed for the GRID Prix). If you do too well, the co-host will tell you to turn it up, assuming you're playing on a lower level.GRAPHICS:Let's get this clear; the game is not the best in terms of graphics (like Project Cars), but it is aesthetically pleasing to the eye. The graphics are by no means bad, hell, they've implemented 4k support (thanks CM). OVERALL:A racing game for enthusiasts, or for fans of racing games. Winning feels like more like a reward, rather than just text on a screen. Gives a challenge, and the difficulty settings allow for even more of a challenge. There ARE few cons (that I can see), such as white line penalties, small selection of music, optimization could have been better, the prices ($40 for this, I can't say it's worth that much), so forth.9/10This game is FUN, however: the vehicles are clunky, making it hard to maneuver, the DLC shouldn't be here (...no), lack of weather effects (snow, rain, lightning, the like), etc. It DOES get the racing part mostly right, it doesn't jeer off, and it does feel genuine.

content:
Posted: September 28, 2014
												Good fun with your friends! The game has solo, multiplayer and splitscreen options. Invite some friends and you can have a blast together. It has good graphics (effects) and with the High Res mod (free) it looks good.Runs smooth, good optimisation and fairly easy to play even without assists.Some cars are interestng some not so much but there is a good selection so everyone will find a suitable one. Would be nice if you could mix up classes based on same performance (you can only play one class at a time) . Or even better put up a series of events with different classes like the old toca games. Anyway the wheel support is there but dont expect pCars or Assetto Corsa like FFB and generally the game lacks feedback on the wheel. With gamepad its fine, it seems the game is optimised more towards the gamepads anyway. But that is okay since you jump in and have a quick arcade race. Do a long endurance race or do few laps but you will have fun time within the game ,regardless. I also suggest to get the season pass since it includes some more variety and brings back the old Touring cars! The multiplayer seems pretty dead by now. But if bunch of friends get the game its fine to put in some AI drivers (on hard and very hard they are agressive but still playable) to complete the racing grid. This also gives the game some bit of challange since the AI on very hard drives very quick and it is challenging to overtake them. If you like arcade racers with bits of realism go grab it ,you wont regret it!

content:
Posted: April 22, 2016
												Its not a bad game. But is not what you are looking for probably. This isn't your arcade racing game where you can buy cars and race. If you were looking for something like gran turismo, or need for speed without being open world and requiring actual skill, DONT BUY THIS. This isn't the usual racing game where you buy a car, you race with said car, get money, get a better car and rinse repeat. In this game you have teams where you get a bot (A.K.A "teammate") assigned to you and you have to compete as a team. A bot that is going to ruin your fun because he sucks and knocks you ot of the race or things like that.As said, this isn't a bad game neccesairly, but its THE grid experince, NOT a racing experience.Sidenotes:-bots have an insane grip on the asphalt, you can't make them spin out, they will only spin out when they want to spin out-multiplayer is basically dead-multiplayer is severly unfair when there are only a few hundred players online because your cars gain xp and you unlock upgrades and tuning options for your car via that. Bear in mind, every car has its own xp bar, each starting from zero-there are a ton of cars ingame, but there are disciplines and categories, you can't use every car everywhere. 1 car is only usable in 1 category in 1 discipline. So that means its really easy to find a match where you can't use the car you just bought.-in singleplayer you dont have a garage. your team gives you the cars you have to race with and the tuning options and upgrades depend on said team.As stated, its not a bad game, its just probably not what you're looking for, unless you are looking for grid autosport specifically. Dont be surprised when this game disappoints you because you didn't expect this. Just like me, i asked on the forums if this is what im looking for, nobody gave an answer that had anything to do with my question.

number of helpful: 1 of 5 people (20%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 27, 2014
												This is a game which appeals to those who are fans of racing and motorsport. Codemasters seem to have nailed the sweet spot this time - perhaps more so than GRID 2. Let's begin with the driving. When most games try to do "simulation", this usually translates into unnecessarily dull driving with plenty of understeer, no sense of speed, the inability to drift and the inability to turn while braking. In Autosport, you still get the excitement and sharp handling of GRID 2 but with a lot more control. You can really tell a car's limits jsut from the vibration and tyre noise. I'd describe it as a perfect balance - it's deep but still fun and intuitive. For someone that plays a lot of racing games, I usually find that in some games, you are disadvantaged by not using assists, whereas in this game, turning of all assists and using manual gears is actually rewarding rather than punishing. Whilst GRID 2 was more like a Project Gotham Racing clone, Autosport is more like a Racedriver game. Whilst there is a strong emphasis on teams, the core gameplay experience doesn't feel diluted or pushed aside by unnecessary stats, menus and artificial babble. The main selling point of this game is CHOICE. You can do all the cool street racing and drifts in exotic tuners and supercars, or you can go for a more hardcore time attack approach around tracks or do some endurance racing in touring cars and such. There are five distinct disciplines which cater for a wide audience; and is something I've personally wanted to see as a racing game fan. No longer do I have to go to a separate game for each kind of experience - you can get all the racing you want in one complete package. It's just very much pick-up-and-play. Weekly challenges return in online mode, where you have a target to beat in each of the disciplines. Want to just set a fast lap time with Bronze Silver Gold Platinum to aim for? You can. Want to get an awesome drift going? you can. From street racing to track racing to demolition derby, this game has it all. It is a very high quality game in every sense, from optimisation, game engine and lack of glitches to robust mechanics and controls. The game is highly accessible to those who have little experience in racing games with a plethora of assists and difficulty options, but also gives more seasoned veterans the chance to earn more XP by using fewer assists, higher AI difficulty, less flashbacks etc. There's not much clutter here. You can tune your car, but in a similar manner to DiRT 2 and 3. Just a 5-point slider with short explanations. The only complaint I have is that of interior view. Not only is it the worst I've ever seen in terms of the camera angle, but there is ZERO detail (see screenshots), it's just black. This is dssappointing as this was my major issue with GRID 2. If you can overlook this minor flaw, you will find high quality racing game which is more about what happens on the track than the menus.

number of helpful: 1 of 5 people (20%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 27, 2014
												This is a game which appeals to those who are fans of racing and motorsport. Codemasters seem to have nailed the sweet spot this time - perhaps more so than GRID 2. Let's begin with the driving. When most games try to do "simulation", this usually translates into unnecessarily dull driving with plenty of understeer, no sense of speed, the inability to drift and the inability to turn while braking. In Autosport, you still get the excitement and sharp handling of GRID 2 but with a lot more control. You can really tell a car's limits jsut from the vibration and tyre noise. I'd describe it as a perfect balance - it's deep but still fun and intuitive. For someone that plays a lot of racing games, I usually find that in some games, you are disadvantaged by not using assists, whereas in this game, turning of all assists and using manual gears is actually rewarding rather than punishing. Whilst GRID 2 was more like a Project Gotham Racing clone, Autosport is more like a Racedriver game. Whilst there is a strong emphasis on teams, the core gameplay experience doesn't feel diluted or pushed aside by unnecessary stats, menus and artificial babble. The main selling point of this game is CHOICE. You can do all the cool street racing and drifts in exotic tuners and supercars, or you can go for a more hardcore time attack approach around tracks or do some endurance racing in touring cars and such. There are five distinct disciplines which cater for a wide audience; and is something I've personally wanted to see as a racing game fan. No longer do I have to go to a separate game for each kind of experience - you can get all the racing you want in one complete package. It's just very much pick-up-and-play. Weekly challenges return in online mode, where you have a target to beat in each of the disciplines. Want to just set a fast lap time with Bronze Silver Gold Platinum to aim for? You can. Want to get an awesome drift going? you can. From street racing to track racing to demolition derby, this game has it all. It is a very high quality game in every sense, from optimisation, game engine and lack of glitches to robust mechanics and controls. The game is highly accessible to those who have little experience in racing games with a plethora of assists and difficulty options, but also gives more seasoned veterans the chance to earn more XP by using fewer assists, higher AI difficulty, less flashbacks etc. There's not much clutter here. You can tune your car, but in a similar manner to DiRT 2 and 3. Just a 5-point slider with short explanations. The only complaint I have is that of interior view. Not only is it the worst I've ever seen in terms of the camera angle, but there is ZERO detail (see screenshots), it's just black. This is dssappointing as this was my major issue with GRID 2. If you can overlook this minor flaw, you will find high quality racing game which is more about what happens on the track than the menus.

May sound impossible, but it just was.Seriously pi**ed that I paid even the discounted £6 for this pile of.......grrrr!Addition due to comments received:Words in anger my friends. Words in anger, but I stand solidly behind that initial review!!!!Terrible AI! (They are on a pre-determined path which makes overtaking on the inside line impossible if near a corner and you CANNOT spin or damage them but they seriously f**ck you up on any contact unless you are too soft to have all the assists off)Terrible attempt at arcade handling (Vehicles handle like milk floats, then a corner comes up and they turn into boats sailing along invisible water)Skitzy code (AI 'wobble' or skip a few frames at time, disappearing then reappearing a few feet ahead where they should be and not my hardware related, believe me)No calibration support for steering wheels leaving a floating zone of about half a foot between steering left and right before the vehicle reacts.Blurry first person view.....was a warning sign of shoddy programming!I dont give a sh*t if people buy this game, I am not swaying anyone away from it, but for the first time I saw the pics and vids of this and bought it without reading the reviews and BAM, lesson learned. Most are negative as well from reading before posting mine! Seriously, TOCA on the Playstation all those years ago was incredible compared to this.....and this is just a rushed game to make a few pennies. Horrendous!

number of helpful: 12 of 28 people (43%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 24, 2014
												GRID Autosport promised to be a combination of all things great about GRID and GRID 2, which of course sparked a great bit of hype for Codemaster's upcoming racing game, and I myself went as far as to preorder the game with high expectations. I had enjoyed GRID 2 with my friends for countless hours, and a unification of both games sounded to me like what would be the greatest racing experience for the PC. Codemasters truly did do a great job combining the two games and Autosport boasts fantastic graphics and gameplay mechanics. However, to the dismay of it's fanbase, they had actually subtracted one of the better features of the game with the addition of the disciplinary and vehicle class systems for races. One of the best parts about GRID 2 was the ability to use any car of the event's tier you had desired. There's amazing hilarity and joy in racing an X-bow against a GT-R, and going head to head with racers of all disciplines and varieties, but in GRID Autosport, players are restricted to use class specific vehicles in races, for example, from 20 available cars for a drift event in GRID 2 down to a measely 3 in Autosport. There is no challenge against other players. I love the GRID franchise, but Autosport's discipline system really kills the enjoyment of racing with friends. I sincerely hope and pray that Codemasters considers returning the Tier system or implementing a type of Free Class for multiplayer matches in a upcoming patch or downloadable content to return GRID Online to it's most enjoyable state.

number of helpful: 1 of 6 people (17%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 4, 2014
												Codemasters quickly recycles the widely panned and commercially unsuccessful GRID 2 into GRID AutoSport, the third title in the franchise.While the physics and handling have been mercifully changed from drifty to grippy, almost everything remains the same; limited number of maps, never-ending menu pages and options, insufferable lobby wait times and regional locking in multiplayer matches that prevents players from finding each other without Steam 'download region' manipulation.Multiplayer matches are often lag-ridden disasters and are almost always marred by collisions (both accidental and deliberate) despite long standing complaints and suggestions for improvement from the Codemaster customer base.  A painful grind through neverending levels of cars, disciplines and options was soon to be revealed as nothing more than a sinister DLC scheme with the release of the "XP Boost Pack" that promises to alleviate the pain of progressing through this game.  With yet more DLC coming soon from this unapologetic publisher, other aggravating elements of this game will likely be revealed as little more than deliberate problems designed to attract the player to purchasable solutions.Luckily enough for racing genre fans, Codemasters will finally face serious competition later this year with the full release of Assetto Corsa, Project Cars and 'Next Car Game,' all titles that will hopefully realize that racing fans would like to spend more time on the track than in menus and lobbies and once they have purchased the game, they'd appreciate not having to pay more to dodge its worst elements.

Posted: August 10, 2014
												Best racing game on the market for car people and anyone who loves cars. The graphics are great. The gameplay is better. This game really nails having a feel for the car. I can drift, go fast whatever and never feel like its super "arcadey". The cars feel natural. This game balances simulator and arcade racer very well.  My favorite racing physics engine in a long time. Makes it fun to drive for hours and hours. Solid  online community of great racers. But sometimes it can be hard to find a game through matchmaking so I rely on my list of friends ive met playing/racing, the club system by codemasters, and the community pages to find quality online racing lobbies.

content:
Posted: July 11, 2014
												Autosport had a lot of potential. It's a deliberate step towards a more serious racing game, and brought a lot of features that fans wanted. The game looks brilliant on paper, with a superb selection of cars, better physics, a new AI and glittering graphics. Sadly the reality is, it's a very technologically impressive game but not very enjoyable to play.Autosport, at several different levels, feels like a game trying to be something it isn't. It advertises itself as a hardcore driver's game, and yet plays like an Arcade Racer. It feels outdated as well; the graphics are outstanding, but the AI and physics feel years behind the competition. If it was priced accordingly, it would be a big hit. Unfortunately, it's priced as a AAA title, which it very much isn't.The driving Physics just don't match the game Codemasters were trying to create. Autosport feels like an Arcade racer; not even a Simcade, but a full Arcade game. Cars drift effortlessly almost by themselves, pull insane G-forces and reach ludicrous speed on the straights. I don't mind stylisation, but selling Autosport as a "hardcore simcade" is like pretending Mariokart 8 is a Formula 1 team's simulator.The AI feels much the same as the physics. This isn't a proper circuit-racing AI; it doesn't behave at all like a racing driver, with no thought to rules or self-preservation. It's extremely aggressive, and will frequently ram you for no apparent reason. It also shows some significant perception-related bugs: it will occasionally drive into solid objects at full-throttle apparently unaware that they're even there.

content:
Posted: April 19, 2015
												++++Shiny graphicssimple menus------You have to slow down too much to make any turns without flying off the road. That's no fun. Otherwise handling felt very good.Courses were bland. Where are all the races OUTSIDE the tracks? Who wants to drive on track all the time?Codemasters doesn't value your time. I learned this after trying to play online. 1) To find any players, you must change your download server setting under steam to UK-London.2) No easy jump in/play multiplayer3) long multiplayer load screens / waits for other playersI'm a big arcade racing fan, and I like high speed but I just couldn't find myself enjoying this game due to the issues I had listed above. I'm not going to spend any more time trying to force myself to enjoy this.If you're interested in tryinng out the gameplay yourself before purchase, I'd suggest looking at one of the older Codemasters games on discount. The handling hasn't changed much.I'd recommend instead: Blur, Sonic and All Stars Racing Transformed, Mario Kart series, NFS Hot Pursuit 2010, Burnout Paradise, NFS The Run, NFS Most Wanted 2012.

content:
Posted: April 4, 2015
												GRID Autosport has been one of my favorite racing games for a pretty long while now. That being said, I don't recommend this faulty software for anything over $15.There are countless instances of saved games being corrupted irrecoverably. My first save profile was suddenly corrupted, making it useless. All of my time spent on my profile, all of the cars that I've worked months and months to buy, since you can only get a new garage slot after leveling up. This gets to be a MAJOR grind, especially when you've done it before. After I started the game up, I found my latest profile, which was even more accomplished than my previous corrupted one to be corrupted. I shouldn't need to back up the very hard to locate save file every time I start the game. This has made be very disappointed, because GRID Autosport's gameplay (multiplayer in particular) is rather fun and has kept me interested for many many many hours. Hours that gone now for good.Codemasters, the publisher of the game did promise a fix for the save corruption back in November 2014. It doesn't work.Here's my bottom line advice: If you want the game, don't buy it on steam. You might want a refund at some point. Steam doesn't even answer help tickets anymore, and would never give a refund for what I perceive to be a DEAL-BREAKING defective product. I definitely wish I could get a refund, as I play games expecting them to not remove 900 hours of playing put in.If I was to play GRID Autosport again, I have no cars, no money to buy cars, not enough garage slots for even 5 cars. It would take me a long time of playing to get back to where I was, and here is what it comes down to: it's not worth the time. The game isn't good enough to be allowed to steal my time.I don't recommend this game due to a major defect that has persisted for years now. Fixes were promised, never delivered.On the other hand, if you find the game on sale, and you're not too serious about racing, it's a fun game that is twice as expensive at it should be allowed to be.

content:
Posted: December 10, 2015
												Ok you people gonna hate and dislike it , but yet i'll just tell what i felt by playing .. thisFirstly , freezes and lag into the main menu. Sounds good for the beginning. Then after finally set my controller , i passed into graphics options and tried to set it. Then i ran a benchmark ... All ok ... Until it started drop from 200 FPS to ... 10-15 fps with freeze and lags. Such great. I also noticed you can't go back on desktop, the only way is to force it ctrl+alt+suppr and task manager. Then the gayme will set in windowed mode , and i didn't achieved to put it back in fullscreen , ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ settings didn't worked.Ok then , let's have a look to the career mode. First race , dropped into a car. Game decided to cancel my controller command and switch back on keyboard. Ok , ok , ♥♥♥♥ing game but i relaunch the race. Just to discover i'm stuck into a blurry dark non working interior with not a single working gauge. The only way for me to know if i was in a good gear or not was the screaming of the motor after a sharp turn. Oh wait , i got something more fun ! Let's remove sound ! Indeed , after completed 1 turn , the engine sound just vanished. Purely no way to tell if i was still going forward or not.So after that , and after watching the ♥♥♥♥ed up reflection effect and other weird textures, i finally completed the race.All this combined let me a pretty bad feel about the game. So yes , starting a raceday. AGAIN , a ♥♥♥♥ing non working interrior , no way to tell which speed or gear i'm currently driving. So after a last spinning after a turn because i switched - without knowing it - into neutral , and finished into the grass , i just clicked the red cross (Because still no way to put it fullscreen).Unfinished game , with ugly textures , bad sounds and ♥♥♥♥ed up mechanics.Let's summarize itCONS- Bad sound- meh graphics- ♥♥♥♥♥♥ reflects again , Codemaster signature- NO WORKING INTERIOR AND NO GAUGES- Weird menu- FPS Drops and lags- Windowed bugged- Can't leave benchmark mode- dlcPRO- Uh ... Got cars ?I would've refund immediatly if i bought it on the Store and not on Humble Bundle. I regret i waste 10mn pluging and updating my PS3 controllers pilots. Another Codemaster crap.

Posted: September 3, 2016
												I pre-order this game and have been trying to get a refund ever since.Please, do not buy this horrible game. The AI is some of the worst that I've ever seen. The cars handling in the game is very bad to be realistic feeling, and on top of that you can't custimize your difficulty level that well.I absolutely loved grid 2d which was why I pre-ordered this game to see what this company was capable of and if they would meet my expectations. Not only did they not meet my expectations, they have lost my trust as a customer. I don't have that to say about many games but owning this game literally offends me because it is that bad and was that broken on release.I can't tell you if they have made any changes to this game, but I will say to buy this at your own risk or to just not buy it at all. If you want a racing game forza is now coming out for PC on windows so just buy that instead it will be a much better product, hell this isn't even a product I'd call it a scam.I don't have many no recommendations to hand out as usually I'm a pretty fair and unbiased critic and can cearly state the ups and downs of a game. The only ups this game has is looking pretty and nothing else.If you really want a racing game that is fun and has its own unique style of racing then try out Grid 2, that game is amazing.If you want a similation racing game then just wait for Forza to come to PC, and I think the beta is free to participate in right now as well.Do yourself a favor and do not buy this game.

content:
Posted: July 10, 2015
												I don't know what to freaking say about this game other than Dirt 3 is a GREAT alternative that doesn't cause anywhere near the same amount of frustration.Fun aspects:+ Feels like driving a car on a track sort of+ Good force feedback on a Logitech G27+ Fun to throw supercars on a time trial track and just driveNot fun aspects:- The AI accelerate faster than you off the line- You're usually in 16th so it takes laps to catch up (your event rival is sometimes in 1st even)- You have the beat the rival in 4-6 lap races -_-- Even if you win, your team never does because your teammate SUCKS- Ravenwest drivers do some physically impossible stuff (ie higher speed cornering, not damaging etc)- The driver that flipped over can be seen in your mirror catching up to you at twice your speed- No consistency with FPS on different events (have to constantly mess with graphics settings)Really not fun aspects:-- Penalty forces you to drive super slow-- The driver behind you suddenly touches your bumper causing you to spin into the grass then get a penalty-- The driver in front suddenly brakes causing you to try and stop into him then spin into the grass getting a penalty-- The driver behind ignores your existence in a turn and pushes you off-- The AI constantly ram through you because their cars push like twice the boost yours does?-- Everyone's got the same car as you AND STILL ACCELERATES FASTER THAN YOU GAAAAAAHI still recommend because I don't mind playing it in small amounts. It makes me want to throw my G27 out the window if I play it too long.

content:
Posted: August 7, 2015
												I already own and play Project Cars, Assetto Corsa, good old Grand Prix Legends, Dirt Rally, etc and I find this game really fun and kind of relaxing in between sessions of the other more sim like games.  Really fun and looks great if you download the high res texture pack.  If you have a GeForce card definitely use the "GeForce Experience" and "optimize" the game, this should set the resolution to 2715x1527dsr (dynamic sampling resolution) then just reduce the Multisampling in game from 8xMSAA to 4xMSAA (it's in the options menu) and Voila 60fps or better even in smoke and looks absolutely awesome!!! P.S.  I have a MSI GTX 770 4 gig, 4790k, win 7, so anything as good or better should rock!

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: October 2, 2016
												I’ll first say that the biggest problem with this Grid game is that it is horribly confused.  I can’t, for one, imagine what the goal of the design team at Codemasters was on about with this one.  The first Grid Game was a clear step away from the simulation like TOCA games (while retaining some realistic physics), which seemed designed for the interested car enthusiast who knew of Le Mans and Touring Cars, but didn’t want to fiddle with transmission set-ups or differentials.  The second game (Grid 2) was a lean towards the tuner/Need for Speed crowd.  Grid 2 wasn’t bad—but wouldn’t you rather just get a Need for Speed game if that was your thing?  So, this game, however, seems born terminally confused about where to fit in on this spectrum of realism: from TOCA 3 to Grid to Grid 2/Need for Speed.  So on the one hand, it has got (arguably) more realistic physics and car models than in the original Grid, with, in turn, more of a harden focus on racing.  And it does seem almost like a call back to a game like TOCA 3 (one of my personal favs).  But, on the other hand, here’s where it really grinds my gears, so to speak.  It’s decidedly not for car people—actually.  It assumes you know something about racing, but it gives you numbers and bars for car stats.  You don’t get to see horsepower ratings or weight measurements, etc., nope.  Not for you.  The game kind of assumes you know about oversteer, understeer, what different drive types do for handling, and about touring cars and open wheel, and various different race real-world tracks, tire blowouts, racing lines and car damage, and semi-realistic physics, but realistic stats?--I guess not.  Its kind of indicative of the entire games problem.  It doesn’t understand its audience.  It holds back.  Another example of this is Codemasters did everything in their power to replicate real race cars and tracks, but allowed no options for you to race with anything like real racing rules or penalties.  It should at least be an option for those more inclined right?  They should satiate the fantasy of a more hardcore crowd if they are going to get us pumped for at least somewhat realistic racing! Right?  I know this is not F1 or anything, but it is a little weird they went so far, and yet still thought it might be too complex or something.   Another example is Codemasters poor handling of endurance racing—which is a cool idea—but its just not an effective game mechanic.  The tire wear mechanic is isolated to one part of the game, so what you learn in the endurance racing part of the game is irrelevant in other racing events.  Its awkward and entirely oversimplefied, and a real shame, because Le Mans endurance racing in Grid was so tense and dramatic (you raced a course for 24 white-knuckled hours, luckily this only meant 24 minutes in game, but it was still quite intense).  Unfortunately, endurance racing in Autosport just doesn’t capture that same feeling, and it is hampered by a poor and underdeveloped tire game mechanic, which is not realistic or fun.  Luckily, the other racing types are uneffected.However, I will give the thumbs up to Autosport, because it is a step in the right direction.  It may be a bit confused, and you might be a little bit disappointed if your have more sim interests in this genre, but  it does do the mechanics of how a car corners and drives well.  It by no means is super-realistic, but it does allow us enthusiasts who love cars and racing to have some fun, while not feeling like millions of hours of mastery and a technical manual are needed to compete in the game.  Its probably for those of us who have a gamepad, but not a wheel.  Not to say that you couldn’t do this game with a wheel, but if you have a wheel—you probably already have more intense games than this.  The good news is its not Need for Speed.  And that’s good news after the likes of Grid 2.  And it is certainly more realistic and sensible than Dirt 3.  At the very least, the game has realistic premises and racing revolving around real cars and somewhat real physics.  But, bare in mind, the game leaves you absent from team management, any kind of realistic tuning, and the buying and selling of cars.  Which are sad things to see go from the original Grid—ironically, the game I consider a be a notch bellow this when it comes to realistic car physics.  But, with all that said, this is a good start.  It just happens to be one of those games that comes so close to greatness—you want to hate it, just a little, now and then for what it could have been.  One step further into the car and racing world would have cemented it.  A more immersive atmosphere, with better mechanics and racing pedigree, would have made it perfect.  Right now it is a good car game, with decent AI and physics, that has some oddly casual pretensions in some areas—so it can seem like it is missing key features at times.  But, I do enjoy firing up a Cat B Touring Car for a spin now and then.  It revs throaty and the track feels good under the tires.

content:
Posted: October 11, 2015
												Many people want a realistic racing simulation, not a racing game.Codemasters tries to please everyone, it's a nice challenge but it actually makes frustrations in both worlds, nothing technically overwhelming though.Pros:- Mostly good physics- Mostly good graphics and sounds - Mostly good UI (nice and smooth)- Wide variety of cars and circuits- Many settings available- Upcoming Linux supportGameplay cons:- Hugely annoying inrace slowdown due to penalty (Most stupid decision ever that ruins the game)Physics cons:- Lack of friction that leads to lack of grip- Steering soap effect partially corrigible with settingsGraphics cons:- Not readable dashboard in the cockpit view- No cockpit rendering when looking sideways- Geometry of cars not detailed enough- Skid marks sometimes buggyUI cons:- Too many useless choices at the begining (waste of time)- Awkward sequence: choice of discipline, then choice of circuit, then choice of car- Very slow loading of cars during selectionSuggestions to Codemasters:- Use a button to switch the focus and make the dashboard readable- Allow access to the speed information during the replay- Don't stop the replay when the user switch to another application- I'm a code master, contact me if you have any question ;-)

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: October 4, 2015
												Yo.Now (when I'm doing this "review") I only have 13 hours of this game. But I've played Grid 2 for a + or - 110 hours, and I still prefer the Grid 2..The physics of this game are a bit "strong" compared with Grid 2, and the developers made this game (Autosport) a bit more hard. I use to play Grid 2 and Autosport in medium and you notice a difference between them.Some PROS of this game COMPARED with Grid 2:  In Autosport:     - You have cockpit view (camera, whatever);     - You have, I guess, more challenges;     - You have now + or -  a thorough car customization;Some CONS of this game COMPARED with Grid 2:  In Autosport:     - Like I said before, the physics changed to worse;     - The tracks are a bit boring;     - You have practically the same cars here and in Grid 2. The developers didn't put many new cars in the game!!And yeah, thats it, probably I'll update this post..Sorry for any English mistake..(y)WrAp3r,

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: January 24, 2015
												Pretty much TOCA 4. If you disliked the GRiD/DiRT switch and found F1 and GRiD 2 to be a disgrace, you'll probably love this. You get a bunch of cars, from WTCC, DTM, Supercars, UTES, F3, Indycar and prototypes that you can race on lots of road and city tracks, day or night, reverse and alternate layouts. It doesn't feature the rallycross and other half♥♥♥♥♥♥♥trucks and rally stages, so it focuses a bit more than older TOCAs. Looks pretty amazing, with great performance on lower hardware, tight controls with basic car setup options to fix any issues, great track models, variety, a custom championship mode with lots of options, but only 5 events. The AI can get pretty fast for a good challenge, but it hits you pretty often, causing you penalties and spins even when there's a lot of room to pass cleanly, so that's annoying. The car interiors are terrible, but I prefer the dashboard view, which is perfect for visibility and feel, like in the NASCAR games.  Had some problems, like the save game disappearing, certain options being reset, and obviously it wouldn't be a modern Codemasters game if they didn't chop off some tracks and cars to be sold separately. It's a shame, but it doesn't detract from the fact that this is their most solid game in over ten years. Too bad their reputation will keep players away. Never expected to like this game so much? 5-lap battle for 3rd place at Bathurst in a DTM Audi, hardest difficulty and no assists? Yes, please. That was awesome.

content:
Posted: September 29, 2015
												GRID Autosport is a pretty good game.I wouldn't say it's amazing, but it's certainly not terrible either.  The AI have their flaws, and some aspects of the game get on my nerves at times.  I'd still recommend it to anyone who's a fan of racing games though.  This is more of an arcade racer than a simulator in my opinion.  You don't get to do much of any customization to your vehicles like you do in something like Forza Motorsport on the Xbox 360.  Some teams that you can race for allow you to tune your car (a little, or a lot depending on the team), but you can't change your colors, decals, vinyls, etc.From an Achievement Hunter standpoint, this is a very grindy game, in that many of the achievements require a lot of repitition and grinding to unlock.  Some of them also require DLC, and the multiplayer achievements will be VERY hard to unlock, seeing as not too many people play the multiplayer anymore (sadly).All in all, it's not terrible, but it's not outstanding either.  If you can try it before you buy it, that might be wise.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: September 29, 2015
												Well, there is a lot i dont like about this game, so il start with what i do. I like that the driving model seems to lean more towards sim than previous Grid games. The braking model still needs a lot of work, but its moving in the right  direction. I also like that its one of the few games that actually acknowlege drift as a valid brach of motorsport. I also like the inclusion of cockpit view, if not its implementation.So what do i dislike so much about it, well here goes. Why oh why would they remove the buying of cars and customising your team livery. That was one of the best things about the first grid, it felt like your team. Now its just a sucsession of meaningless contract races and the only progression involved is watching some XP bars go up. Thats literally the progression, no unlocks, no buying cars, no customising, nada. But without a shadow of a doubt mybiggest gripe is the ommisin of pitstops. After damaging my car mid lap, i thought id pit and get some repairs. Spotted the pit lane entrance line, dove towards it, and hit a tyre wall blocking its entry. Really this is sub par for a racing game even if its trying to fit into the "simcade" category.Now the multiplayer looked a lot more promicing in terms of progression, with a garage you could presumably fill with cars you actually buy, maybe even customise them. However after the stale taste i was left with by my singleplayer experience i didnt do much MPat all. I felt like they had gutted the best bits from SP an then tacked on a worse version to MP.My advice for a winning grid title would be. Include pitstops, I mean really its a car game. Have a large garage we can use for both single and multiplayer, earning the same currency in both modes. Give us back team customisation, this really connects the player to the game. It makes it feel like its "yours", not a borrowed ride.ProsStunning graphicsDrift evetsFireworks at spa!ConsNo pitstop featureNo team customisationBraking model still needs workThis could have been a great simcade racer, but the singleplayer experience dosent connect the player to the team or the car. The progression is terrible, nothing there to unlock, just watching bars fill up with different colours. All the ingredients were there, but for me its a "go backand try again" moment for the grid franchise.As i mentioned though i didnt play much MP raceing, maybe id have gotten a different impression if I had done more. But after my SP experience i didnt want to go any furter with it. Very dissapointing :(

												I can recommend this game certainly. This game is good example of a game of the racing genre. Grid Autosport shows us a great graphics of tracks and cars, everything is designed to the smallest detail, areas are as in the real life, they create you an impression that you are there what you can compare with the real life situation. So you see.. you can find a lot of pluses in this game. I`d like to continue describing them to you because i`d like to highlight these details and facts which can give you an advice to buy or not to buy this game. The game can be boast of it`s reach list of cars, tuning and upgrade packs and tracks. There are lots of cars and etc. There is no any problem. There are cars of different makes of different countries and disciplines. As for disciplines they are very different that was feedly marked in grid 2. Autosport shows 5 car sorts: street, tuner, endurance, open wheel and touring cars. They enclude coupe, super cars, gt, gtr cars: gt3, gt1, formula cars, touring cars, prototypes and other different car classes. I like cars and i like that sphere and it`s main for me, that`s why i`m descrimbing thats oll now. I think car disciplines is a main thing in that game because cars of one discipline can`t race with the car of different discipline but can race with the car of the same discipipline and that is simply realistic.(in contradistinction grom grid 2) Remember the first grid game- racedriver grid. I think that and lots of other things were borrowed grom that game that weren`t found in grid 2. Tracks are olso very realistic and hard. And I can give a big plus for these details to grid Autosport. I think the game had managed with them. But everything that i`ve just said is not so important. YES it`s certainly important for the game but not so much as other main details. Car`s Hadling! Codemasters made a normal and more realistic and involved handling than in grid 2. In my opinion the present grid`s handling is better than in grid 2 and such handling should have every game of the racing genre. the present car`s handling can "undestand" only an advanced racing player therefore i can recommend  this game to a player of such sort. About auto`s handling we can speak for a very long time and lots of players hihlight this fact. I think the hanling and lots of other details were borrowed grom Racedriver Grid. As for me racedriver is the best game (Bue racedriver grid!)in the grid series*. I`ve noticed these similarities with racedriver in Autosport. And it`s good that the creators added to their trird grid game classical traits grom their first grid. Now summarize. Grid Autosport has lots of pluses. But it has some minuses which were left lesser then in grid 2. I think the game is not finished. Yes, its finished but i think the creators from codemasters could do everything better and more evolved. There some storages in the game. I can`t describe them. Maybe this game is a little boring and less impressive then the last two games or something else. Probably this game shouldn`t be  the most gameability among the this genre players. I think people from Codemasters can do better games. All is in their hands. Generally Grid Autosport is a good game and i recommend it to advanced players. As for me I like this game and I don`t have any reasons not spend my presious time on it.

												I'm a really big fan of SIM racing games such as Assetto Corsa and Gran Turismo so when I decided to pick this game up I wasn't expecting much. It was really just to be a relaxing game that was a new addition to my library. However, I was extremely surprised at how much fun this game can be. The physics are simple. I jumped right into the open wheel championships and couldn't stop driving races. The AI are competitive and I'm sure you could make this game extremely difficult with the AI set to max settings. I would really recommend this game if it is on sale and you're looking for something new to add to your lineup of racing games. Certainly not a sim racer, but definitely an excellent all around racing game.

												I can recommend this game certainly. This game is good example of a game of the racing genre. Grid Autosport shows us a great graphics of tracks and cars, everything is designed to the smallest detail, areas are as in the real life, they create you an impression that you are there what you can compare with the real life situation. So you see.. you can find a lot of pluses in this game. I`d like to continue describing them to you because i`d like to highlight these details and facts which can give you an advice to buy or not to buy this game. The game can be boast of it`s reach list of cars, tuning and upgrade packs and tracks. There are lots of cars and etc. There is no any problem. There are cars of different makes of different countries and disciplines. As for disciplines they are very different that was feedly marked in grid 2. Autosport shows 5 car sorts: street, tuner, endurance, open wheel and touring cars. They enclude coupe, super cars, gt, gtr cars: gt3, gt1, formula cars, touring cars, prototypes and other different car classes. I like cars and i like that sphere and it`s main for me, that`s why i`m descrimbing thats oll now. I think car disciplines is a main thing in that game because cars of one discipline can`t race with the car of different discipline but can race with the car of the same discipipline and that is simply realistic.(in contradistinction grom grid 2) Remember the first grid game- racedriver grid. I think that and lots of other things were borrowed grom that game that weren`t found in grid 2. Tracks are olso very realistic and hard. And I can give a big plus for these details to grid Autosport. I think the game had managed with them. But everything that i`ve just said is not so important. YES it`s certainly important for the game but not so much as other main details. Car`s Hadling! Codemasters made a normal and more realistic and involved handling than in grid 2. In my opinion the present grid`s handling is better than in grid 2 and such handling should have every game of the racing genre. the present car`s handling can "undestand" only an advanced racing player therefore i can recommend  this game to a player of such sort. About auto`s handling we can speak for a very long time and lots of players hihlight this fact. I think the hanling and lots of other details were borrowed grom Racedriver Grid. As for me racedriver is the best game (Bue racedriver grid!)in the grid series*. I`ve noticed these similarities with racedriver in Autosport. And it`s good that the creators added to their trird grid game classical traits grom their first grid. Now summarize. Grid Autosport has lots of pluses. But it has some minuses which were left lesser then in grid 2. I think the game is not finished. Yes, its finished but i think the creators from codemasters could do everything better and more evolved. There some storages in the game. I can`t describe them. Maybe this game is a little boring and less impressive then the last two games or something else. Probably this game shouldn`t be  the most gameability among the this genre players. I think people from Codemasters can do better games. All is in their hands. Generally Grid Autosport is a good game and i recommend it to advanced players. As for me I like this game and I don`t have any reasons not spend my presious time on it.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: August 6, 2015
												Out of all the racing sims available, and I have all of them, this one is still the best.  Projects Cars looks better, Asseto Corsa has better physics, IRacing has the leagues and community, RFactor2 and its "subsidiaries" have loads of realism,  Forza has countless cars, etc., etc., but this game is very well-rounded in all of those aspects despite not mastering any of them.  IMO, the damage model is simulated extremely well and can be comparable to Dirt Rally.  I've seen some wrecks that really blew my mind and many of them were without my direct involvement and rather the end result of the Ai simply pushing their machines beyond their limits.  I'm glad there is a rewind feature for those moments.  And the Ai are incredible.  Other than iRacing, I don't play against online players.  Simply too many factors can work against me.  So, I rely on really good Ai behaviour and you get it here.  I can't begin to describe how well of a job Codemasters has done in programming the Ai.  They're not too hard and not to easy, not overbearing or sloppy/wreckless.  The best Ai I have ever raced against.  Awesome.  There are many good racing sims out there, but this one is a must-have.

content:
Posted: July 7, 2015
												GRID Autosport is a great game. It has many great things like good graphics, nice sounds, lots of cool tracks, many awesome cars. But then there's the AI. Oh god, the awful AI. The AI is way too agressive. They don't know where your car is, which brings problems like being spun out by a rival car or trying to go up the inside of an opponent when there's a big enough gap for your car when you enter the corner, but in the middle of the corner the AI forces you into a wall. They just don't give a♥♥♥♥♥♥about your place on the track and sometimes they force you out wide, which is fine in the corner, but at the exit of the corner, they force you into the wall. Apart from the AI being♥♥♥♥♥♥and basically ruining the single player experience and the cockpit cam being♥♥♥♥♥♥(will get to that in a bit), it's a good game. The online is cool (eventhough it's fairly dead), the physics are nice and the menus are easy to use. The reason I said the cockpit cam is♥♥♥♥♥♥is because of the way the devs blurred everything. The dials are blurred, the mirrors are blurred, the steering wheel is blurred. Basically everything except for the windows is blurred. I like to drive first person. If the dials are working and the rear view mirrors actually have a use. The mirrors being blurred creates the problem that you have to look back manually, which may cause you to drive up a slow opponent's♥♥♥♥♥ which is fun *cough cough*It are just 2 things, but they are 2 big things able to completely ruin the game for me.Good job, CodeMasters Racing....Well done....

												This is the first time I refunded a game. This game is not bad, but just not suitable for me. All I wanted to start with was getting a car to practice on a track before starting a career mode, but in the first hour I just couldn't figure out how to do that. I needed to enter the career mode and try all the buttons in a race. How could I won a race without practicing with a car on a track in a sim? The graphic is great, and run smoothly on ultra without a lag. The handling is OK, it's not totally arcade, but not a pure sim if compared to Assetto Corsa. I would say it's like Forza maybe. I wanted to keep it but I felt it difficult to just pick a desired car to run on a desired track, and then after an hour I lost my patience so I refunded the game and went back to Assetto Corsa and Project CARS.

												After playing Grid 2 and having mixed feelings, mostly because it felt like a repetetive taks, I was hoping Autosport would win me over. It did not. This is emphasized by the fact that your progress is only shown by XP bars and in return you get naught.Example:You can not choose your cars in career mode. You get left with choosing a class and then a team, which participates with certain fixed cars in the available events. So if you want to drive a certain brand, you are out of luck unless Codemasters decided to put them in the fixture.

												I don't know what to freaking say about this game other than Dirt 3 is a GREAT alternative that doesn't cause anywhere near the same amount of frustration.Fun aspects:+ Feels like driving a car on a track sort of+ Good force feedback on a Logitech G27+ Fun to throw supercars on a time trial track and just driveNot fun aspects:- The AI accelerate faster than you off the line- You're usually in 16th so it takes laps to catch up (your event rival is sometimes in 1st even)- You have the beat the rival in 4-6 lap races -_-- Even if you win, your team never does because your teammate SUCKS- Ravenwest drivers do some physically impossible stuff (ie higher speed cornering, not damaging etc)- The driver that flipped over can be seen in your mirror catching up to you at twice your speed- No consistency with FPS on different events (have to constantly mess with graphics settings)Really not fun aspects:-- Penalty forces you to drive super slow-- The driver behind you suddenly touches your bumper causing you to spin into the grass then get a penalty-- The driver in front suddenly brakes causing you to try and stop into him then spin into the grass getting a penalty-- The driver behind ignores your existence in a turn and pushes you off-- The AI constantly ram through you because their cars push like twice the boost yours does?-- Everyone's got the same car as you AND STILL ACCELERATES FASTER THAN YOU GAAAAAAHI still recommend because I don't mind playing it in small amounts. It makes me want to throw my G27 out the window if I play it too long.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: July 24, 2015
												Been playing this game a long time now, and i wouldn't normally bother reviewing games. But this one seems to cop a bit of flak and i can't for the life of me figure out why. This is a proper race driver game. It's not a full simulation sure but its damn close. It's a brutal game at the best of times.. almost strategic.. If you don't brake at the right time/take the wrong line around a corner/too much throttle and you can lose it all and i ADORE that in a game. Having said that i love the flashback ability and how you only get a few of them to use. They really come in handy and will have you sit there and ponder how you could have done better/alternative stradegies. It does not kill the experience and the game is far far away from being too easy. AI is absolutely brutal and its scary as hell when you are winning and you can hear their engines behind you closing in. Speaking of scary stuff.. How about barreling down an F1 track and having your front tyre blow (in cockpit view). Or that moment you realize you've not remembered x corner correctly and you see wall. OR even better.. When the AI stuffs up ( and they do.. and its spectacular) as they go flying over the top of you. Or spin out right in your intended race line. The other thing i adore about this game is the Mini coopers/classics races.. All of the cars have a very real feel to them. If you're in a mini.. it feels tiny and nippy and they are SO MUCH FUN to drive. And most of the mini races do nothing for your points so they are there just to have fun with. Other realistic features i like: The game feels genuinely stressful to play if you're trying to play serious. A real race driver would be stressed out. The noises.. the whole game feels chaotic like a racetrack would, You hear the car at work, If someone smashes into you and you lose a window.. everything outside gets louder etc.. The opponents being right behind you is scary stuff. The feel of the cars..you easpecially feel when you have damaged something quite badly and it feels like it should.. If you break your suspension you hear all the bumping around and it feels harder to control. Lighter cars feel light, F1 cars feel really damn quick and make you think about EVERY MOVE. The only way to play this game is with full damage on. Id also recommend playing it with at least a 360 controller.. I don't have the time or money to buy a full wheel/pedal set but i imagine that would be an even sweeter experience. I could go on forever about this one. I tip my hats to the devs.. My favourite car game to date. AND its cheap.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: December 5, 2014
												GRID Autosport does a lot to correct many of the issues I had with GRID 2. The cringe-inducing, over-the-top presentation has been toned way down. The narrator and your crew chief speak in a calm, non-irritating voice, and they generally only tell you relevant information. For example, when an accident occurs during a race, your crew chief no longer feels the need to inform you. Instead, you might hear the stadium announcer take note of it over the loudspeaker. It's a small touch, but it goes a long way towards adding realism to the game and alleviating a lot of the annoying dialog that plagued the first two games in the series. The game also doesn't have fake SportsCenter clips or any other such nonsense. The focus here is on the driving. On the track, GRID Autosport can be challenging, exciting, and frustrating, just as any good racing game should be. I found the handling model to be a good balance of fun and realism. It requires far more thought, caution, and finesse than GRID 2 did, but it's not nearly as punishing as a true simulation. On harder difficulties, the AI offers up stiff competition, and they race each other in a believable fashion. 16-car races offer that perfect balance of chaos and control, and they can be an absolute blast. In contrast, time attack and endurance events offer you plenty of opportunities to dip into that zen state in which you can focus on hitting every apex and shaving off tenths of seconds here and there. GRID Autosport's mix of different racing types do a lot to prevent boredom. When I was getting a little tired of one style of racing, there was always another that I could easily switch to. Visually, this game is gorgeous. With the high-resolution texture pack installed, car models, buildings, and other in-world objects look fantastic. While earlier Codemasters games often used ugly filters that would wash out colors, GRID Autosport's environments are bursting with color, and the lighting model makes everything pop fantastically. The city stages are borrowed from GRID 2, but I don't blame them, as these are teeming with detail that make them a sight to behold. Famous buildings and landmarks, background details like descending passenger jets, and a nicely modeled crowd all go a long way towards adding to the immersion. For as much as a racing game can have an "atmosphere", GRID Autosport nails it. If you're looking for a game in which you can slowly amass a gigantic garage full of exotic sports cars, this game is not for you. This game is not Gran Turismo or Forza. Nor is it Assetto Corsa or iRacing. You don't buy cars, you don't upgrade or customize cars, you barely even tune them. This is a game solely about racing, as the title suggests. So long as you know what you're getting into, you won't be disappointed. I was pleasantly surprised by GRID Autosport at almost every turn, and it gets my recommendation for anyone looking for a solid sim-cade racer on PC.

content:
Posted: December 5, 2014
												If you are looking for a racing game inbetween simulation and an arcade one, this is the game. You can jump behind the wheel in a lot of cars, and drive them on a lot of tracks with various circuits (GP, National, Reversed etc.). It is similar to what Grid 1 had to offer, and does not make all the errors Grid 2 made.There is still penalty given if you cut track.Singleplayer career is awesome, multiplayer is not too bad either, tho there are always players who just wants to watch the world burn. Side by side action is not so often, and 30-40 percent of the time one of the two participants are knocked off road, or forced to use a FLASHBACK, which is still the dumbest thing in a racing game.Controller/Wheel is recommended, tho I've seen a number of players beat everyone with the keyboard, so that shouldn't be a setback.If you are looking for a more serious racing sim, go play assetto corsa or wait for project cars, or if you just wanna have fun with cars, turn towards the needforspeed series.I do recommend this game, not even the singleplayer gets boring, multi is there also if you want to challange other players, and in every week there are 5-6 new RaceNet challenge to compete in.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: December 5, 2014
												It's a great game.A bit different from Grid 2 which was basically drifting all corners. It was just too easy, like too casual. I liked Grid 2 but then I got this game, which is miles better (pun intended).The game seems much more matured and actually has five categories for racing, which is great to have different racing styles instead of just normal "Street" racing: Touring, Endurance, Open Car (Similar to F1 or Indy Cars), Tuning, and Street. This organization is great. At first, this game appeared to be not fun at all. More like a simulator, a boring one. But I now have the hang of it and had to get used to actually braking on the corners instead of drifting all of them. You have to be strategic with the corners, not oversteering or understeering. That's what makes it fun. Plus, the list of features added goes on. Small things like the racing line, and many other difficulty settings added, an assortment of cars, quite a bit of tracks, TONS of cars. Yes some of the tracks were recycled from Grid 2, but they were good tracks anyway, and also improved.Overall, I've been hooked on this game lately. It is just a fun game to play, which I would rate a 9/10
