Posted: November 28, 2014
												My take on Grid Autosport.Good PointsBeautiful Graphics, The track and cars look brilliant with the HD Pack cranked right up makes it just delicous to look at while racing.Mechanics, The game in itself is very good not full simulation but enough to keep the "die hard" racing fans more then happy.Eveything all in all is very good, nothing you can really say that is truly bad about the gameplay or the multiplayer versions of the game other than some racers as like most MP's want to ram and spin you off rather than race cleanly.Bad PointsTC/ABS the assits in multiplayer you should be able to disable either ABS OR TC not have to have both off which makes for some really good on the edge racing, but alot of people that aren't used to racing without ABS, will steam down the home straight and lock up, wiping out 2-3 racers at the start of a race.DLC - Just not enough cars even with all the DLC needs to be atleast another 2 car packs to come to make up for some of the race classes that only have 1,2 or 3 cars unless it is a specific race class of course. Needs more older cars aswell as newer cars,  A porsche or another daily drive supercar wouldn't go a miss or even some more hot hatchs to blast round with.DLC - Again frustrating really.. If you are a player with DLC all the cars should be availble in the selection list even if the host doesn't own the DLC you do. As for tracks then they shouldnt be of course avaiable to those without DLC making them unable to join a game but for cars they should be unlocked at all times along as you own the DLC to use such cars.Multiplayer rammers can be a bit annoying when they purposely crash in to youre car, rendering it a complete wreck and have to retire, But on a side note it can be fun when you are waiting for the ram and you give it a bit of flick and they slam right into a wall so i guess it is a trade off really :)Drifting for me i don't think it is very good but that is my opinion maybe other drivers really enjoy the drift on Grid Autosport.Overall the game is pretty awesome but a few little things that i don't like have dropped it a point or i would of gave 10/109/10 not too shabby.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: November 27, 2014
												If you like any of the previous GRID games then you will be happy with this itteration. It combines both simulation and arcade racing. There are pretty severe downfalls to this game however, and it does truely ruin the experience.The singleplayer is a decent experience. It is the typical arcade style menu system in which you choose a race out of a list and take part in it. Compared to GRID 1 it is very simplistic. You simply pick a race, pick a team and go! You still have a team-driver taking part with you on most events and have the ability to change his driving tactics. All of this would have been great if the AI weren't so clumsy. On the easier difficulties (easy or medium), they are extremely slow and easy to win. Even with inexperienced gamers. However, as soon as you pick a higher difficulty, they become extremely aggressive, ignore the player and drive with the strength of a tank. You will be span off the track constantly. Having only played online with friends (not publically either), I cannot comment on the entire online experience, but it is pretty good. When the online lobby is first created, players can join fine, the first race is usually flawless. However, oftentimes there will be game-breaking desychronisation issues on some races after that. One main issue I keep encountering is where the AI will not load for the players properly. The host will see ALL AI, but some most will not move and stay at the starting grid. Other players will either see the same, or not see any AI at all. You and your players can race fine (although unfairly) but the race will never end since the AI haven't even moved from start line yet. There are MORE issues with online, that will most likely never be fixed by codemasters.In conclusion, I recommend this game IF you like any of the previous GRID games AND if you can get over the constant bugs and flaws with AI and connection issues. It is fun (for the most part) and is ever so steadily improving with DLC. Hopefully Codemasters will at least attempt to fix the online issues before pumping out even more DLC for a broken game.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: December 15, 2014
												The best racing game I've played in about 10 years.So many racing games these days consistently exhibit 3 very annoying things:Pointless narrative/career management thing where some old racing veteran gives you pointers and you 'work your way up' and/or choose sponsors etc. (Toca Race driver 3/Dirt 3)Unecessarily flashy seizure inducing menus that look like they were created by the Top Gear editing department and/or some needlessly 3D menu that takes forever to navigate and the graphics options are hidden behind the noticeboard or something. (most NFS titles/Dirt 2)Not enough racing, usually caused by point 1 and 2.GRID Autosport has none of that. You play the part of a racing driver, not some rookie, and you're racing from the moment you start the game. The menus are white text on black background. Glorious.Also, unlike a lot of other racers, you don't actually have to win every race because advancement is based on gaining experience. Which is just as well because the races can be very close.You also gain more points by making the game more realistic, and it can be very realistic. To top off all the good points they also brought back support for head tracking.If you like racing games this is probably the best one you can get for the PC just now.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: February 1, 2015
												I previously gave this a non-recommended because of rubber-banding, but after playing it more I have to revise my opinion.For whatever reason, Codemasters decided to put rubber-banding in for Touring Cars, but the other 4 disciplines have no rubber banding. I'm sure it made sense to someone up there...Ignoring the rubber-banding, this is a pretty good racing game. The four disciplines feel nicely different in the way they drive, making changes to the set-ups in your cars now finally actually makes a difference in the way they handle, for the first time ever there are practices and qualifying, so you don't just always start on spot 9-12, and you can adjust the race lengths from normal to X2, X3 and X5, which is pretty cool. Street racing is as cool as it was in Grid 2, Open Wheel is fantastic fun, and the drifting is longer than in Grid 2 where it was waaaaaaay too short.There are some bad things too. The graphics engine, while running smoothly, is getting really long in the tooth, and they basically copy-pasta'd something like 60% of the tracks from Grid 2 just straight into this one. The AI is still god-awfully terrible and will happily plow into you if you happen to be driving on their racing line (seriously, ♥♥♥♥ you Nathan McKane!) essentially forcing you to drive weird lines so as not get rammed off the ♥♥♥♥ing road by them.The Endurance discipline is a nice idea on paper, but in reality the whole "you have to worry about your tires" gimmick just makes you drive ultra-careful which is just plain boring. Coupled with the fact that even at X5 length you only race during night time, but that night time is now just basically a "slightly darker day" versus the absolute terror of seeing NOTHING at Le Mans in the first Grid, and it's just a boring chore of a discipline to play through. Racing should be about balls to the wall driving at your limit, not carefully entering and exiting corners so that my stupid tires don't give out too soon.While there is no stupid "You must gather social media followers to advance races!" crap in this one, there still isn't the sense of team ownership / deciding on sponsors / buying cars etc from the first game, and I can't figure out why they refuse to put that back in. Here you still just drive for teams with crappy team mates and often crappy cars and it's disappointing.Finally, the in-game commentary has progressively gotten worse from game to game to the point where here it just constantly repeats itself (does hearing a "standings update" that tells you your ten points ahead of ravenwest in the overal team standings sound like something you want/need to hear every lap? No? Well, you'll still get to hear it for 30 laps in Endurance Also, enjoy hearing the commentator count down every minute during practice. "7 minutes left! 6 minutes left!") and never actually gives you any helpful info. The best thing to do is to just turn it off.All in all, it's enjoyable to race in 3 of the 5 disciplines, it runs smoothly, and you can definitely tinker with set ups to get the cars to drive the way you want them to. If you like not-too-overly-simmy racers, this is worth picking up for $10, but I expect Project Cars to blow it out of the water. (or at least I hope it will.)

												Yes, yes the game has nice graphics, nice cars, the DLC's are there to rob us, ok, fine, just remember this: leave the  traction control and ABS turned on, otherwise you'll find yourself spinning out of control in the last lap just before the finish line with no flashbacks, at which point you'll start screaming like a mad man and destroy your keyboard, Xbox controller, or that fancy Logitech wheel! Or a nearby window.Because this is what this game does to you, it will make you MAAAAAD!!The camera shake... My God the camera shake!!! One of the worst features of this game, it's annoying, it literally makes you sick and the worst part it can't even be turned off!! Even if you set it to 0%, the camera will bounce your view into new vomiting heights. My head hurts after playing this boring game. Didn't any of the beta-testers saw this before they released the game? Is this a feature now? Making you sick while you play it's a feature now?The controls don't make any sense even with a Xbox 360 controller. They are just to twitchy and non intuitive. There are advanced options in the menu screen regarding sensitivity, liniarity (what is that by the way?), dead-zone, but changing any of those values doesn't seem to have any effect.Combine the awful camera shake and the twitchy controls and an unbalanced AI, which is boring to beat at very easy mode, but kicks your @$$ at easy mode, and you have the recipe for a very annoying game.What happened to Codemasters? Grid was awesome! Dirt 1 & 2 were awesome! Dirt 3 was so-so but still fun, didn't even bother with Showdown. Grid 2? That was a piece of $#!t. But Grid Autosport was supposed to redeem the series, they were supossed to listen to the fans, and how did they listen? By putting an awful cockpit view with no moving dials, low resolution textures, i mean why did they bother? I've played mobile racing games with better cockpit views.This is dissapointing game. I can't recomend this even on sale. I got it cheap, but i pity the others that got it at full price, only to find out that they have to pay extra to get the full game. 29,99 for a season pass? For this game? No thank you.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: April 4, 2015
												All i can say is, for original GRID fans, it's what you were hoping it would be!I have a love/hate relationship with Codemasters. The DIRT series has been fantastic, but it was hijacked by DLC and Ken Block. GRID was...well, lets not even begin to discuss why GRID 2 was pathetic. GRID (1) was an amazing game, and if you loved that, then i'm certain that when you play this, you will get a nice fuzzy feeling, reminding you of the joy that you had playing the original grid. As you can see, i have not played Autosport for very long, but i already feel like i can tell you that Codemasters have done well to go back to what made GRID so special. If you're looking for a new TOCA, then this game won't deliver for you - i think that those days are gone for codemasters. With their DLC policy, and their habit of spewing out new F1 games all the time, it's clear that the financial team have had a bit of a deathgrip on the devs who just want to make amazing games with endless content.I know this isn't shaping up to be much of a 'review' of the game, but i hope that this helps to give you an idea of what to expect when buying Autosport. The gameplay is very nice - I use a G27, and the game has plenty of support for wheels. One thing i would suggest is, before you play, get all of your settings in order. For some reason, when i started, there was a 20% deadzone on my steering, clutch, accelerator and brakes which is pretty stupid. Physics are, (so far) perfectly fine, and the AI is much better than i expected it to be. All of my experiences with Codemasters games have had great AI, so it was surprising to me that so many people said how it was 'too aggressive' or 'blind' - In my personal (brief) experience, i have found the AI to be challenging, and rough, but that's how you're supposed to drive! I had a lot of fun battling for positions in an experience very much unlike iracing, gran turismo, forza and raceroom. It's a breath of fresh air playing a game that lets you be a bit crazy at the wheel!The career mode is good, but not as fun as the original GRID. There is a similar leveling up system, but it is a little bit impersonal when compared with the experience that you had in GRID 1. There is no garage on the main menu, and most of the game is very 'clinical', getting you straight into the racing.I have only had  a short time with this game, and i'm excited to play more. I feel that, if codemasters decides to make a new GRID, without terrible, terrible DLC, it will be at the level that the sequel to GRID1 should've been

content:
Posted: March 8, 2015
												Great split-screen!I've played this game in single-player for a bit and it seems good enough. Shiny, fast, quite lavish with it's set dressing too. But I'm gonna extoll the virtues of the split-screen mode.It's really well featured compared to it's competition, which often don't even do a split-screen mode nowadays. This game however gives you an excellent 2 player split with an assortment of options. You get a total grid of 12 cars (including the players) which really helps to up the drama and you can choose to do individual races or group some together to make a championship type affair either through one formula (eg GT cars) or have a number of disciplines in the same championship. You get the option to race at night or day on most tracks and you can choose any of the courses featured in the singleplayer game. You even get a replay, again a rarity in split-screen racing games nowadays.I know not everyone uses the split-screen mode if anyone out there is looking for a good 2 player racing fix. You could do far worse.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: December 28, 2014
												After almost 40 hours and over 300 races in the solo campaign on this game on hard difficulty with my gamepad, I have to say: this game is probably one of the best in the genre that I have played of recent on the PC. I thoroughly enjoyed both Grid 1 and 2, but I put 20+ hours more time into Autosport than I did the first 2, and for good reason too.This game has great diversity in both cars and tracks. On top of this, it also has 5 disciplines: Touring, Endurance, Open Wheel, Tuner and Street. So whether you're into drifting around a track to score the most amount of points, or endure a 12 minute race without burning your tired out, or just want a straight up race, this game offers a lot for fans of the racing genre. Plus, there is a free DLC available for the game that allows you to play a demolition derby mode, much like the previous game in the series.As you race in these various disciplines, you will earn XP and will gain levels based on a) how many races you participate in, and b) how well you do in those races. Once you have reached level 3 in ALL disciplines, you will unlock the first Grid Series Championship event (level 6 = the next and level 9 the last). This will take upwards of 30 hours to achieve, which is why I put so much time into this game. And I enjoyed the ride (no pun intended) :)So, if you enjoyed the previous games or have played other racing games such a the DiRT series or even popular racers on console (e.g. Forza), then I'm sure you will like this game, and hence I definitely recommend it! The car physics are a bit of a cross between arcade and simulation too, so if you weren't a fan of Grid 2 and adored the first in the series, you should try this one out. Plus, in the solo campaign, there's no purchasing of new cars nonsense. You simply pick a team and get given cars to drive in (which, personally, I preferred!).Enjoy! :D

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: February 22, 2015
												First of all let me say that I bought this game and all the DLC in a sale, so my perspective may be different than others.Everyone wants something different in a racing game. Some want a sim, some want the ability to throw throw turtle shells, some want to drive six-figure cars without the real-world limitiations such cars have. When a game doesn't meet the needs of a particular player, it is easy to say the game is "bad" when it may not be the case.  I like a healthy dose of aggression in my racing games whether it be from projectiles, or some good old-fashioned rammin'.GRID Autosport falls into a good place on the continum. The physics are realistic enough that there is a challenge, but not so much that I can't drive faster than 60mph without spinning out. The damge modeling is strict enough to encourage clean passing, but forgiving enough that I can use my time-tested "Get on the inside of the other drivers and use them as a bumper" conering technique.  The AI is agressive, but not Sebastian Vettel. These factors come together to make the racing feel like an impression of a real race--trading paint, driving at the limit to catch up to the car ahead while fending off the cars behind, stubbornly accelerating while the other drivers start braking before a turn, risking a catastrophic crash to squeeze into an impossibly small space, etc. The flashback feature emboldens you to, as your coach says "Take some risks" without fear of runing your race. As you probably know, there are several disciplines and event types but to me the game really shines in the "Street" and "Touring" modes (in that order).  Even though there are a lot of recycled tracks and you have to play through the series' multiple times to unlock all the cars I've never had a boring race and that's what keeps me coming back. Not many other games have you catching air on the urban-hills of San Fransisco in a Mclaran P1, ramming a Koniseegg Agera sending it flipping down the other side, then making sure you hit the braking zone so you make it through the chiccane smothly.

												I cannot recommend this game. The best thing I can say about it is that it is better than Grid2. Much better, but that's not saying much. Is it better than grid 1? In some ways it is and other ways it's not.You can drive in actual races on actual tracks and there are some interesting tracks and cars, but the way they drive without any aids is not realistic at all. I'll have to find it because the game has promise to spend some time with, but the weird physics are annoying and I was never able to finish a race. I simply got bored halfway.Grid 1 was not stellar either, but to me it was at least engaging. In fact, I have pages and pages of complaints on Grid1, but after considering when it was released and how both audiences and technology has advanced, releasing a slightly better game than Grid 1 seems a bit silly.

												Grid Autosport is very similar to Grid 1 in terms of racing.  Maybe a little less arcady than the first one.  It gives buyers new cars, tracks, and a chance to play on steam servers instead of Tunngle or something.   However, unless you have some friends to play with, you're going to have a tough time even finding a custom game (which is further limited to whether the host/player trying to join have the dlc being used).  I personally like the campaign in the first one more -- I never wound up beating this one.  I like the tracks and the multiplayer mechanics more than Grid 2 though -- which was overall more arcady  (imagine Grid 1 mixed with Hot Pursuit 2).   The corner cutting mechanic is still unpredictable, but better than Grid 2.  I'd reccomend this game only to those who have some friends wanting to race  (lack of player base).    If you're looking for a solo racing game, Grid 1 is just as good of a buy.  The only feature I occasionally play on this game is the weekly racenet challenges.

content:
Posted: December 25, 2014
												Looks like Codies hurried to win back fans they lost from GRID 2.  This is the game GRID 2 should have been, however it does not feel like it should have been a full priced release. Pros:The handling is an improvement over GRID 2 and much closer to GRID 1.  Drifting will slow you down in this game, not speed you up like it did in GRID 2. GRID Autosport has a great car and track selection.  The online level cap has been increased on this game and will take a considerable amount of time to reach giving you something to strive for.  Online race clubs have been added and a very similar damage system to GRID 1 implemented.  Car tuning such as ride height, brake bias, suspension etc and vehicle upgrades are also available. A generic rear view mirror has also been added.Cons:The point to point tracks are gone.  Seems as though online suffers the same issues as GRID 2. The online community is even smaller, some players still have a tendency to use your car as their brakes for the corner without penalty, and similar corner cut issues from GRID 2 still exist. Players will not be able to join games where the host has DLC the joining player does not regardless of whether or not the DLC is being used. The cockpit view looks terrible and the cockpit view mirrors are not functional.7/10

Posted: January 1, 2015
												Graphic, physics and handling is great of this game. BUT the gameplay is such ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥t. You almost never can drive your own car in multiplayer, not to mention the broken single player. There are 5 disciplines and each discipline has like 8 sub-divisions. Each of those 40 or some divisions has usually 3 cars avaliable to choose from to race in that division. To put it simple, you cannot drive a Mustang against a Nissan 370z since there are not in the same division even though they have very similar specs! What's more ridiculous is cars like Mini, Alfa Romeo 8c has its own class! That means you can only drive your own 8c when you join a 8c-only event. And guess what? You only has 10 car slots to start with. Chances are you buy a car and never have the chance to drive it! I mean, this is such a poor design. I dunno what's gotten into Codies' minds but it's truely regretful to see brilliant contents get absolutely destroyed by the stupid idea of "Autosport" divisions.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: January 1, 2015
												GRID Autosport hits the sweet spot between racing simulator and arcade racer. The physics pose a challenge on the limits of adhesion and reward a wheel/pedal setup, but aren't so demanding as to require huge investments of time to transition across the many racing disciplines. Graphics and audio are good but are not the focus point of the game. This plays more like a spiritual successor to the TOCA Race Driver series than GRID 1/2 and has filled a void that has been on PC for a very long time. Highly recommended

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: January 24, 2015
												Pretty much TOCA 4. If you disliked the GRiD/DiRT switch and found F1 and GRiD 2 to be a disgrace, you'll probably love this. You get a bunch of cars, from WTCC, DTM, Supercars, UTES, F3, Indycar and prototypes that you can race on lots of road and city tracks, day or night, reverse and alternate layouts. It doesn't feature the rallycross and other half♥♥♥♥♥♥♥trucks and rally stages, so it focuses a bit more than older TOCAs. Looks pretty amazing, with great performance on lower hardware, tight controls with basic car setup options to fix any issues, great track models, variety, a custom championship mode with lots of options, but only 5 events. The AI can get pretty fast for a good challenge, but it hits you pretty often, causing you penalties and spins even when there's a lot of room to pass cleanly, so that's annoying. The car interiors are terrible, but I prefer the dashboard view, which is perfect for visibility and feel, like in the NASCAR games.  Had some problems, like the save game disappearing, certain options being reset, and obviously it wouldn't be a modern Codemasters game if they didn't chop off some tracks and cars to be sold separately. It's a shame, but it doesn't detract from the fact that this is their most solid game in over ten years. Too bad their reputation will keep players away. Never expected to like this game so much? 5-lap battle for 3rd place at Bathurst in a DTM Audi, hardest difficulty and no assists? Yes, please. That was awesome.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: October 11, 2015
												Many people want a realistic racing simulation, not a racing game.Codemasters tries to please everyone, it's a nice challenge but it actually makes frustrations in both worlds, nothing technically overwhelming though.Pros:- Mostly good physics- Mostly good graphics and sounds - Mostly good UI (nice and smooth)- Wide variety of cars and circuits- Many settings available- Upcoming Linux supportGameplay cons:- Hugely annoying inrace slowdown due to penalty (Most stupid decision ever that ruins the game)Physics cons:- Lack of friction that leads to lack of grip- Steering soap effect partially corrigible with settingsGraphics cons:- Not readable dashboard in the cockpit view- No cockpit rendering when looking sideways- Geometry of cars not detailed enough- Skid marks sometimes buggyUI cons:- Too many useless choices at the begining (waste of time)- Awkward sequence: choice of discipline, then choice of circuit, then choice of car- Very slow loading of cars during selectionSuggestions to Codemasters:- Use a button to switch the focus and make the dashboard readable- Allow access to the speed information during the replay- Don't stop the replay when the user switch to another application- I'm a code master, contact me if you have any question ;-)

												On Reflection after a long break - mechanics were a definite improvement over GRID 2, drifting discipline was finally Okay, but still not as enjoyable as GRID 1 had. Which is me doing the full game twice. Should you? No. No Reward. Didn't go past this part in the game.Multiplayer? Not reviewed, i would have, if the drifting was as fun as GRID 1.Conflicted feelings - i enjoyed it, but i am reviewing this as another "No" to the series.
